Draft at Hollingshead in Orange, CA. Pours a nice, ruby color with hardly any head. Aroma is thick of berries and sweet malt. Light, tart flavor. Strong cherry presence. Tasted very fresh. Not strong in the tart department, but still there. Excellent beer from Russian River.

Bottle of batch 006 at Apex. Pours a ruby brown with a small pale head. Aroma is sour cherry, currants, red wine, fig, balsamic vinegar. Medium-full bodied, vinous mouthfeel, sweet and acidic on the palate with a slightly dry fruity finish. Taste is currants, sour cherries, figs, red wine.

What a delicious tasty treat for the palate of beer consumers across the World. Absolutely a Beautiful craft of flavors and smells with tart cherries, red wine, luscious fruits, sweet malt and some good ole barnyard funk in there to twist you up a bit but  then you got a genuine balanced beer throughout which is thumbs way up. My hats off once again for another amazingly crafted beer. Ladies and Gentlemen, Enjoy!

Bottle. This is a banger, but you probably knew that already. Pours a deep, dark purplish brown. I wish I had furniture in this color. Smell is funk, barrel, vinegar, wine, fruit, more. Elegant and complex. Taste is big-time sour but other flavors come through nicely -- Cabernet and currant arent at all lost. Alcohol is well-hidden -- I wouldnt guess this was 10% if I didnt know.

Poured from a bottle bought from Russian River a cloudy burgundy with minimal head.
Aroma of a lovely sour scent of wine & malts? Definitely got the sour thing going here.
Oh double damn the flavor is incredible. Fruity boozy sour funk is crazy. Not a huge cab barrel aged brew fan but this one blew me away. So good.

Very sour but drinkable (had 2 on tap @ Isaac's). Great taste, no complaints.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared with a friend. Pours ruby red with a small beige head. Aroma is funky, red fruits, dried fruits, cereal, barnyard and a bit nutty. Taste is pretty sour, medium sweet. Some grapes and a bit alcoholic. Awesome. Loved every sip of this beer. Long dry finish. Full bodied with soft carbonation.

Near perfection for this type of beer and it doesnt seem like a beer. Fresh fruit and sour on the nose. Nice ruby color with a small head. Dry mouthfeel with a slight puckering but not overdone. Small amount of carbonation. Flavors were so well blended that it was very wine-like. Subtle fruit flavors with a little hops but very comforting. A must try.

Simply amazing. If you like sours get this beer. The alcohol does sneak up on you, so sip carefully. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a bubbly copper w/ no head & not much lacing. Aroma screams sour! Taste is tart & sour but somehow relatively smooth. Very different & quite good!

The beer pours great with a reddish brown hue, the smell is great with a sour bourbon fruit smell. The taste is a bourbon boozy taste with a bitter fruit taste on the back end (plum and current). The mouthfeel is great with a solid bitter fruit taste and a dryness on the back end...the beer was carbonated appropriately. Overall, a solid sour beer with deep dark fruity taste.

Batch 005X1E - 375mL bottle.
Aroma has a vinous dark fruit character with lots of cherries, berries and what I can only assume is what currants smell like. A hint of a leather note along with some light oak notes. Moderate acidity and a hint of alcohol. 
Pours an amber brown with some ruby notes. Thin tan head that recedes very quickly leaving a slight film on the edges. 
Flavor is rather tart upfront with a moderately strong dark fruit character similar to the aroma. Medium light oak character with a hint of tobacco. Slightly vinous with low bitterness and moderate acidity. Light alcohol note in the finish with some lingering dark fruit notes. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with low to almost no carbonation; the cork was starting to dry out and it only slightly hissed when popped. Light astringency with medium low alcohol warmth.
Overall I really enjoy this beer and I think the age has added a nice touch of complexity to it. Lots of people say this beer doesnt hold up as well as the others to the age, but I think it did better than the Supplication. The fruit still tastes rather fresh and hasnt washed out yet but it could use a touch more carbonation.
Bottle pour at home. This sour lives up to the hype, but then again so does every other RR beer. Im loving the deep red wine flavors coupled with the strong sour cherries!

Bottle: Medium tawny brown. froth fades very quickly. Huge lift. Very sour and extreme. Sour fruit, floral, hint of malt. Old oak. Just funky. Dry. Very sour. No bitterness. Acid level is like sucking on a green lemon. Flat sour palate. Long but acid driven. Medium to light medium weight but long. Oak, fruit and floral. Caramel and berries. Savory. Very old world. Like drinking Rioja!

Tap at Toronado. Deep reddish purple pour. Loads of deep red wine notes on the nose - delicious blackberry, blackcurrant and prunes - great tart critic notes, red wine vinegar, decent barnyardy musty funk. Taste is an explosion of dark berries - so juicy - huge vinous notes, lemon juice, musty funkiness. Lingering tart berries and lemon juice. Great balance. No hint of the ABV. Shit me, this is wonderful.
Rated from backlog. Dark red color. Lots of fruit notes, very citrusy, vinous. Very tasty and complex.
Poured an amber red from the bottle with aromas of wine, sour cherries, light funk and some acid. Flavors are the same, tart cherries, dipped in wine, a solid beer overall thanks for the share.

Refrigerated 375 ml brown bottle corked and capped poured into a tulip. Pours dark brown with crimson hue with no head. Aroma is sour, body medium, no carbonation, and no lacing. Taste is tart, some wine, and some vinegar. Expected a lot more based on other ratings.

Its unbelievable that this is 10%; seriously, you cant even tell through all the complexity. Aroma is over the top: sour cherries, spice, faintly cinnamon, prunes, stone fruit, and oaken character. Taste is sour cherries, sweet earthy undertone... This is not the kind of sour brew that is reminiscent of vinegar. The finish is sour with a jaw aching dryness. Seriously, if you like sour brews...if you see this... buy it...Im seeing stars...

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2013 On tap at Russian River on 062013. Clear copper with a minimal head. Nose is acidic cherries, sherry, oak, dried fruits. Like a funky barley wine. Taste is somewhat tart with sweet fruits and sweet malt with a dry tart finish. Smooth body and soft carbonation. Warming and refreshing.

375 ml bottle. Pours a clear ruby color with a small fizzy head that quickly fades to nothing. Aroma is red wine, sour dark fruit, light raisin, and oak. Taste is fairly sour but not as much as other RR beers Ive had. Red wine presence is strong. Tart finish with a hint of raisins. Solid sour but Im surprised to see this is the top non-retired sour red/brown. Ive had better but Im not the best sour judge.
Out of bottle. Pours hazy red. Very fizzy pour, excellent beer. Up front sour, tart middle and a very clean finish. Wish it lingered a little more.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2017 Re-rate. Bottle. Reddish, copper color with a thin, fizzy beige head that lasts and laces some. Aromas of tart cherry, wood, funk, lemon, tobacco, jam, and vinous notes. Flavor is tart cherries, lemon, funk, wood, grape, plum, tabacco, and light vinegar. Medium body, smooth with a tart, drying finish. Moderately sour, slight acidity.

This beer is a weird brownish red colour, with a nice fizzy white head. Aroma is lots of funk, aroma is sour cherries, oak and red wine. Taste is a very well balance of tart and sweetness. Wood finish is prominent, with a nice dry red wine flavour. Enjoyed!

On tap at russian river brewery. Pours a solid black. Sour on the nose. Little head. Very bitter/sour with a slow and bitter finish. Smooth for its strength. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark ruby color with a fizzing head that quickly dissipates. Tart smell with hints of wine and fruit, mild funk. Incredible taste. Not too boozy. Great sour. Carbonation dies quickly. Goes down smooth. Want want want

I'm not a fan of sours but this one is really good. Very flavorful. But not overwhelming. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark ruby brown color topped by thin off-white head. Awesome aroma full of grape skins, currants, oak and balsamic vinegar. Tart and dry without being overly acidic. Nice dark fruit jam flavors and lingering oaky tannins. A slight toasty almost smoky malt character compliments the fruit nicely. Great beer.
UPDATED: OCT 9, 2013 Tart delicious beer! Aaaaaaaaaa Aaaaaaaaaa Aaaaaaaaaa Aaaaaaaaaa Aaaaaaaaaa Aaaaaaaaaa

Reddish pour with thin white head. Sparse lacing. Aroma is all Cabernet Sauvignon with raisin and prune notes. Taste is tart berries on a backdrop of subtle malt. Medium body, lively carbonation. Very nice brew!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Off Tap at the brewpub. Dark pour with a white head. Tastes of sour dark fruits and has pleasent sweetness.

Type: 12-oz. (I think) draft
Glass: Goblet 
From: Russian River Brewing Company in Santa Rosa, Calif. 
Price: $6.75 
Purchased: July 17, 2013
Consumed: July 17, 2013
Misc.: N/A

Poured a reddish dark brown color with one finger of khaki white head when I got it. Below average foggy lacing on the sides. Minimal-to-bad retention on the top. 

Smelled dark cherry, black cherry, sour cherry. So cherry. Also raspberry, red wine (Cabernet?), purple grape and plum.

Tasted similar to the nose, but better. Got sour cherry, black cherry, Cabernet red wine, sour grape, plum and raspberry. Very smooth. 

Medium body. Oily texture. Soft carbonation. Long, smooth finish.

This beer just got better each drink. Fantastic.

12.68 oz. bottle from the brewery. Batch 8. Deep mahogany color without any head. Great nose! Black Cherry, notes of oak and Lees. I get a lot of barrel notes in the flavor. Musty oak, pond moss, Dark berries, red wine, wood sourness. Medium-full bodied with moderate carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel with with a sour and warming finish. ABV is not noticeable. Mild vinegar notes that are slightly off putting. Overall still pretty good.
Tap at brew-pub..Pour is dark with a off white head..Nose is sweet and spicy, bugs, tart, currant..;Taste is tart, bugs, barrel, dryness, dark fruits, nice sweetness

Pours dark red brown with low white head
Aromas of bretta, red wine barrels, cherries and a touch of caramel malts.
Taste is absolutely marvellous. Great balance between sour and sweetness. Filles with red berries and cherries.

Bottle from the USA cheers Phil; hazy chestnut pour with thin off white head, red wine like aroma, taste has grapes backed up with some dark fruits, plums and dark cherries, sourness and Brett are present, amazing beer.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2013 Thanks to Tommy and Chris for this, so refresh my memory on how this is 10% because it feels like I am drinking supplication with currents...maybe even a bit sweater...hints of oak, dry backbone, and some sourness.  
 
Update 9/30/2013
Alright so now I can rate this good and proper. Sour red brown pour with some light fizzy carbonation.  Aroma of sour cherries and hints of oak. Flavour is sour boo ya shak a, little bit of oak right in the middle, acidic finish on the back of the throat. Just fucking great. Love it.

Batch 005 poured into a tulip glass. Well balanced sour with deep, dark fruit and slight wet blanket interplaying. Slight honey in the background. Oak is lightly pronounced. Amber-caramel and hazy with an off-white head that is nearly non-existent but leaves a collar. Tart and tangy with dark fruit. Above average carbonation. Very dry. [Woo hoo!!!  I was the 1000th rating of this beer!!]

Chocolate, tobacco, currants, dark fruits all figure prominently in the aroma. Clear dark brown body is topped by a decent off white head that recedes to ring. Sweet up front with a creeping tart sour followup. Plenty of dark fruits and citrus and some mineral qualities. Champagne-like effervescence and medium body. Tulip glass. Allowed to warm from fridge temperature. Bottle. Batch 001X1.
UPDATED: JUL 4, 2013 Wow first sour and I love it need more. Aroma is cab smell, sour flavor then sweet fruits cant say enough flavor is great. Reminded me of when i was a king with a sour warhead
Dark ruby pour. Very sour. Sort of a dark fruit sour. I dont see why so highly rated.
Really good sour. Pours a translucent brown with no head. Smell is sour fruit funk. Taste is of course a fruity sour that makes your mouth water. Really nice and refreshing.

Bottle. Pours a clear and extremely dark brown color with effectively no head on it. Nose has a little bit of sour in there with some dark fruit notes in there. Taste is definitely sour and will make your mouth pucker a bit. Seems clean and smooth, though a tad rich.

This is beer? It has a fizzy, tangy wine flavor, that is almost champagne / wine / beer / ale. Not very bitter more like a sweet and sour. I would recommend this to anyone as it is a unique brew that has a great flavor. I had this at yeasty beasty in Monmouth. Something new I have never tried before awesome Flavor.
Dark orange pour with a tiny white head. Big currants, wine and barrel aroma. Taste is big fruity currants, big barrel aromas.

Batch 01 thanks to ParkerDaniels. Murky reddish-brown pour with brown head that disappated quickly. Aroma is fruity and sour. Taste is oak, sour, acidic and dry. A fantastic sour mouthfeel that later showed dryness. An awesome beer that was worth trading a GI BCSV for.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2013 Bottle from Ales unlimited in SF.Pours with very thin head that quickly dissipates. Very obvious scent of the cabarnet sauvignon. Will definitely make you pucker up. Another great sour from Russian River.

Rated this with my girlfiwnd whod never had a sour before, i wouldve rated it higher. Its good and.complex, taste like a soir green grape. I dont taste the barrel that much but it had to mellow out the sourness. Great beer from a a great brewery. Thank you RR
bottle. Red amber with two finger head. Sourest beer Ive had. Huge pucker power. Also, very nicely fruity. Awesome.

I got a bottle of this as a special from Yeasty Beasty.  What a great treat!  It pours a beautiful, dark, ruby color with a small head.  The aroma is of dark fruit, which makes perfect sense, being as it contains currants and is aged in wine barrels!  The taste is almost sweet up front, with a tart to sour finish, without the sourness being overpowering.  Dark fruit and a vinous quality make this a complex and enjoyable beer that should be sipped slowly and savored.  It would probably pair quite well with slices of a sour baguette or some bruschetta topped with smoked salmon or shellfish.

Bottle from Conn Ave aged 2 years after purchase - catching up on old ratings from Oct/Nov 2012 timeframe. Big sour beer that smacks you upside the head and makes you want to call for your mommy. Fantastic.

A great blend of sweet and sour with a complex palate with flavors of oak, cherry, currant, grapefruit, and Cabernet Sauvignon.  Has a very acidic mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

First off, what an amazing smelling beer. Lots of fruit notes, very citrusy, wine notes. Color is dark purple/red color, you can definitely tell its been aged a while in Cabernet Sauvignon barrels. Overall a wonderful tasting beer, highly recommend! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2014 Much better than my previous experience with a sour. Bottle share thanks to Mary. Brown color with a slight tang to it. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2013 Bottle at the Smiths. Pours deep amber with little head and no lacing. Fruity aroma with barrel character and hints of leather. Taste is puckeringly tart and fruity with no booze at all. Medium mouthfeel with high carbo. The usual excellence from RR.
Bottle>snifter.  Light murky brown with no head.  Aroma: sour brett, currants, honey.  Taste is tart, with grape juice, dark fruits, slight vinegar.  Very good, but not as good as Supplication.

Pours dark copper with no head. Aroma is deep ripe berries, nice brett, sweet cherries, sour berries, currants, vinous, a little lacto acid, fresh vanilla, nice barrel, a little bit of fruity tobacco and some apples. Taste is nice ripe fruits, sour currants, dry wood, dark oak, brown aleish notes behind, apples, a bit of vanilla here too, pretty tart in general, nice brett and a bit of lacto acid.

Dark ruby brown with no head. Cheesy, funky scents with some dark and sour cherries as well as grape juice. Very brett-centered, sour taste at first fades into some sour cherry notes with a tannic finish very reminiscent of a cab. Barnyardy notes at the very end. Medium high carbonation.

translucent amber brown with a creamy beige head. medium bodied. the sharpness of the acidity makes the medium-high carbonation feel quite prickly. 

aroma: sour black cherries, dark crystal malt, brown malt, complex sourness, musty basement, black currants.

taste: clean sharp sourness, chocolaty malt, dark fruit (including black cherries, black currants, plum, and fig), malt sweetness, cocoa or carob powder, musty basement, and a medicinal cough-syrup finish.

there are elements of this beer that i love, but there are also some unpleasant and overbearing wine and medicinal notes that overtake them. i think i would enjoy it a lot more if aged in barrels other than cabernet barrels.
Another excellent sour beer by Russian River.  This is a great sour beer.  Good flavor from start to finish
Poured at brewpub. Dark amber with thin white head. Sweet tart grape nose that carries through to the taste. Also get hints of some boozieness.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2016 May 19, 2013 - batch 6 bottle via trade.  Brown pour with limited head.  Aroma was sour fruit, wood and red wine.  Taste was consistent with aroma, but heavier on the brett than red wine.  Light carbonation. light to medium body and somewhat dry finish.   August 3, 2016 - on tap at RRBC. Bumping to 4.1.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2014 375 ml bottle from Supermarket Liquors.  Deep reddish appearance with a small, dissipating white head.  The aroma is nice and tart with notes of dark fruits, wood and light red wine.  Similar flavor, sour, fruity and dry.  No sign of the 10% ABV.  Very nice!  Update:  Still awesome.

Wee bottle from adnielsen - many thx bro, shared at Linda and Björns, cons 2013-05-09, Lysekil
AR: tart, red berries, wee vinos, lemon juice
AP: murkey bourgone, wee reddish head
F: tart, black currant, kriek, horse pee, - great brew!

Bottle courtesy of Homer321. Pours a dark ruby and brown color with a quickly disappearing white head. Aromas are forest floor, leather, brett and rum raisin. Flavors are tart raspberry, blackberry and some grape flavors with a strong tannic flavor that reminds me of grape skins over a very nice brett sour characteristic. The mouthfeel is perfect with tons of carbonation to lighten this heavy ABV beer. Overall, this is a superb beer that leaves a long grass and grape/apple skin aftertaste that reminds me of my wine drinking days, excellent!

Pours dark reddish brown with a fizzy white head that recedes to a ring instantly. Aroma is oak, red wine, and sour fruit. The taste is tart sour cherries, oak, tannins, tobacco, and bitter, sour fruit. Nice carbonation and really smooth on the palate. Delicious.

Batch-005X2E

A - Pours a dark ruby brown color with an off-white head.

S - Red wine comes out strong along with lots of clean wood. Dried cherries, musty old church-like funk.

T - Sweet/sour cherries, tart raspberry quickly overtakes any sweetness with a lactic acidic bite. Malty sweetness barely bleeds through with notes of faint cocoa. The finish is a sensation of having plum/grape skins on your tongue along with a sharp punch of acidic sour right at the end.

M - Low prickly carbonation, thin body.

Wine and wood are strong components. Sharp and sour with lots of tart fruit character and was nice to have some good funk in there as well.

This would go great with grilled goat cheese filled mushrooms.

Serving type: bottle

04-22-2011

Drank in tulip glass poured from 12oz bottle. Aroma - tart aroma with light blackberry notes. Appearance - amber colored with light froth. Taste - strong sour notes with a little bit of red wine taste. Palate - very sour and funky mouthfeel. Overall - really good sour but not my favorite

Bottle. Rarely do I spring for a bottle this expensive (probably overpaid but sometimes beer lover's impulse strikes) but I do not regret it one bit. I am new to sours (and became a fan thanks to The Bruery's Sour in the Rye), and the balance of this brew is just perfect looking forward to Supplication next!
Batch 2 bottle - what can I say that my score dont say. This is one amazing beer. Aged to perfection, perfect balance of sour. Beautiful color. Currant and wine and age = perfect beer!

Deep red pour with a thin head.  Long oak taste.  Hints of charddonnay.  Oak and vanilla.  Aroma is sharp.  Lots of sour notes.  This is very drinkable and tasty.  Light mouth.  Probably the best sour Ive had of this style.

Pours dark ruby red with little to no head.  Aroma is sour cherries with barnyard funk and oak notes.  Taste is tart at first then a well rounded body with oak, cherry, and leather aftertaste.  Overall one of my favorite sours that has a great balance of sour and fruity body.

Pour is dark ruby red with small ring head that fades quickly. Aroma is overripe fruits, vines, wood, sour funk, cranberry juice. Flavor is barnyard funky sour at first but then transitions into a wine/cabernet body with a dry fruity finish. Sour of course, but much more controlled than others in the style. Im still not a huge fan of sours but this is a step in the right direction.

Bottle. Hazy deep amber liquid with small light brown head. Aroma of lemons, red currants, light oak, apples, light funk, lacto and cherries. Taste is dry and medium sour with notes of red currants, lemon, apples and light barnyard. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Nice stuff, great sourness and a good taste of berries.
Dark brown and transparent, aromas of sour cherries and Cabernet. Very tart with no letting up from the sourness of the Bret yeast.
Bottle. Pours dark with basically no head.  Aroma is tart, wow. Super nice smelling sour. Flavor is sour apple and cherries. Solid sour for sure.
Sampled at the brewery. So damn good. Chocolate, fruity, bright acidity, vinous. This is one of the best sours made. So glad I had this at the source.

Pours an opaque caramel color with no head. Tart apple and Belgian yeast aromas. Ok, so Im not a wild fan at all. I mean, as much as I want to get it, I just dont. Have you ever picked up a sack of apples that have fallen off the tree? The sack was left outside all night. You went out the next late afternoon and picked them up. The movement stirred the honey bees inside. You stuck your head in the sack. This beer tastes like that apple sack smells. I do enjoy how after the beer disappears from the palate and I lick my lips, theres a sweet taste that, subsequently, appears on the tongue. Im still developing my palate for the wilds. Bear with me.

What a monster. Pours like a dubbel with more reddish highlights. The aroma is dominated by crushed wine grapes and some barrel but there's some biscuit and cherry underneath too. Lovely balanced palate entry that comes in sweet and finishes very comfortably sour. Wow. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375mL bottle. Batch 008.

A: Cherry coloration with a very thin lacing of head. The beer is actively moving in the glass; a geyser rises from the middle and and turbulates the beer. Light legs.

N: Sour cherry, currant, powerful acids. Very vinous, plenty of wine grapes, and the oak is noticeable. Light blackberry. New leather and some funkiness.

T: Wow, lots of currants. Theres a pleasant sour pie cherry in the background, and the oak and acids are moderated well. Some tangerine /lemon zest. I do get some light tobacco/leather flavors.  Grapes and a little bit of raisin. Has a lot in common with the cabernet sauvignon barrel.

M: Light and very, very well carbonated. I am getting a surprising amount of alcohol, though. 

O: A sterling beer that Ive passed over too many times to count. While off chasing the newest sour from around the block, Consecration beckons us back to its sublime, balanced fruitiness. Delicious.

ok, time for a treat...pours a deep garnet hue with no head to speak of.  aroma is very sour, vinegar, lots of berries, and red wine accents all shine and meld together nicely...great nose for a sour.  flavor is sour, but not overpoweringly so...cherry, other red berries, red wine, wood and tart apple...solid stuff.  highly carbonated but surprisingly easy to drink for the style...only knock I really had is that the finish seemed to end abruptly.  residual dryness after the finish, but not a lot of potency.  excellent beer...one of the best sours Ive had...
Im not sure if I like supplication or consecration better... It just depends on the day.

Pours dark hazy red with a small, dense white head. The nose is great I must say. More currants than wine barrel which suits this sour just perfect. The nose has natural berry aromas and none that are too candied. I like it a lot. The mouthfeel is great as well, creamy and light at the same time. Perfect carbonation - farmy and bretty at the same time and a perfect amount of berry coming through too. A decadent joy :0)

Pour dark slightly hazy ruby-red, with no head. Aroma is really nice and complex of sour berries, cherries, wood, green apples, dry wood, tart, cherries, sour sweets. Really nice. The taste is quite sour, with the perfect amount of sweetness. Really enjoyable!!
Medium bodied, with some semi-fizzy carb, which really suits this beer very well. Well made indeed... Thanks to the guys at "de bierkoning" for giving me this. Hell yes...

Bottle. Thanks Benji and Sev. Clear mahogany brown with little ring of head. Strange aroma, couldnt get my head around it until I read the description, its red wine with a little vinegar and oak. Taste of red wine, tannic, light funk ans vinegar. Harsh fizz and very sour.

An amazing beer.  Nice ruby brown pour with effervescent bubbly head.  Aroma is of tart fruits and red wine accents.  Almost sherry like.  Taste is tart, sour, but not too much.  This is one of Americas best Flanders style brown I have ever had.  Great balance between the malts, wine barrel aging and body of the beer.

Batch 1 bottle shared at RBWG! Pours a hazy brown with little to no head or lacing. Aroma of dark fruity esters and sweet, tart fruits. Taste is super tart, but not in a bad way, well balanced and not overbearing, no where near the taste of 10% abv. This is the king of American sours, and I can see why.

From a 375 ml bottle shared at home.  Batch 007.  Pours a clear deep amber with a feint off white head that quickly dissipates.  Aroma tart cherries.  Some raisin and grape notes balancing the tart apple and cherry.  Crisp tart finish.
Rbwg beastiefan ftw! Hazy reddish brown small white head. Omg! So good. Super sour red fruit cherry raspberry and wood. Always enjoy this beer.
Heavily hazed mahogany. Tart fruits and toasted nuts in the aroma. Aggressively tart like Orange juice.
Batch 1 bottle shared at RBWG. Sour, sour, sour. A bit of balsalmic vinegar, currants. This is pretty good, but its a little past its prime.

On Tap, Pours a mahogany color with a light off white head with decent lacing. Smells of currents oak and and other dark fruits. Tastes of all the same things in the smell. Mouthfeel is heavy and surupy with pretty good carbonation and a dry finish. Overall this is a great sour too bad this is probably the last time in a while Ill have it because they pulled distribution out of this state.

Pours a deep mahogany brown with ruby edges a lil eggshell fizz that rises and settles quickly. On the nose are deep vinous cabernet notes of dark tart ripe berry, rustic wood, with touches of chocolate undertones. The palate is just as complex with  lots of grapey fruit, tart sour cherry and woodsy earth funk. Lots of vineyard character mixed with wild yeast notes.... great finish. YUM !

Pours dark red. Tastes sour/tart, wine, and plum. The oak flavor from the wine barrel comes through. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle been aged about 1.5 years I believe.

Pours dark wood, rich red color with small fluffy head, dissipates quickly, leaves some lacing.  Nose is sour, wild. Smells like the wine barrels its been aged in for sure.  Tastes very winey sour, woody, dry, dark fruits. Darn tasty!

(bottle - corked & caged 375 ml - Night of the Titans 2013) Hazy golden pour with a puffy white head. Wonderful tart and sour aroma with a light sweetness from the cab sauv barrel and the currants. Flavor is mildly sour, not over powering but more than enough to know that its there, and a light oaky sweetness at the end. Smooth and easy to drink with a great sour aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours dark plum with a cream head. Very effervescent, persistent carbonation. Aroma is fruity, light and tart. Taste is very well balanced. Not overly sour, but nice and sweet tart. Very vinous in a very pleasing way with a nice juicy balance.
Red clear. Fruity sour in the smell. Taste nice and tart with a nice cherry almost plum in the after taste.

Bottle from Capones. Pours an almost clear ruby-mahogany with a thin finger of off-white head. The head fades down fairly quickly leaving behind a touch of lace. Aroma is a mix of sour dark fruits and currants with some Cabernet Sauvignon grapes, oak, earthy smells, and just a touch of booze. Starts off with a mix of strong sour currants and dark fruit with some dark grapes, vanilla, and a touch of tobacco. Through the middle, oak flavors come through with some more dark fruits with some sour cherries and plums. The finish is a mix of sour dark fruits, dark grapes, oak, some earthy flavors, and some booze. Medium-full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a sour and warming finish. Once the palate adjusts a balance masterpiece of a sour that only gets better with every sip. One of my favorites.

375 ml bottle received in trade. Thank you Adnielsen! Pours clear reddish golden with a small pinkish white head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace on the glass. Smell is sour, tart and fruity with black currants, red currants, acetic acid, moist wood, dark grapes, tannins, lemon juice, leather, lemon zest, rustic red wine, perfume-like tobacco, alcohol, vanilla, ripe gooseberries, unripe strawberries and very subtle hints of glue. Taste is sour, tart and fruity with crackers, red currants, rustic red wine, moist wood, hay, tart slightly unripe raspberries, black currants, moist soil, leather, tobacco, alcohol, blackberries, raspberries, frozen strawberries, bread, tannins and hints of black currant jam. Mouthfeel is dry, fruity tart, tiny mouth puckering and medium bodied. Finish is sour, tart and fruity with red currants, leather, bread, lemon juice, tobacco, lemon zest, alcohol, unripe blackberries and strawberries and hints of black currant jelly. Very nice fruity sour...

Bottle, thanks to _angst_. Clear deep amber/brownish beer with a small offwhite head. Vinous vanilla aroma, caramel, tart, funky, tannines, oak, grapes, citrus, pears, peach, cherries, raisins, leather, tobacco notes, red wine, nutty, red currant, sweetish notes. Sourish fruity flavor, red currant, leather, citrus, lingonberries, woody, citrus, caramel, tannines, vanilla, black currant, grapes, warming alcohol, sourish, tobacco notes, leather, funky, banana notes, prunes, vinous, hay notes, some floral notes. Just plain wonderful beer.

Pours a nice clear dark amber color with minimal off-white head that doesnt last very long. Aroma is initially a nice full wine aroma with undertones of sour fruit, cherries and oak. Flavor is initially very bitter sour with notes of fruit that turns into a nice bitter oak and wine flavor at the back end where the bitterness lasts a long while. Mouthfeel is average with carbonation decent. Overall this is a solid sour beer.

2009 vintage on tap. Aroma was cherry cheesecake, tobacco, and prunes / raisins, I could smell this beer all day. Flavor was incredibly sour with hints of oak and dark fruits; Very complex. If youre a sour fan and have not had this seek it out!

On tap @ Mutiny Hall. Pours reddish brown with thin head. Aroma is tart dark cherries and mild spicy notes - which I suspect is currents - I cant say I know that flavor well. Taste is rich clean nutty caramel malt with sharp initial pucker. Notes of brown sugar, cherries, malt, and leather. Just a bit spicy on the finish. The barrel aging seems to tone down the sourness a bit, also adding a real depth of flavor. Easily one of the best domestic sours around. And it takes something to stand out among Russian Rivers offerings. Real pity theyre withdrawing from WA state. Im sure theyll be back soon enough, but it sure sucks in the meantime.

On draught at Baileys Taproom CellarFest 2013. 2009 vintage. Pungent currant sour with funky notes of mushroom and other fungi. Also has a distinct steak sauce finish. Alcoholic yet surprisingly easy to drink.

Pours a clear, dark, brandy, almost non-existent head.
Slightly vinegary, vinous currant aroma...a little juicy fruit gum.
Flavour is tart, berry, sour wood.
Extremely smooth..nice..
Barrel tones are strong and defined.
Had in bottle share while in California for work.  Currants really add a lot to this flavor profile.

Aroma has a slight buttery, cheese note followed by cherry and mushroom that becomes more apparent as it warms.  Flavors include tart cherry, light cheese and butter, mushroom and wood and has a lingering tart cherry finish.  Great balance of fruit, body and tartness.  Tart but not overly so.

375ml bottle. Excited to try this! Pours out a clear reddish brown with a head that vanishes abruptly. The red wine barrels give this a really pleasant aroma along with those familiar vinegar notes that let you know that this will be sour! On the tongue the fruitiness of the barrel plays of well against the dark malt and gets close to the tobacco character described on the label. I had a harder time trying to identify the currants, which seem to be integrated more subtly. Not quite as sour as I imagined but nicely so. Maybe a slight let down from my expectations but still makes me wish I had access to all of their beers.
Pours a darked red color with a small white head. Funk, berries, oak in the aroma. Lovely sour and funky flavour with notes of currants. Lively carbonation. A good sour.
Bottle courtesy of mashmaster. Balsamic vinegar and slightly funky aroma. Clear copper with no head. Oaky vinous vinegar and musty funky flavor. Light to medium body, moderate carbonation.
Bottle.  Currant,  vinegar, and malt aroma.  Dark amber - no head.  Strong oaky vinous malt and vinegar flavor.  Currant aftertaste.  Nice.

Bottle sent by northernbrews, Jeff you rock!  Pours a clear light brown with a thin head, the aroma is amazing, tons of funk with a good amount of sour fruit and the wine really does come through, the flavor has a lot of sour fruit and vinegar notes with the wine and oak coming through in the finish, this was the hit of the night for sure, really hope I can try this again some day.
Had at the brewpub. Super strong sour funky aroma. Little carbonation. You can definitely gets hints of the wine barrel. Amazing beer

Pours a deep, opaque brown with a quarter finger of tan head that settles in seconds. Aroma is sour, fruity, with tones of oak and wine. Flavor is moderately sour and fruity up front, stone fruit, blackberry, raspberry, grape. Fades into smooth oak, with tones of wine and alcohol. A very nice level of sourness. Lively carbonation and light body, with a crisp mouthfeel and relatively dry finish. Oak flavors really come out as it warms up. Delicious and refreshing, an amazing sour.
Dark red color, flat with little carbonation.  Strong sour smell.  Excellent smooth taste that starts on the front and moves to the middle of the tongue.  Even finish, crisp.  Fantastic beer.

Bottle at home (from Beermongers, Portland OR) - 19/12/12.
Pours a reddish brown with a large tan head initially but this dissipates quickly to nothing. Visible carbonation evident.
Nose carries wood, wine notes, funk, some mustyness, burnt sugars, tarte berry fruit, touch of smoke, earthy.
Taste comprises soured berry fruits, woody backbone, grapes, wine, booze, malt, earthy, tarte and bitter.
Fuller end of medium bodued with fine carbonation leading to a dry finish with a touch of alcohol.
Good stuff as always from RR.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Pours dark brown, mostly clear body,  head settles quickly.  Smells sour and funky.  Tastes sour and has nice notes of currants and Cabernet Sauvignon.  Palate is alive and bubbly.  Overall much better than the first time I tried this 3 years ago.  Highly recommended.
Batch 7 bottle. Pours dark burgoundy, very effervescent but nearly no head. Aroma of Brett-laced cab with hints of oak. Taste of beautiful sourness with cherry and tannins. Medium palate.

A superb and interesting sour. Pours almost ruby red. The currants give a nice backing to the tart flavor. The carbonation is almost Champagne like. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From a 12 oz bottle there is no head at all. Cloudy reddish-brown.  The aroma is faint for me.  Cant place it.  A little bit of lemon?  Medium to heavy sour at first, but mellows as the ale warms ... tart berries come to mind.  Very lively, almost fizzy carbonation that softens after a bit.  This has been my first venture into sour ales, and its definitely "different" for me.  I cant compare it to others having had no experience.  And while I can definitely say that this is not my favorite style of beer, at the same time Im surprised by how much Im enjoying this brew, more and more with each new sip.

On draft at Bigwood 12/6, from notes [1 of 11].
May 2011 vintage.  Ruby-red brown, perfect clarity, still surface with only a tiny ring of bubbles around the edge.  Aroma is TART black cherry.  Taste starts tart, ends sweet with some earthy notes in between.  No alcohol burn.  Lively carbonation, nice mouthfeel.

First beer of what promises to be a very good day.  Friends havent shown up yet, so I get this one almost all to myself.  My feeling from this and the few other Russian River sours that Ive had is that drinking these beers is like reading Hemingway.  It is well-executed and straight-forward -- not simple by any means, but not heavy-handedly muddled with overt complex flavors.  Quite tasty.

Leffervescence est bruyante et anéantie la tête en peu de temps, belle couleur rouge sang. Le nez est vinaigré, acide avec une touche boisé. En bouche cest très surette avec un bon effort tannique, des notes balsamiques également. Buvabilité surprenante.
Light brown colour, no head. Flavour picks up the fruitiness of the Cabernet Sauvignon. The sourness on this one is bearable, helped by a thicker, heavier body and the high level of alcohol.

Hell yes this was good. Great tart fruit/ Can totally see the Cabernet Sauvignon all over this. Rich and delicious without being overwhelming. Never once did I think this was overdone or over-the-top. I just want more. Great beer.
À larôme, de notes de thon (?!), pas trop agréables, heureusement accompagnées de levures et de touche dalcool. Au goût, du cassis, des fruits. Bonne acidité et finale maltée.

Bottle (375 ml) batch 005X1E. Traded by jp7161 or iguenard, thanks Joseph and Ian! Hazy amber/brown with almost no head and little off-white lacing. Aroma of tuna, red fruits (probably currants), wood and slight brettanomyces. Taste is moderately sour with red fruits, brettanomyces, wood, wine... quite complex! Mouthfeel is slightly dry and acidic. Very complex beer with awesome balance and great use of the fruits.

375 mL batch 8 bottle to 120mL taster
Raisin, prune, cherry, cassis, molasses, Bret yeast, and lemon. Reddish amber with no head and some settled particulates. Taste is a long heavy acidity with a slight sweetness. This was just what I was hoping for with this beer.

Lovely odor of sweet dark fruits like currants, berries, dark grapes etc., much like a wine but with the decent level of carbonation, it allows the yeast and sour flavors to come through creating an even more complex odor. 

Pours with a very thin, almost absent head which is perfect for this barrel aged beer. A very sour taste with a depth of fermented grapes and currants.  

Palate is excellent with a wide variety of flavors makings its way into the taste.  This version was bottle aged for about six months. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bootle - Batch 8 - Sweet ripe fruits, currants very obvious.  Muddy brown, no head.  Pleasant sourness, wine like with a mild bitterness and long finish.  I would love to age and see what happens.

Bottle, thanks to fredrik_!
Reddish brown with a beige head.
Aroma: wood, berries like currants but also cherries.
Taste: very sour and tart with red berries, wood, vinous.
Medium bodied.

Bottle batch 008 thanks to timfoolery: Poured a clear brown red with a thin whisper off white head. Aroma is very wine like with fruits, currant, and leafy malt. Taste is sour up front that opens the tongue up to that fruit however it subsides fast to sweet malts. I really am against sour/wild ales until a gem like this comes around.

Bottle received in trade.

A good beer. Had higher hopes for it. Like Supplication it lacks that dryness and complexity.

Bottle 750ml. Thx mathieuc.
Pours brown with almost no head. Intense lacing. Aroma is of dark fruits, malt, sourness. Taste is of dark fruits, malt, sourness. Overall: Alcohol very well hidden. Convincing balance. A pretty good beer.
Bottle, batch 8. Pours a clear red with no head. Smells vinous, currant, sour. Medium bodied, medium carbonation, finishes dry.

Not much notes, we had so many good beers back to back. Sour but not too much, this one felt like a more refined La Folie. Damn fine american sour/wild ale! Currants and wood were definitely there, I just cant describe it precisely without some notes. Seek it out for yourselves, please.

Thanks Thomas

Batch 3 750ml.  Poured a dark ruby red/purplish color.  It both smelled and tasted like wine, very smooth can def get the cabernet barrel aging throughout the finish. vineous, vinegar, wine, lemon peel, dark fruit.  would like to try a fresher batch to see the difference.

Smells like apple cider.  Dark red pour from draft with tiny head. Imagery. Good beer. Can't taste the strong ABV 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Batch 006. Very nice wine-like sourish nose. Reddish-brown, glassy surface. Thin fruitiness, some vinegar, and mild sourness. Thin body and extremely astringent. I couldnt really catch much of the Cab notes. A complex brew, to be sure.

On tap - visited during our Californian motorhome trip. Pours deep brown with reddish hue.Clear vinious and woody notes, plums, Medium body with nice sourness, backed up by a roubd mouthful of fruitiness. Quite astonishing beer that goes over most Flemish sour ales à la rodenbach easily! Great bar, great beer.

Oh how I love this beer!  Had on tap at the brewpub in Santa Rosa.  So sour and so delicious.  I cant be more descriptive without having it in front of me again, but I look forward to having it every time I go there.
On tap from the sampler at Russian River, good wine aroma and cab front finish.

375 ML C&C bottle served in a Lost Abbey teku glass. Batch 007. Big thanks to Matt (mfavoino) for sending this my way.

A: Pours a dark ruby color with a light tan head forming on the pour. It recedes quickly to a thin ring. Not much lace is left.

S: Big sweet currents with mildly tart undertones. Some lighter malts are present with a nice cab body showing itself on the finish of each sniff. Pretty earthy and bold, yet restrained enough to let the beer show.

T: Much more sour than the nose would suggest. There is some lactic sourness with a tart current body. The cab gives some dirty grape punch to cut through the sourness. Just a little bit of earthy and leathery malt to counter balance the tartness as well. As it warms a little more of the barrel comes out with some dry oakiness and light sweetness. The booze is so well hidden. I would have guessed, 6% or 7%.

M: Medium bodied with a nice prickly carbonation. There is a little more body to this beer, but it doesnt take away from the drinkability. The finish is slightly drying.

O: The Cab didnt overtake the base beer which is awesome. It gave it just enough earthy undertones to provide some more depths of flavor. This is right up there with Supplication as my favorite RR sour. The booze is extremely well hidden as well. Well put together.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-13-2012

From notes - Snifter pour of hazed brown red with a barely off white head of two fingers.  Nose was super funky, sour, cranberry and dark berry fruit, sulfur and balsamic quite present.  Flavor was barnyard, funk, sour, sulfur and eggs with notes of vinegar following.  Body was on the lighter side of medium.  Definitely a good one.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2013 Light brown, clear. Sour, fruity, brown ale aroma. Very dry flavor, wine, tart cherry, a bit medicinal, some funk. Complex.

Update: my second impression is much better. Flavor is tart and dry, as before, but now cabernet flavors are more overt. Very nice.

Small coarse head quickly disappears. Clear reddish brown body. Vinous vinegary wooden aroma with cherry wax notes. Dry-acidic earthy peppery redcurrant taste with chemical notes. Mid-to-thin body. Sharpish mouthfeel. Dry-acidic earthy funky cherry aftertaste with metallic wooden notes. A challenging, sippable beer. Not bad, but not great, either. (0.375l bottle from City Beer, San Francisco.)

Pours dark amber with no head. Aroma is tart with some fruity notes - plums, sour cherries, but theres a definite hint of sweetness which is more like sweet, juicy, ripe cherries. Soft mouth feel, low carbonation. Very sour with some fruit, must be the currants coming out. Finish is tart and a small amount of bitterness. Alcohol is incredibly well hidden.

Dark amber color with thin layer of white head. What a nose! Sour maltiness with an well aged white wine. Amazing bouquet of complex tart fruit flavors with some hints of single malt scotch. Like a fine champagne with a strawberry in it , Heavy dry cherry tartness on the finish that coats the entire tongue and leaves you confirming that this is on of the best sours this country makes.

Bottle from god knows when. Batch 006. What can I say, this is a phenomenal dark sour. It's perfectly balanced, sweet, tart, a little fruity. Fantastic.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

0.375l bottle. Brown colour with no head. Vinegar aroma with sweet malts and spices. Caramell, vinegar, pepper and lemon. Medium body with a balanced bitterness.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On the nose its caramel, tootsie roll and sour, dark (plummy) fruit. Taste is intensely sour, but judging by mouthfeel this one could age longer.

Batch 008. Pours a beautiful ruby red, orange pretty clear liquid with a off white head that disappears almost instantly. Aroma is very nice at first sniff. First I get some tart notes with a nice balsamic vinegar feel to it. I gett barnyard funk, green apples, cherries, red currant, definately vanilla oakiness in there aswell. Aroma is very wineous and complex. Love it! Taste is; tart, wineous, berries, currants, oak, vanilla, cherries, no alcohol at all just a slight alcohol warm in the throat, balsamic vinegar, barnyard funk, wet overripe fruits almost. Taste is very complex aswell. This is a really nice sour from russian river that I enjoy alot!

1/3/2010 - For my 600th review I chose something special. When I first started drinking craft beers, my stash was marked by an imposed egalitarianism. No beer was above another, and no beer enjoyed a privileged spot. They were a council, electing members to cast their vote on my palate and to be judged. One day I was given a reason to break tradition. I was given a bottle of the Russian River Consecration. A very good (and considerate, and well compensated) friend purchased this beer for me on my birthday. When I took it home I put it on a pedestal, and vowed that it would appear in a very important beer rotation; it could only be had on some kind of special event. It seemed almost as if rather the beer marking the event, the event marked the beer. So, Happy New Years to me, and a warm welcome to 2010, but an even happier welcome to Consecreation, exiting the bottle and entering the world. This beer also augured the near future. It was originally made as a relative of the 20th anniversary brew for Torinado, the famous taphouse in San Diego, and my future home for 5 years as an aspiring Ph.D. student. This beer holds a special place in my review archive, and deserves special attention in both the tasting and the tasting notes. I hush the room, and pour the beer, where the ruby red and almost black body climbs up the glass, eventually unfurling a light tan head. A robust but controlled aroma of sour cherry and roasted cherry tobacco emanates from the nose. Its a nice sour - natural, unique, pleasing - and hints at the chardonnay barrels so proudly employed by the brewers, but like many sour ales, it is a singular aroma. Sourness and acidity are ramped up in the flavor, supplemented by some alcoholic burn. In just one sip it tastes like a barrel of juicy Bing cherries touched by the patient effect of oak aging. Its a sour brew for sure, and I find my eyes watering here and there, but its well worth the torture. As it warms, the Consecreation rolls in some flavors of fine olive oils, introducing low, rolling and smooth grassy and olive notes, which add a third dimension of flavor to a sourness that threatens to wrest control from all the other flavors. Sour beers are not always known for the ornateness or filigree of their flavor profiles, but the flavors they do exhibit need to be keenly profound. The Russian River Consecration does not fail to miss the mark, setting high expectations for my future sour ales, and beginning the New Year with a high mark. (Little did I know how formative 2010 would be. The Consecration obviously did its work.)

Bottle. The pour was a clear deep dark mahogany brown with a small (less than 1 finger) white fizzy head that dissipated in 1-2 seconds and basically had no lacing to speak of.

The aroma was very complex and enticing with a dark grain malt and funky Brett yeast and possessed notes of dark fruit (red grape and black currant), a bit of oak cask and a boldly tart red wine presence.

The taste was sweetly tart and a tad acidic and had strong currant and grape notes throughout, with the finish having a bold and somewhat dry sour wine alcohol taste. The flavor lingered on the taste buds for a bit more than an average duration following the swallow, with a really wonderful sour fruity taste lasting quite a bit longer.

Mouthfeel was right below medium in body with a really smooth dry texture and an almost champagne like carbonation.

Overall I can not express how much I enjoyed this particular brew, it was sweet and fruity yet bold and sour with a fantastic lingering lip smackin taste. By far the best Russian River brew I have had to date. I highly recommend if given the chance, that you most definitely give this one a try...

Pours dark red with a quickly dissipating head. Aroma is tart wine, fruit and funk. Taste is sour, wine and plum with only a little oak overpowered by the tartness. Very fizzy carbonation, very dry and light body and the tartness sticks around with some wine flavors that linger. Overall an amazing sour beer worthy of the hype RR gets.

Tap. Wow does this beer bring it home. Pour hazy deep amber with a small off-white head and some lacing. Aroma is wonderfully tart red wine, cherry, wood, caramel. Flavor is balanced sweet and tart with obvious wine and wood notes mixing with cherry and caramel, leading to a warming alcoholic finish.

12.68 oz corked and caged bottle. Batch 7. Pours almost clear ruby red with little particles floating around under a small white cream-colored head. Aroma is vinegary, barnyard, vinous, oaky. Taste is mouth-puckering sour with a dry finish; nice and acidic. Alcohol is noticeable, but it doesnt taste 10%. Yet another awesome sour from RR.

Notes getting a bit shabby at this point. Appearance: yes. Taste: deep horsey funk, lime juice mingled with vanilla-choc softness: the barrel. Crab apple. Deep dank cellar aroma. Full of limes. Really beautiful.

375 ml corked and caged bottle. Mahogany red color topped by a brief white head that disappates very quickly. Aroma of wood and bourbon tinged with vanilla bean. Wow! the sour notes overwhelm the senses. lots of flavors here. Barnyard, cheese, wine, citrus, plums and cedar. This is truly unique and not for the uninitated.

Batch one bottle thanks to Ari. Pours a deep purple amber with a near white head that dissipates slowly to the edges. Aroma has a strong note of currant with a good amount of acid with a underlying note of oak. Flavor is quite acidic up front with a good amount of currents and just a hint of oak.

Smells fruity, sour wine barrel. Incredible sourness, tingles around the side of the tongue. Hints of clove, tangy fruitiness, touch of tobacco. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

RR seem to have these beers down to an art. Consecration is a perfect example, Looks a nice fruity brown/red colour and smells tart on the aroma. The taste is all there, tart, sour, love the wine flavour, one of the best!

Draught at the brewpub. Even thou ive tasted this beer a few times before its always great to try the beer close to its birth place. Wonderful complex sour and tartness. Wine notes and with that magic aging a good beer in a barrel gives. This has Vinnie written all over it.
Bottle.  Thanks to adnielsen for the bottle.  Pours a reddish brown color with weak white head.  Cherry, oak, sour berries, and grape aromas.  Sour, red wine, cherry, and oak flavors.

I dont know that this beer achieves the near perfection that its rating dictates, but its very good.  The vinegar acidity of the flavor is a sizeable challenge to balance out, but a careful selection of rich malts and the tempering flavors of cherries, currants, tobacco, and grape make this beer anything but uninteresting.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2012 Big thx to Dave for bringing this one from the states // this was for a long time very high on my list // 375 ml bottle @ home // First things first. this is disturbingly close to Bush Presige // seriously I am not crazy it totally is but this one is better // looks like very, very dark wine, dark red / brown I suppose, carbonation is so insanely violent that head disappears and actually almost comes back, goes away, comes back. goes away,,,, // very heavy on wine, cabernet sauvignon I suppose, very, very heavy wine, oak, pure berries, sour, tad vinegar, so full of wine but better than any wine I have ever had // taste is same, so wine heavy, pure vinous, loads of berries, currants, vinegar raspberries, reasonably harsh, vinegar soaked oak, lots of wine grapes, vinegar cherries, vinegar soaked oak, crazy acid finish, hurting the throat // fizzy carb. quickly gone. substatial body  // it is clearly better than Bush Prestige but why is it so damn close? // & oh yeah batch 8

12.68 oz. corked n caged bottle, batch 007, drinking this as 999th rating as a lead up to Supplication as my 1000th - Pours slightly hazy dark orange to red with a fizzy white head that reduces almost immediately. The aroma is tart, cherries, oak, wine grapes. The taste is the same, sour and tart, wood is strong, grapes and cherries, raisins, very complex. Body is medium to almost light, carbonation is high leaving a fizzy feeling after the swallow. Overall I would have loved a better appearance, but from the ageing I think you have to get used to little to no head or lace, that is I am assuming what happens from sitting in the barrel then bottle for sometimes years. Great beer.

A-- Poured a dark brown and settled dark black cherry color. Good amount of haze. No head at all. A little bit of off white film on the sides of the glass but not much else. on swirling the glass got some head but went bye quickly. 

S-- Sweet and sour. Very well balanced nose. Get Cherry, oak, straw, and barn. 

T-- Sweet to immediate massive sour cherry pucker. Cherry sweet tart on steroids. Or is that I mean Oak. Really like how it goes from sweet cherry to massive sour tart cherry and then Oak hits. 

M-- Lots of carbonation in the mouth but still a medium feel about it. Light in the front but gets heavier in the back. A lot of cherry or citrus acidity and cherry sourness in the back. Not that much cherry sweetness in the front but it is there. Can totally see where this is becoming a sour bomb as the sweet is seriously dropping off in this and the sour is taking over in this.

Batch 005X2E. Spicy aroma, like Tequila BA. Vinous, wine-like. If this was a wine, it would probably be considered infected. Amazing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
We were astounded by this beer and its cross appeal to multiple beer drinkers. It had champagne qualities to it that really drove home the unique, masterful Cabernet flavorings. Fantastic beer.

Bottle shared at tasting.  Pours hazy brown with no head, far from the most attractive beer Ive ever seen.  The great stuff starts to come out in the aroma with tart dark fruits, raisins, oak and noticeable cabinet sauvignon.  Nicely tart sour berry flavour with no swwetness.  A fantastic beer, but possibly a little over rated.

3 aug 2012, bottle. Batch 1 cask 2. Rosy amber, faintly cloudy. Nose is hugely oaky, crushed red fruit, and white wine. Thin and a bit fizzy. Very dry palate, hugely oaky, tart, currants, some cherries, maybe tobacco. Alcohol doesn't seem like 10%. Impressive! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, 75cl corked, at RBNAG-11. It pours almost clear, dark amber in color and with a minimal sized off-white head on top. The aroma has popcorn, but not in the typical dms way, as well as caramel notes, coffee and meat. Sourish, roasted flavor with very evident berries. Dry and tart on the palate, finishing with a lasting tart, berry-ish and vinegar-ish flavor. Certainly a nice brew, but Id rather have a regular geuze over this anytime. 111015
210712. Tap at Russian River Brewery. Pours dark amber with a nice head. Aroma sour fruit. Sour berries taste. Long finish. Not Bad.
Dark amber pour...the cabernet sauvignon really comes through with other nice fruit flavors.  Another enjoyable sour from RR.  Awesome!

This could one of my favorite beers of all time. Unique only begins to.describe it. I believe this beer to be a masterpiece. Smokey, fruity, tobacco notes. At 10% alcohol it barely comes through. Well balanced and well done.

Bottle- Batch 007: Pours a clear dark amber with ruby tones and a thin off-white head that diminishes very quickly. Oaky aroma has hints of currants, cherries, and dried fruit. Flavor is sweet and tart with hints of cherries and oak in the Cabernet flavor finish. Ive tasted Cabernet Sauvignon out of the oak barrels in Napa and the aromas and flavors of this ale reminded me of that experience. Simply delicious!

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2012 Blatantly fruity aroma of currants, lime juice, hay, ripe strawberries, old wood, and a vinous touch. If you dig deep enough, youll get to the needly, medicinal, almost acetone-like alcoholic notes and a touch of caramel-esque malts. The taste is very tart, with a lingering sweet-and-sour aftertaste. The alcohol is very hard to perceive once its in your mouth. Theres also the darker, malty components. All in all, a really good beer.

Bottle: Vintage 2010: Batch 004X4: Thanks to Steve: 
Sizzling tan head disappears immediately and leaves a headless more amber than ruby colored beer.
Smell black currants, barleys, yeast, wood/oak, wild yeast, some dark fruity sweetness.
Taste sour darker fruit, sour yeat, sour oak and wood, sour malts tend to go nasty but seems to be stopped due to the sour grade.
Some yoghurt sour, darker fruits, dry, vinous, barleys, barley malted sweetness with a dark druit sweetness that is taken over bu the sour part
Starts with a nice sour dark fruity mix ten goes dry and sour and tends to go nasty sour malty.
Aftertaste is a mix of sour grapes and sour cherries, a nice warm dryness with yeast/wild yeast and malty oak tones.
The aftertaste tends to go to nasty bitter but gets taken over pretty quick, by a more or less one dimensional sour tartness.
Medium to fuller carbo, tingly sparkling spicy mouthfeel, full body and a light creamy texture.
Easy drinkable, considering the alcohol percentage.
Not a bad beer at all, but for some reason I expected something more.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: 2010 750 ml. Pours a transparent dark amber with a thin, light tan head. Complex aroma of sweet dark cherries and oak. Starts with nice biting carbonation and tart complex oak and cherries with some other dark fruit notes and good acidity toward a slightly warming finish. Shared with 3 other people, Damn Im a nice guy.

Bottle @ CBCs 1st Birthday Party. Thanks to the deeblo for busting this out. Cheers. Deep reddish amber color with a small white head. The nose is flanders red - sweet brown sugar, light balsamic tartness with cherry jam. The taste is caramelised brown sugar, wild funk and moldy cherries. Light body, soft carbonation. OK.

Tobacco, leather, dates and funky fun. Drinkable, nice and acidic, complex with leather and oak.  Awesome. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Thanks hugely to Bruce. Good aroma. Good red berry sourness.  yes sour. Nit much funk but certainly sour. Fruit is certainly excellent. Yes fruit is good. Touch too sour. Redcurrant sour. No funk. No poop.

Batch 002X3

Purchased at the brewery in Fall, 2009 and consumed while playing original Nintendo on July 12, 2010. Decadence.

A: A thin and flat appearance, ruby-tinged brown hued with very little head and virtually no retention or lacing. Upon the second pour, the head is very fizzy and fades almost instantly with a hissing sound.

S: Cherries, oud bruin, wild yeast, wood. This beer smells very complex.

T: A lot of flavors going on here. Everything I named in the aroma, plus a funky tartness that makes my lips pucker and my throat tingle. Really profound and complex, this beer is very intriguing and enjoyable. Many sours in the 10% or above abv range are considerably harsher than this.

M: Acetic, vinegar finish that grows stronger over time. Puckering finish that makes the cheeks (on your face) pucker and cringe (in a good way).

D: Im taking on the whole 750mL tonight, but this is certainly a good candidate for splitting amongst a few friends.

One of my favorite sours. Sampling a bottle for the first time after having had it many times on draft. Batch 006. Poured a clear cola brown instead of the expected ruby red on draft. Small bubbly head disappears quickly. Fantastic sour! Crisper and fruitier on draft but dark caramel smooth from the bottle. Perfectly blended now. Very complex barrel notes. Not tasting the red currant as much as in a fresh draft. Bottle version is still definitely sour, but the finish is wonderfully smooth. Not much carbonation, but still has a thick body like a fine cognac. Draft is great, but the bottle is fantastic!

Bottle sample at a sour tasting at Noams office. Many thanks DSG. Batch 006. Pours clear red to brown with a beige head, aroma of glue, vanilla, fruits, dulce de leche  and cream, flavor is sour with leaves, alcohol, fruits, medium to full bodied, live carbonation, great  8/4/8/4/15[3.9] 

Bottle sample at a sour tasting at Noams office. Many thanks DSG. Batch 001X2. Pours brown to red with a beige head, aroma of caramel, cassis, toffee and wood, flavor is sour with chocolate, wood, olives and fruity tones, medium to full bodied, great  8/3/8/4/15 [3.8]
This is the best beer that Ive ever had! A great sour with plenty of kick and a lingering Cabernet taste that is unmatched!

Pours a deep, dark lively cranberry/mahogany with a short lived inch of off-white head. Perfect, beautiful lacing and just wisps of retention remain after a few short seconds.

The nose is exceedingly tart... subtly funky bits of red wine, fresh grassy notes, overripe fruits, lemongrass, and so much more. I can hear the beer fizzing and hissing as I take each whiff.

Dark and sour indeed. Very dry wood character smothered with tart wine notes. Sour grapes, abstract acidity, funky preserves, the woody/earthy notes tender to linger.

A beer thats hard to really describe concisely in words. Its a must-try for anyone even remotely interested in the vast creative potential of this beloved liquid we call beer.

Poured a deep brown with very little carbonation. The nose was heavy of tart fruits, and oak. I just got done drinking a Lost Abbey Red Poppy before this and wondering if it tainted the flavors, because it tasted very similar, just better in balance. The fruit flavors from the cabernet barrels were definitely noticed and the oak was not overwhelming. There was not much sour to it though, which I was kind of bummed about. It was more like a heavy, fruity beer. Not bad, but expected more.

A simply amazing sour beer. Enjoyed many times but not rated. Complex nose, perfect balance of wine, wood and bugs. I love it when science is magical!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2014 Pours a ruby red, kind of a cola color, with a head that disappeared very quickly.  Aromas of oak, sour fruit, tartness.  The aromatic expectations leadme to believe that this is going to be a very tart beer.  Ok, here is the first sip:  we are dealing here with an almost lambic level sourness here, with almost no residual sugar.  This is fantastic news because I hate beers with a sweet finish.  Upfront you are getting a smack of tartness, followed by a clobbering of wood.  Oak, sour fruit and whispers from the dark unknown dominate the profile here.  You can almost here the chant of daedric lords in this beer.  Amazing is all I can say.  Mind = Blown. 
RE-RATE: Bottled on 11/22/13. Slightly sweeter than I remember it but still good. Prickly carbonation, good, deep sourness. This one is a little young, I will leave its original score stand until I revisit this batch in a few years.

Bottle from Marina Market.  This was an awesome beer.  Great tartness with nice carbination.  Taste isnt as sweet as other sours.  Nut this had a nice oak taste.  Shared this with my dad and it was great.  I wish I could get more if this.

Batch 001x4. pours deep red, kind of vibrant in color. thick creamy head piles high and slowly goes away. huge sour notes with strong cherry scents. a little vinegar, i noticed the currant flavor through and through. it blended in well with the sour funk. the oak aging has mellowed this a bit. noticed bits of other dark fruits but the currants really stand out. currants are a bitter fruit alone so they just blended so well with the brett. very nice carbonation. not too much bite and the head did not interfere with the drink. quite smooth actually. Reviewed on: 05-27-2009

Bottle sample at a sour tasting at Noams office. Thanks DSG. (9.5.08, bottled 12.08) Murky nut brown, foamy off white head. Blackcurrants, sweet aroma, tastes sour, alcoholic and oily. Medium body and short finish.

Bottle 0,5 at Monks Cafe, Philadelphia. Muddy red color with a very thin beige head. Vinous oak in the nose with some grape/berry and funky mustiness. Taste is tart and sour with the vinous oak and berries and hints of malt and a little dark fruit. Very good, I sat on this awhile and it was worth it!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared at a sour tasting at Noams office. Thanks StFun for this bottle!  Batch #001X2. Very deep brownish red color. Vinous aroma of berries, quite a lot of oaky funk and some pedio. Sour oaky flavor of berries, a hint of vinegar and a yogurt note. Medium to full-bodied. Really great stuff. 8/4/8/4/17=4.1

Bottle shared at a sour tasting at Noams office. Thanks StFun for this bottle! Batch #006. Clear reddish amber with a beige head. Sour aroma of malt, berries, a bit of vinegar, pedio. Sour flavor with berries, malt, light lactic hints, a citric hint, oak, and a more sour finish. Medium-bodied. I liked the older vintage a bit better, but this ones very good too. 8/4/8/3/16=3.9

A - Pours an almost clear ruby-mahogany with a thin finger of frothy off-white head. The head fades down fairly quickly leaving behind a touch of lace.

S - Aroma is a mix of sour dark fruits and currants with some Cabernet Sauvignon grapes, oak, earthy smells, and just a touch of booze.

T - Starts off with a mix of strong sour currants and dark fruit with some dark grapes, vanilla, and a touch of tobacco. Through the middle, oak flavors come through with some more dark fruits with some sour cherries and plums. The finish is a mix of sour dark fruits, dark grapes, oak, some earthy flavors, and some booze.

M - Medium-full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a sour and warming finish.

D - Very drinkable. I really like how sour the beer is, but at the same time the balance is still very good. The dark fruits really compliment the sourness nicely.
Incredible powerful fruit and tart flavour, almost overpowering, and perfect for me. This was really good!
Damn. 10%?? Dont taste any heat. Oak, brett, red wine, sour - but not over the top. Strong spiced fluffy carbonation on the front end of my palate. color - deep mahogany.

Bottle pour from batch 3x4, muddy red color with a very thin beige head. Vinous oak in the nose with some grape/berry and funky mustiness. Taste is tart and sour with the vinous oak and berries and hints of malt and a little dark fruit. Very very good, I sat on this awhile and it was worth it! Would definitely put this in my top 10!

Deliziosa Sour Ale invecchiata in botti di Cabernet Sauvignon, non a caso vincitrice di tante medaglie nella sua categoria, eleganti le note vinose, e frutti rossi, carbonatazione perfetta ed equilibrio totale per una birra acida fuori dai soliti schemi. P.s. inimitabile....

Bottle at James place. Pours reddish brown with a thin off white head. Funky yeasty aroma with light sweet fruity notes. The flavor is earthy and funky with some tart fruity notes and a nice earthy finish. Good stuff.

I had this bottle in my cellar for  about 5 years.  Pours dark red with no head.  Aroma is sour with cherries and wood.  Flavor is similiar and very tart and has some wine characteristics.  Fruity with a bit a vinegar.  Lively carbonation and ABV is undetecable.  Not my favorite style but very easy to drink.

Pours dark copper with no head. Aroma is deep ripe berries, nice brett, sweet cherries, sour berries, currants, vinous, a little lacto acid, fresh vanilla, nice barrel, a little bit of fruity tobacco and some apples. Taste is nice ripe fruits, sour currants, dry wood, dark oak, brown aleish notes behind, apples, a bit of vanilla here too, pretty tart in general, nice brett and a bit of lacto acid. Pretty dang nice to enjoy outside on a sunny eve!

375 of awesomeness. Pours a reddish brown, only slightly hazed. 1 finger head that doesnt stay long. Aromas of red wine and oak and so much more. Taste is tart with the oak and red wine notes, slight vinegar aroma. Overall another very tasty sour one of the best Ive had.

Pour is brown in color,clean and clear. Aroma is sour and fruity. This beer is very sour but the like a sour candy you cant put down. You can taste the cab flavor if you now what you are looking for.

From the bottle. I get woody notes from the oak with some sour/dried fruit character on the nose

Good levels of sourness with some dried fruit on the finish.

Well rounded overall.

31st August 2009Tasting at Mes and Sims flat. Batch 2. Very dark brown beer, hazy. Dry palate. Sour and rich. Sour coca cola and currants. The dark fruit providing a reasonable counter balance to the lemony sourness.

Sampled from bottle. Poured a slightly cloudy brown color with an off-white head. Aroma was dark, dried fruits with a tart kick to it. Flavor is tart, slight puckering sour. Wine notes, grape crispness. Carbonated pretty well so a bit of a fuzzy note to it. Good.

Snifter at brewpub. Real good.aroma. tart, Fruity. Cherry, raspberry, vinegar. Dark brownish orange.small head. No lace. Tart flavor. Lite body, smooth mouthfeel, tart dry finish. Darn tasty. Wonderful Fruity tart beer. I could go on, but why, you already know about it if youre reading this.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Una delle migliori birre che io abbia mai bevuto, Russian River è sempre una certezza!

#1468 bottle; nose is red grape, menthol, brettanomyces, some leaves, rosehip, weak wet grass, grapes, feel is mediumwatery, carb is medium, taste is peach, dry red grape, some brettanomyces, then soap, finish is quite mellow hops

Bottle, thanks Julie! Pours deep ruby, no head. Aroma: Oak, vinous, vanilla, brett, red berries, dusty, stable, grape peel, gooseberries, currants, cherries, greean apples, acidic notes, fruity. Taste: Acidic, tart, lemon, red berries, brett, vinous, oak, strawberry, gooseberries, very refreshing  and elegant.

Pours a slightly hazy amber/brown with minimal head that quickly goes to a ring.  Smell is tart dark fruit, red wine grapes.  Taste is tannin like acidity, red wine definitely popping out, some cherry, very sour, and some of the oak.  Not as tart as Supplication but smoother.  This really nice.
This beer is sooooo good! I will not even try to describe it. I am not worthy! Perfection! So dang expensive!!!!!!

Bottled from Bierkoning, Amsterdam, batch 007. Hazy orange-brown colored, very small dying head. Very strong nose, sour, lambic-like, fruity, some smoke, wine, some wood, very complex. Acidic and alcoholic flavor, thin mouthfeel, finishes mainly alcoholic. Very promising nose, but in flavor complexity and especially balance is nowhere to be found. An interesting experiment, but it doesnt really work out very well.
Amber with an off white head - a sour aroma with some hints of some berries - sour taste that lasts for a long time with some berries and malts - nice and refreshing sour

Very interesting beer. Slightly floral aroma. Very sharp, very sour - just like my ex-wife! No head, Hmmm....Definitely like my ex wife! No lace either. Not the beer you are going to drink all night long, but awesome to taste. I'm a lucky guy... Well, apart from the ex-wife who took my house and drank all my beer :-)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: APR 23, 2012 Dark brown colour, no head. Sour fruity aroma. Flavour is sour, oak, malty.

Bottle thanks to Dave! Smells intense, vomit/bile... I know not appealing at all but I have heard great things so I am going to drink this. Really sour, I get the wine barrel and wine, oak, funk maybe cherry? Taste is far better than the nose. This is great.

Purchased in San Francisco at Blackwells Beer Store. Duvel Tulip served at cellar temp. Batch 007.

A - 1-Finger big and tiny bubble head dissipated quickly and very very fast. Beer is an SRM of 5. Dark brown and very hazey.

S - Sour, tart but not as much as Temptation. Very nice on the nose but nothing too impressive. Subdued almost watered down or oxidized red wine smell.

T - Wow. Intensely acid like with lots of sour. Loving the carbernet notes which are very subdued and the black curants. Its a very tasty beer very similar to Hanssens Experimental Cassis. 

M - 50/50 carbonation, dry finish, lingering tartness.

O - its good. B+ but nothing remarkable.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2014 Bottle, batch "004X1". Big thanks to beace for sharing this with me. Nice, thin off-white khaki head. Cool, mildly hazy maroon body. Little lace that doesnt stick - it slowly slides back into the body. Very tart and very sour taste, with a light acidic bite in the finish. Very light carbonation. Kind of fruity red wine aroma under the sourness. Sour tart aftertaste persists long through the aftertaste. Interesting... But I dont love it. Probably better enjoyed by hardcore fans of sour ales (at the moment.. I can only say that I merely dabble) 6/4/7/4/14 Re-rate, 12.7oz bottle 7/9/14: Thanks to DanielCoor for sharing. Bottled 11/22/13. First time I had this, it was one of my very first sours ever. I had no frame of reference. Worth a re-rate. Pours a hazy brick red color. Thin khaki head. Couple loose dots of lace. Fantastic bigger puckering sour aroma. Light spiciness. Hides ABV well. Medium to bigger body. Good, kind of chewier more full feel to it. Light dry finish. Wonderful vinous, oak, spice, grape and currant flavors on this. Delicious sour to sip on. Now, I get it.

Bottle. Pours translucent reddish brown with minimal head and no lacing. The aroma is full of sour cherry with some grape notes. The taste is very sour and full of sour cherries and oak. Some wine notes. The finish is Semi dry and alcohol free. Amazing.
Red copper colour. No head to speak of. Refreshing sourness. Currants. Rich caramelly flavours. Mellow texture. Very nice.
Bottle at RBNAG-11. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is sour, smoked, berries. Flavour is sour, smoked, berries, chocolate, vinegar, oak, vanilla. Nice beer.

Sours i love and this one was wonderful. Sour fruit aroma. sourish and balanced with a full-body bitterness with a clean finish. I really liked this one.
My fav out of the russian rivers.

Vinuous deep brown with no real head and low carbonation. Brett all over the nose with some oaky notes. Medium bodied and extremely tart. The red currant flavors are pervasive and the mouthfeel is gorgeous. Long, complex finish.

OK I have tried all the specialty "sours" at RR now and I guess I am not a fan, the aroma is very nice but it is more like a wine than beer, pours with no head at all, taste is very sour, mild carbonation time to get back to my Damnation 23...

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2014 Batch 3. Bottle at RBWG 2012. Pours a cloudy brown with no head. The aroma is oak and vanilla malt. Thin mouthfeel with a sour cherry and dark fruit with nice sour finish. Easy to drink, a very impressive sour ale from Russian River. Really enjoyed this one.

Batch 1 bottle thanks to Tom. Pours a cloudy copper with paperthin white had that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is oak, cab, and tobacco. Thin mouthfeel with strong oak, cab, with very sour finish. Very good

Pours a murky brown/red color with minimal head.  Aroma is very nice with currants, cherries, leather, earthy, wet leaves, vanilla.  Taste is moderately tart and lightly sweet with dominant currants.  Overall quite nice but no supplication.
picked up for me by my brotha from anotha motha C-TIP. jesus this is a complex sexy sour. Tart berry flavors and some oakyiness. Very nice russian river. Very nice!
