Deep ruby color with a nose of sour cherries and funk. Taste is beautifully sour up front with a hint of the wine and oak to temper the sour on the finish. Very smooth mouthfeel and palate. Great brew.

Another good one from Russian River. Tart, vinous fruit up front balanced (for a sour ale) with malt and a bitter finish. Strong barnyard/funk with a hint of wood. Something of a halfway point between RRs more sour brews and a reglar ale.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2017 Fresh sour-cherry and winey woody aroma.  Pours amber-brown in color.  Tart-sour flavor dominates (cherry) with a wood dry character and with a more typical ale malt finish.

Notes:  First at GABF 09 then at the brew pub (June 17)

26/03/2011 Brasserie 4:20 (tap). Birra speciale offerta da Alex in occasione della cotta pubblica di marzo 2011. Ambrata intensa, con riflessi rossicci, abbastanza limpida. Aroma intenso, lieviti selvatici, note fruttate (frutti di bosco), vinose, legnose, nettamente percepibili. In bocca è di una intensità straordinaria, lacidità è contenuta, si percepiscono note di frutta rossa, sensazioni vinose, buona secchezza e freschezza in bocca nonostante la gradazione alcolica elevata. Corpo medio, carbonazione soft. Sour ale eccezionale, complessa e impegnativa. Bevuta memorabile.

Sours are not my specialty - but this one was worth the investment.  A pretty brown-plumish color, little head retention, with a neat sour fruit aroma.  Nice even mouthfeel and sour, but balanced with a full-body bitterness and clean finish.  Very interesting and, Ill admit, its making a believer out of me :-)

Pours somewhere between amber and mahogany, with hints of orange, and with a fast fizzling head. Smells sour, fruity, and of white wine with a touch of oak. Taste is initially sour and then moves to fruity sweetness. Medium-to-full bodied with an astringent texture and prickly mouth-carbonation, Russian River Consecration finishes with a soft lingering sweet-sourness.

Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Clear reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, yeasty, dried fruit, brett and alcohol. Flavor is quite sweet and rather acidic. Quite dry and rather acidic finish with warming alcohol. 270112
Ruby red. It smelled of sour cherries, oak and funk. It tasted like dried currants, sour pucker, oak, wood and cabernet. Very wine like and tasty.

Tap at RR. It pours deep red-amber, with off-white head. The nose is tart red fruit, lemon, farmyard and TCP. The taste is tart cherry, strawberry, lemon-lime, wood, jam, red grape, vinous, touch of herb and some alcohol warmth in the finish. Medium body, light carbonation and moderate tartness. Smooth, well balanced and well hidden alcohol. Great stuff.

Bottle to tulip. Smells good; like a strong ale should. Tastes Fantastic! I LOVE the Cabernet influence! Does wonders for the flavor. Complex, but not in a " I taste plums, cherries, and earthiness, etc." kind of way like youd get from wine snobs. Just. Good. Beer. Mouthfeel is great; what looks to be relatively low-carbonated is actually deceptively carbonated, just as a sour should be. Overall, a great beer that Ill definitely be seeking out again!

375 ml bottle. Batch #7. Brewed on 31.08.2010 Bottled on 21.10.2011
Pours clear copper color with minimal head. Aroma of sour fruits, cherries, wood, vanilla notes, herbs and nettle. Flavor of sour cherries, wood, fruits, grass notes and rose hip. Very good brew.
3456

375ml bottle from City Beer, San Francisco, CA
Batch 007, brewed on 8/31/2010, bottled on 10/21/2011 - Pours dark brownish red with small bubbly white head. Aroma of sour berries, currants, spices and malts. Taste of tart berries, sour currant, spices, oak and woody notes. Finish is malty with notes of red wine, tart berries, sourness and dark fruits. Well balanced, tasty sour ale with red wine notes.

375 ml bottle. Batch 007, brewed on 31.08.2010, bottled on 21.10.2011.
Pours a deep amber colour without a head. Aroma of sour berries, oak, honey and of course Cabernet Sauvignon. Flavour of really sour berries such as blackcurrant, oak, light spices, Cabernet Sauvignon grapes and surprisingly strong tannin notes. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and a long, dry and really sour finish. Cabernet Sauvignon makes this a bit more stuffy than the Pinot Noir on Supplication, but this is still an awesome beer.

37,5 cl bottle @ home. Batch #007: brewed 31.08.2010, bottled 21.10.2011
Aroma is stale and sour with leather and earthy notes. Also hints of tart cherries. Flavour is sour and somewhat tart with oaky notes and blackcurrants. Sour, red wine -like and nice. Slightly worse than Supplication, a bit too much red wine here.
Dark ruby color with minimal head. Smell is of light sour note of currant. Taste is clean, sour,  with nice full oak flavor that balances well to the finish leaving a great aftertaste.

Poured into a Russian River stemmed glass, with no head and little carbonation with very small bubbles. Deep mahogany with a red tint, somewhat clear, which was suprising. Smells of oak, funk, alcohol, and a little vinegar. Tastes acidic and sour thoughout, with a mouth-puckering finish. I get a tingling sensation on my lips when I drink this beer, its amazing. This is a great sour and if your looking for that hit-you-in-the-mouth sourness, this one is for you.

This is my favorite beer. Great sour note with and oak and cabernet finish. If you have not tried a sour, this is a great place to start and never look back. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From notes.  First reviewed 2/22/2011.  Poured from a 375 mL bottle into a pint glass.

Consecration pours a dark brown color with a hint of ruby at the edges. No carbonation apparent from no head - uh oh. 

Black currants, vinegar, with a nice oak barrel character create an acetic aspect to the nose. An obvious tart character accompanies a light raisin aroma. 

The flavor is dominated by sweet balsamic vinegar, black currants, and a rich oaky bite . Some dark fruit flavor complement. The finish is quite tart. 

For a sour, this is full bodied. Tart and puckering, with a little bit of residue on the tongue. Pretty flat, maybe I got a leaky bottle?

This is a beer I definitely enjoy, and a change of pace from my normal hoppy beer. Sour and enjoyable.

750 ml bottle @ RBNAG-11. Murky brown body with a small off-white head. Aroma has acidic fruitiness, caramel malt, oak and alcohol. Flavor is fruit and berries, both acidic and sweet, mild chocolate and wood. Fine body and rich in aftertaste, acidic. Very nice.

Ill keep this simple, because my notes are stupid. They just say "give it a 4."

Tart, cherry, surprisingly smooth. Quite good.

Bottle @ Too many Geuzes - only one toilet , Ulfborg 2012 - Day 1.  Dark reddish brown color with beige head. Moderatly sour aroma, oak, raisins, vinous, vanilla, currants. Taste is very sour, ripe fruit, currants,vanilla, caramel, malt. Nice.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2012 Pours a very dark ruby, almost cola colored. Bit of alcohol legs. Almost no head. Smell is very cherry, little bit like unsweetened kool-aid. Very strong smell. Taste is crisp and tart, lots of cherry up front. Oaky and almost smokey flavor. Medium bodied. Delicious sour, probably my favorite out of Russian River.

Poured from 375ml bottle. Batch 7. Pours with no head and appears fizzy brown/red in the glass. Might think it is a Dr. pepper if you didnt come within 10 feet of smelling it. Vinious aroma with a touch of funk and candied fruit. Flavor is quite tart and quite good off the start. Unlike many other sours, the tartness hangs around all the way through the long finish.  Would never guess this is 10%.
Strong chardonnay aroma with tart and other complexities mixed in. Cant even tell it s 10% ABV

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2013 Amazing sour beer that Ive had many times on tap at Russian River brewery, very dark with lots of cherries, super tart, beautiful dark color, love it! One of the best sours ever.
This is one of my top 5 favorites ever. Definitely got that sour cherry sort of taste going on and raises the bar for the sour/wild ale category. Unfortunatly they are hard to come by in most places.

38cl, Batch 7, exclusive American brew, with black currants, thx to Secret Santa!, complex sour fruit brew, sour/vinous and slightly alcoholic/woody, not too heavy, balanced, hazy, nearly no head, very good brew, yet very expensive!
Taste is complex with so many different nuances. Vinegar, oak, wine, alcohol and fruit all make an appearance at one time or another.

Bottle @ FOneFan. Dark amber/brown with small beige head. Aroma is malt, yeast, sour, little caramel, oak and a little dark fruits. Flavour is malt, vinous, dark fruits, medium sweet, vinegar, caramel and oak.
Perfect heavy Sour ale very good balance. Very drinkable .  Tasted on cask.

Sample at Central Waters anniversary party.  Deep brown with red highlights.  Dark fruit, cab, tart acidity, and wood in the aroma.  Flavor bursting with tart red wine, meaty dark fruit, currants, cherry/plum, and wood.  Lightly sweet.  Great residual mix of flavors.  Springy carbonation.  Excellent.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2017  Aroma:citrus grape Ud.: nøddebrun Skum: cremet mellem hold E.smag:sød lidt sur moderat  Krop: medium For.: vandede Brus: blød
  
27/1-12 @f1 
0gså tap rr
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head with medium duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are caramel, fruits, brett, nuts, wood and wine.

RBAG 2012. deep brown red color and a fizzy white head with nice carbonation pooling at the surface. aroma has vinous red wine sourness, oak, dark cherry, currant, and tons of delicious funk. crisp mouth feel with nice prickly carbonation at the side of the tongue. flavor has plenty of sourness, rich red wine character, dark berry, oak, currant, and tobacco.
Angenehm säuerlicher Beginn, die Fruchtigkeit wirkt aber gesüßt. Dieses Aroma könnte saurer sein. Angenehme Fruchtnoten, süffig, rund. Trocken säuerliches Finish, etwas harsch. /12/12/11/11/12
UPDATED: OCT 24, 2012 Had on tap at Russian river brewery. Great sour. Pours a dark color. Smells sour. And the taste is a tart sour finish
On tap at the brewery. Pours very light with a white head. Aroma is sour and so is the taste. has a bit of citrusy to finish but basically drinking a good sour.

Beautiful auburn color, mostly clear, not much head but theres some sparse lacing.   Very tart, funky and vinegary smelling, with overtones of cherries. Not much else is going on really, but it does smell wonderful!  Lovely tasting stuff. Very sour, with vinegary overtones, currants and cherries fill out the fruity flavors too, followed by a pungent sour brett funkiness.  Feel is pretty light and zesty, with high acidity and light carbonation, leaving a lingering sour cherry aftertaste. Not much alcohol taste for 10% ABV. Another great Russian River beer. If youre into wild ales, this is your friggin beer!!
Super Bowl XLV tasting.  Pours brown with red hues.  Muddled sour lemon nose.  Taste of sour fig newtons, chocolate an raisins.  Yummy.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2012 Pours a murky light brown, with a disappearing head. Aroma seems typical sour ale; what do I know about sour ale aroma, though. Taste sour, of course, with notes of wine and berries. Finishes a bit on the dry side, but overall I enjoy this a lot.

Bottle. Pours a dark ruby red color with no head. Aroma is of black and red currants, cherry notes, balanced sourness, oak, subtle funk of leather and barnyard. The flavor follows the nose with lots of black and red currants, sourness, vinous notes, red grape, apple vinegar, balsamic vinegar, caramel, brown sugar and subtle funk of barnyard and dusty old flavors too. The body is medium with a dry mouthfeel. Overall a pretty tasty American Sour!

Bottle served in a tulip. Clear, dark amber-brown with a short head. Short retention and zero lacing. Bright nose of currant, wine, and lighy oak. Terrific flavor. Approachable versus being a sour bomb. Still has excellent acidity and fruit on the palate. Medium body, oily-thin texture, soft carbonation, and a long fruity, acidic finish. Delicious!

courtesy of watson1977. 375ml bottle batch 004x4. pours a cloudy rusty red, no head. aroma of sour fruit, wood and red wine. flavor is full of fruit with hints of wood, creamy and delightfully sour. the currants shine through and give this one an awesome flavor! the 10% abv is masked well. a great sour ale!

Bottled. Brownish red, slightly cloudy beer with a thin head. Complex aroma, sour cherries, currants, gooseberries and some sweeter raisins/sherry notes. Delicate, woody vanilla touch. Sour, graperuity flavor, tight and leathery brett finish with nice tannins. Interesting dark woody//tobacco notes in the late finish. Almost flat texture, medium body. Really interesting beer.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 A - pours  deep reddish brown with soft white head

S  - earthy oaky notes currents cotton candy  dark cherries berries. 

Mf- med heavy body low carb. 

T - earthy oaky cab currents nose, sour and oakiness throughout, lingering sweet currents and cherry very subtle peachiness and sweet pea (?) front of the mouth .  Subtle limes, light leather end.

O - overall great beer, It is a wonderfull oak aged  mellow sour oaky cab with current berry and cherry notes.  fantastic sour ale

8+

Shared bottle @RBNAG-11.  Shiny, deep red colored body. Small blond top.  Vinous, acidulous berry aroma. Faint smoke and ashy malts. Taste is acidic berry-fruity with notes of vinegar and cider-apples. Hint of wood and ash, and a noticable sweetness underneath. Medium to full body. Alcohol warmth in a vinous, sour-acidic finish.

Bouteille de 375ml, bouchon de liège. Un gros merci à Patrick de mavoir fait découvrir cette bière. Le liquide est brun, elle ne faisait pas de mousse. Le nez est bien agréable, des arômes de chinotto se propage vers les narines. La bouche est acide, vineuse, le boisé est bien intégré, elle est très équilibrée, un caramel est perceptible. Lalcool se fait discret et cest tant mieux. Elle a aussi une belle texture en bouche. Un classique. (005X2E)

(rating #1000, batch 005X2E, thanks to ontbeermaker for this world class beer)  Une mousse évanescente sur un liquide à la robe brune acajou.  Un nez spectaculaire construit autour de fruits surets et de parfums boisés avec des arômes de vin aigre piqués par une sublime rusticité.  Une leçon de complexité et déquilibre.  Des saveurs incroyables de petits fruits surets et de notes boisées riches avec une petite touche de douceur qui émerge dans ce grand et beau fracas.  Une bouche qui est plaisante, au corps moyen et à leffervescence maîtrisée avec une texture huileuse.  Une finale intense et jouissive, un amalgame de notes surettes et aigres qui rappellent que parfois, dans le doux bouillonnement dun liquide, on peut entendre le cri du Sublime.

Bottle to tulip. Aroma has funk, sweetness and sourness to it. The pour has a red/brown color with a small white head. This beer is extremely sour. 

This beer is by far the best wild/sour Ive had. Similar to Surly five. Love the wine barrel aging. This is no exception.

35cl bottle courtesy of Brian nyc.
Thin white head. Hazy amber pour. Sour aftertaste
750 ml. Bottle.  Brownish color with a red hue.  Great sourness complexity.  Wine barrels do this beer wonders.  Wonderful.

Bottle 37,5 cl, trade. Pours clear ruby mahogany with a shortlived beige head, looks very nice. Aroma is fruity, acidy, sour, tart, tobacco and a bit sweet. Very nice. Flavor is refreshing; fruity, acidy, sour, phenolic, lemon juice, berry and slightly dry. Finishes tart, sour and berry.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2012 Bottles from multiple sources and on tap at the brewpub.  This is by far the sourest (?) beer Ive had, but what an excellent palate for that deep, rich pucker.  Dark fruits, cherries, and rich zinfandel-type flavor meet Warheads/Sour Patch Kids.  I absolutely love this beer...really the best with a BBQed ribeye steak, medium-rare with horseradish.
15.10.2011. 0,75l Bottle. Dark brown colour with a thin layered off-white head. Farm house aromas and very sour. Very refreshing with notes of red berries or fruit. Flavours of oak or red wine?.

Poured from bottle, purchased at Russian River Brewery in September 2011.

Aroma: Sweet and funky sour, with a hint of barnyard.  Fantastic.
Appearance: Crystal clear deep mahogany.  No lingering head.
Taste: Starts off with a nice dark fruit sweetness followed by an inrush of sourness.  Assertive, but not puckering.  Sourness lingers until subtle hop bitterness and dark fruit finish it out.
Palate: Lively carbonation, nice mouthfeel.
Overall: A phenomenal beer.  Nothing more needs to be said.

Bottle.  A very cloudy reddish brown beer with a thin white head.  Sweet and sour aroma of alcohol, berries, and wood.  Taste is mild sweet, very sour; quite fruity.  The alcohol makes its presence felt.  Very dry finish.

Sharing with sour beer fan friends Mike n Bryce (homebrewers). Poured with no head or lace. Color is a hazy/cloudy honey amber. Aroma is yeast, sour, oak, sherry, malt. Flavors similar to taste but not as complex. Body and carbonation are perfect for style. Finish is like flavor, clean, balanced, and a nice alcohol prod. Very nice.

I poured a 375ml caged and corked bottle into a tulip glass.

Appearance: Beautiful shade of hazy ruby red/mahogany. Forms a tiny head which fizzles away like a soda. 

Smell: Distinct sour red grape with a lot of vinous overtones. Strong vanilla/wood aroma imparts rustic earthiness.

Taste: You know a beer is going to be great when, upon your first sip, you cant think straight afterwards because youve just experienced so many different flavors at once! Thats what happened to me just a few seconds into Russian River Consecration. Wow! Where to begin? Its like a Belgian quad thats been soured and wood-aged with some roasted malts added and gone flat. Ill break it down:

It begins with immediate sourness - the tasty kind you find in beers like this brewed with wild ales. Next comes dark, tart, acidic fruits like cherry, black cherry, currants, blackberries, and sour red grapes. Its similar to sangria, but with an overt sourness to it. After all that comes the barrel-aged portion with strong vanilla and wood flavors - akin to a clean rum. I even detect a brief, subtle flavor of chocolate or dark roasted malts, although I doubt theres any used in the brewing of the beer. It comes full circle back to the sourness, only stronger and drier, with a surprisingly clean aftertaste. Its delicious and I want more!

Mouthfeel: Thin, tepid, slight warming sensation and accompanying taste of alcohol. 

Drinkability: Russian River Consecration is an expensive beer, which is a shame because its so easy to drink and such a delight for the palate that you wish one bottle didnt cost the same as a 12-pack of most supermarket beers. The palate is strong as hell, no denying it, but the drinking process is amazingly easy. It goes down like water, and its even refreshing for a moment with no cloying after effects. An amazing beer on so many levels.

Dark red pour with minimal head and lacing. Aroma of blood orange, Ribena, oak and red wine. Cherries, currants and deep bourbon-soaked wood up front, a light lactic tartness, and a sharp lemon/vinegar sourness. Finish is salty and boozy - like the rim of a margarita glass, but for a welcome late touch of malt. Light to medium body. Complex, if not all that subtle. Extra points for outright uniqueness.
Strong sour flavour with a lingering finish.  Very unique mouthfeel.  Overall good beer.

Bottle, many thanks mom and dad, very quickly dissapearing small head, complex medlay of colours: hazy very dark orange, on top of it some reddish notes and lots of brown taints finishing, aroma of red wine vinegar, spice, wood, berries, citrus,  a noticeable brett character and maybe a hint of metal in the back, flavour of wood and vanila from the oak barrels, red fruits, apple vinegar and some very light oxidised notes, suprisingly light bodied for the alcohol level, quite a lot of tannins which need to mellow ,meaning this brew can probably can still age for a considerable time. Integrated and balanced, highly enjoyable.

Pours a clear and brown beer with no head. The aroma is redwine, vinegar, malt, tart and some acidity. The flavor follows the nose with additional notes of cherries and acidity. The palate is fresh and acidic. Overall a good beer. [Rating #2500]

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2013 Draught @ Russian River Brewing, Santa Rosa, CA
Pours dark amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, raisin, caramel, dried fruits, red wine, tart and brett. Taste is light sweet and medium sour with a long dry, fruity and sour finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.
Bottle 750ml @ RBNAG-11
Pours cloudy brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of vinegar, oak, vanilla and coconut. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter and medium sour. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle, RBNAG 11.
Deep, rich, vinous. The currants are more felt than tasted. Sour finish, some vinegar.

Shared bottle at the RBNAG-11 grand tasting. Clear mahogany with no head. Dark caramel, spices and pickled dark fruits on the nose. Acidic, bitter, vinegary flavors. Astringent. Grows slightly in the mouth and is noticable in the throat.

0.75l bottle @ RBNAG11. Pours a dark red-brown body with a small fading sidesticking off-white head. Aroma is vinious, some dark old fermented berries, tobacco, smoke, strawberries and wood. Quite nice stuff. Average to lively oily. Nice and sour flavors, lots of wood and oak, red-currants, nuts and it has a heart warming aftertaste. Nice stuff!
Bottle.  Batch 004X5.  Pours clear mahogany with a thin white head.  Aroma of tart cherries, spices and wood.  Taste is cherries, dark fruit and a bit of caramel.  Dry and tart.  Amazing.

Reddish brown colour, no head. Aroma quite sour, fruity, oak, brett, some sour apples. Flavour tart, lots of sour apple, quite spicy, brett tones. Bit one dimensional. Finish tart and fruity.
(From 75cL bottle @ DRBM 2011. Courtesy of Jos. Batch 001x1)
caramel, chocolate, cheese, red, brown, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, heavily sour, umami, full body, thick feel, lively,
Shared bottle, RBNAG 2011. Barrel aged 6 months, with currants added. Reddish brown colour. Intense farmhouse aroma, sour fruit, oak and spices. Sour flavour, good but not impressive.

Pours a dark, hazy, copper-brown with little to no head. Aroma strongly reminiscent of a glass of wine. Flavors are very complex. The wine flavor is there, along with a woody note. Very sour finish to the beer. Fairly heavy carbonation. I dont know that sour ales are really my thing, though this is an interesting beer to sip and savor.

Bottle. Pour is hazy ruby/brown with a small off-white head. Poor retention/some lace. Aroma is vinous, barnyard, dust, dark fruit (figs, currants), barrel. Taste is sour, oak, lots of dark fruit, dry finish. Palte is soft, lightly bitter, oily texture, long sour finish. Really nice.

Pours cloudy, light brown, little to no head. Cedar, currants, Brett on the nose. Vanilla, leather, cedar, quite tart, tons of sourness/bitterness on the finish. bubbly and effervescent. unbelievably dry, yet balanced. near perfection and a great sour.

12-oz bottle courtesy of James shared with James and Streets. Drank from snifter. Pours deep, dark red with small off-white head that disappears rapidly. Aroma is red fruits and tartness; palate is more of the same with a more pronounced sour quality. Strawberry, cherry and red wine. Light body; light, smooth finish and short legs. Quintessential sour. Awesome.

Shared bottle at RBNAG-11. Pours dark mahoganey with a small off-white head. Aroma is funky dark berries. Taste is more ho bitterness oriented, not as sour as suggested by the aroma, but still enough funky sourness to rock my chair.

Bottle @ drbm. Slight hazy brown color, short head. Aroma is slight tart, fruity, hint of oak, reasonable malty backbone, bit nutty even. Sourish taste, very complex, fruity, slight hint of alcohol. All the ingredients have their own place, blend very nice and make up for a perfect sipper. Wonderful sour.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ deep amber with an off-white head. Aroma of wood,oak,black currant, funk, sourness and funk. Flavor is sweet and sour with some dark red berries, currants, oak and funk.medium body, average carbonation.Really nice funky beer.

Bottle, first batch @ drbm. Aroma is smooth fruity brett, green apple, some barn.
Flavour is deep green apple, brett, barn, spice and more.

GABF 2011.  Murky reddish brown, fading head. Aroma initially of sour cherries, oak, and rusty earthy toffee. Delightful sour taste of tart cherries, oak, a bit of light red wine, some tart yeast sourness, a bit of earthy robust maltiness. Pretty swell!

750mL corked bottle poured a reddish color with big white head which settled quickly to a few spots of lace.  Aroma is dark fruit with some wood and roasted malts.  Taste is malty sweetness with fruit and wood and a mild hoppy finish.  Decently balanced brew with nice carbonation, a medium body and fairly tasty.  Recommended for a tasting experience.

Deep ruby red colored pour. Large, light tan, head that fades as soon as Im done pouring it. No lacing. Very acetic aroma with a dried cherry aroma. A slight bourbon scent with hints of alcohol. Leather and pepper as well. Very tart and acetic taste. With a twangy currant presence. A bit dry and some sweetness mixed in to balance. A pleasant woody earthiness, with a bitter dry back. Very good.
Thanks to dedollewaitor. Blind tasted. Pours copper with a small beige head. Aroma is caramel, vinegar and fruit. Flavour is caramel, acidic, sour cherries, vinegar and leather notes.

Mazel tov! It couldnt wait to escape when I removed the cork. Amber and burgundy tones with a small tan head. Definite cabernet aromas with bright citrus aspects. The flavor is the same. Sour ale deliciousness!
Bottle from craft beer outlet. Dark red with sour, cherries aroma.  Tastes of sourness, cherries. Another excellent Russian river selection.
On tap at the brewery:  vinegar cherry aroma.  grape wine.  sour throughout.  berry, vanilla.  rich texture.  long tart finish.  great.

Rating this on tap now, but I know I have a bottle rating somewhere in my notes. Dark, reddish oak pour with plenty of tart fruity notes, currants, raspberries and cherries. Really lovely lactic acidity with a lip-lingering tart touch of acetic and some woody oak. Earthen spice and mild mossiness with a touch of green pepper dryness and funky afterthoughts on the tongue. Delicious.

The beer had a reddish brown color in the glass with a very small head. Aroma was definitely a wine feel. Currants, wild berries along with some oak were pretty heavy. This was my first sour beer so the taste caught me off-guard. I like dry red wine but the tartness was surprising. As the beer warmed up it improved slightly but not enough for me to buy it again.

Bottle. Big thanks to my friend Greg for getting me a bottle during my trip to California. Pours a translucent purplish-red. Off-white head dissipates quickly leaving no lacing.

Smells divine. Grapes, acetic, oak, vinuous, alcohol. Tastes even more vinuous than it smells. prefect amount of sourness. Body is lacking and strong alcohol flavor is a bit off-putting. Still a solid beer.

Its strange how my first reaction was that it is pretty good, then I turned and thought it was great towards the middle. But now that I am taking my last sips, Im back to thinking its just pretty good.

The beer pours a beautiful dark brown. The bite is unexpected. The taste does not lead you to think the beer is 10%. The wood does not taste hot, there is no alcohol behind the wood, but rather flavor of sweetness from the currents with a kick of sour. Great beer. Thanks Fred at Beverages 4 Less.

This beer is thanks to Fred over at Beverages 4 Less in Santee, CA. Fred is the best. The beer might be better thought, no offense Fred. :) The beer is a dark brown with a hint of red burnt into the color. The aroma is nice but doesnt do the beer justice. Perhaps this is because the beer was a little too cold. However, the smell doesnt seem to possibly indicate the wonderful flavor the beer has. The sour is obvious, with a nice funk and strong bite. However, the currants seem to really balance the beer in a nice way. The beer tastes dark with a champaign bubbly mouth feel sweet and sour flavor that really is great! Nice job Russian River! (as if that wasnt expected)








t7r2

Dark clear mahogany pour biege head some cherries dried fruit lots of sour notes apples oak influence there is good carbonation of medium strength flavours sour apples currants wine influence cherries caramel cinnamon a dryness very morishing acidic sharpness note of chocolate great on the palate at thefinish some sweetness as well as strong sourness fruity tastes dark malts funky wild stuff a cracking aroma
one of those beers you could just sip all night. cherries and currants well balance with the sour. awesome beer. my favourite sour (thus far)

Pours brown, amber when backlit, coarse tan head, but it disappears in seconds.  Sounds like snap, crackle, pop despite the placid surface.  Aroma is sweet caramel, some lactic acid, and then hints of the darker fruits (currants) and maybe a subtle influence from the wine casks (I think these two things contribute to the color.)  The wine comes out in the flavor, bits of currant, lots of sour, lactic with a bit of acetic/harshness.  Very light on the caramel- pretty dry and clean really.  The lactic lingers and puckers for a good 5 seconds.  Light/Medium bodied.  It definitely grew on me as I drank.  All of the mastery of Rodenbach Grand Cru with added complexity from the wine/currants which mainly presents itself in the aroma.

Draft at the brewery/restaurant.  Nice purple color.  Aroma of dark berries.  Tastes like a carbonated cabernet.  Nice carbonation.  An excellent beer.  I will drink this beer any time I see it on tap.

Poured from a bottle, batch 4. Pours a deep crimson, some head at first, dissapates quickly, however. Very sour flavor, with some good taste from the currants. No hint at all of the 10% abv. Great sour!
Bottle in tulip glass. Aroma of red wine and damp wood. Dark brown colour. Taste is sour, obviously, grass, tart cranberry. I havent had a lot of sour ales, but I enjoyed this one.

This ale came as quite a pleasant surprise. It was not labeled as a sour, but it is one of the best sours that I have had. It poured a beautiful burgundy. with a small off white head. The aroma was beautifully fresh and reminiscent 
of a fine wine. The mouth feel was effervescent and lively.The taste was a  beautiful balance of malt and hop with a sour wild yeast flavor, combined with the Cabernet background that made this a very pleasing ale. Good show!

750 ml bottle, batch#1 thanks to ericandersnavy. Pours dark brown with fast fading tan head. Aroma is very tart, aged oak, cab, very subtle brown sugar. Flavor is much the same with notes of must, farmhouse, cherry, very tart and sour.....acidic. Mouthfeel is light-medium with medium carbonation. Overall, holy shit! This is sooo damn sour and tasty! Damn good stuff!

Batch 006 shared with FunkyBrewster.  Pours with a thin white head and a raisin hues.  Minimal lace.  Nose is notable for a tangy grape and hint of oak.  On the tongue, this beer is lively and smooth with a medium body.  A pleasant sweet citrus moves into a potent wine vinegar tang to finish with blueberry and lime notes.  Great stuff.

Bottle batch 006, shared with Dioinysian_Son. Pours a deep mahogany with a small of white froth. Aroma of tart cherry and plenty of funk, dark fruits, the currant is nice with a noticeable earthy barnyard note, the wood is very nice in there. Flavor starts sweet, overripe fruit, currant, some tart cherry, raisin, prune, getting an aggressive funk, the brett and earthy woodiness really giving it a fullness. Finishes tart and aggressive, lingering with a touch of cidery vinegar like funk. Medium body and a crisp carbonation. Excellent beer

Served on-tap into a mini pint at TJs 7th Anny. Party. Number one of three in my Russian River flight. An amazing party with amazing beers.

A - Pours deep amber with a thin film of white head that leaves minimal lacing down the glass.

S - Strong tartness up front, strongest of the three. Hints of spices, berries, and oak. Aromas dont linger for long but they leave a lasting impression.

T - Not the first time I have had this one. Starts with a bit of spice from the currents quickly giving way to a blast of strong tartness. Finish is a lingering funk with a bright acidic note. I prefer the other two, supplication and temptation, but I still like this one a lot. Still one of my favorite wilds.

M - Medium body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Tart finish lingers but not for too long. It wears you down after a full glass.

D - Fairly high. I really like this one but when you put all three of these together you really see how different they really are. I would rank this one last out of the three but it is still so good that you can not go wrong. Glad I have a few bottle of this in the cellar.

Bottle courtesy adnielsen. Pours a clear yellowish orange color with very light carbonation. Aroma is certainly sour with woody notes and dark sour cherries. Oaky smell. Flavor is pretty sour and tart, with a woody flavor as well and a slight fruity sweetness. Dont get me wrong, this is certainly sour, but it has a little character to it. Ok!
Bottle from Cavie.  Light brown pour with a small white head.  Aroma is sour berries, vanilla, and wood.  Taste is funky, leather, berry, and some vanilla at the end.

Pours a dark deep brown with lots of red tones.  White head with little lacing. Aromas of citrus and cherries.  Taste is heavy sour and medium bitterness on the back end.  Palate is fizzy and lively, clean and refreshing.  Overall, I am becoming a fan of sour ales.  This one has a nice hint of sour cherry that complements the malts, and doesnt overpower.  Very nice.

Bottle, cannot recall which batch number. Pours a dark red with very little head. Aroma is boldly tart with some notes of the oak barrel. Also gives a slight vanilla flavor. Taste is very tart but full. Very hard to believe this is all of 10%.  I would say it is comprable to Supplication, but with more body to the beer. Finishes with a perfect blend of vinegar and sweetness. Awesome sour.

On tap at the brew pub, served in a tasting glass. Pours clear caramel with a moderate tan head. The head fades slowly, leaving a small amount of lace. The nose has huge notes of cabernet sauvignon, oak, sour fruit and hints of tobacco and chocolate. The flavour is intensely sour throughout, with a light acidity that increases somewhat as it progresses. There are sour fruity notes throughout, cab sauv, and oak. The finish is long, sour and acidic. On the palate, it is medium in body with a watery texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a nice, complex sour ale with cabernet sauvignon and oak barrels. It is subtle and complex, with subtle notes of tobacco and chocolate: definitely the best sour tasted today. 2011-06-09

Bottle.
Deep amber pour with very little head that disappeared quickly.  Aroma is vinous and slightly sweet with some oak and tartness.  Flavors of black berries, slightly sour and tannic.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2013 Re-rated after visit to RR Tap Room. My second favorite in the series after Supplication. Pours dark amber to brown with a small head. Aroma is redwine - dark berries, wood, earthy, with a touch of cherry and some bretta. Taste is very much cherry and very sour but still balanced and very drinkable. A bit of sweetness and vinegar and a long, lingering aftertaste. Mouthfeel is quite light and crisp with a medium level of carbonation. A great beer!

November 13, 2010 - Waterloo tasting with blankboy, jerc, mabel and tupalev.  750ml bottle, corked and caged - batch 002 x2.  Hazy (with floaties) deep copper with an average diminishing beige head (3+).  Smells great - sour with background caramel sweetness, some raisin and herbal bitterness, restrained alcohol for 10% with an emerging red wine/oak character (for some reason at this point in my voice memo I said "and then Ill bury the head separately").  Taste incredibly lemony, with green apple, alcohol, much less vinous, still oaky - this is an 8- where the aroma was a solid 8+ - a bit jagged, but still good, it could mellow some.  Light, almost frothy mouthfeel, solid carbonation and acidity, finishes dry but not as sour as I expected - pleasant, with a bit of a burnt oak linger.

Bottle @ Blindtasting, Odense, July 2011. Pours dark amber red with a small creamy off white head. Tart, oaky and fruity nose. A bit of vinegar and berries. Very sour and crisp flavor - acetone and horsemanuer. Boom!
Pours a dark, murky brown. Smells sour, woody, fruity undertones. Taste is super sour, tart, finishes with a lot of strong oak. Dominantly sour and finishes with a really nice dry, oak flavor.

Hazy chestnut with a small off-white head. Aroma of cherry, toffee, vinegar, nuts and funk. Dry and very tart sour cherry flavour, with funk, malt and caramel notes and a hint of alcohol. Extremely sour.

2011 375 bottle. Pours a copper color with an off-white head. Nice nose of funk and woodiness. Balanced sour flavors up front with a fruity sweetness. Finishes dry and mouth puckering with a hint of currants. Good amount of alcohol overall. This is a tasty wild ale. Nicely done..

Bottle ~ batch 006] Deep reddish brown hue, decent head formation. Intense red wine aroma, sour dark berries, wood, earthy spice. Sour fruitiness, dark sour cherries on the palate, some sugarry sweetness for balance, woody dryness. Quite a bit of citrus in the finish as well as a strong tart acidity. A bold beer for an American brewer and an overwhelming success.

Shared a bottle with Armed and some other friends.  Pours a reddish color with a thin head.  The oak barrels are noticeable, the beer itself is a little bit on the sour side.  This isnt my favorite variety of beer, so my rating is probably below average.  I will give this one a second try but I was underwhelmed the first time around.

375ml bottle at Toronado in San Diego-pours currant red dark crimson hue with basically no head.  nose of currants, cherries, vineous notes, lite vinegar, and toasted wood-wonderful!  Vineous vanilla and cherry flavors with a bit of port and dark fruits (plums)-lovely but short finish when cold.  Alcohol becomes somewhat apparent, but not overly out of place and mostly covered by the woody notes.  As it warmed, there was a long finish of tobacco that was really interesting-not in a smokey way, but more like if you were smelling the leaves or smelling a unlit cigarette.  Yet another winner from RR!

75cl bottle shared by oj83. This got me drunk! Its pretty dam drinkable for a 10% beer and would rival Westvleteren 12 for hiding the alcohol. Its a muddy brown/red beer thats smells of sweet currents but is balanced by a sour refreshing finish. Nearly reminds me of a sweeter Goudenband in profile. The flavour was currents and the typical American wild ale honey taste. Very little funk on the nose! Impressive beer considering the strength but Im not sure this would cellar well. However I could be wrong.

This one was a "good customer" treat from the GM of the Pourhouse in Westmont, NJ.  Russian River isnt sold in NJ but he a bottle from PA and opened it for a few of us to share.  Gorgeous ruby-garnet pour supporting a tall off-white head and liquid velcro lacing.  Aroma of tart cherries, barnyard yeast, biscuits and light malt.  Pleasantly sour and complex flavor with cherries, blackberries, tart apple, bourbon, earthy spices and a hint of molasses on top of a rich malty backbone.  Silky smooth mouthfeel and a sweet but crisp, long and inviting finish.  Wonderful brew.

Poured mahoghany brown, smells of cherry. Tastes sour immediately, but mellows over time. The carbonation washes away the sour. However, the sour mutes some of the fruitiness.  Can smell the wood after more examination. 4.0

Aroma: notes of fruits, yeasts, wild
Appearance: red, deep
Taste: medium sourness, alcool, moderate sweetness.
Palate: full body
Oveerall: 20720

375ml, batch 004x2. Poured into an over sized wine goblet. A - Pours a dark brown with red tint. Very clear and bubbly. No real head to speak of, but theres some nice action going on around the edges of the glass. S - Tons of currants, cherries, and oak. The finish is very musky and funky. T - Extremely sour. This is probably the most sour beer Ive ever had, even more so than the Belgian lambics and guezes Ive tried. Cherries and oak. The sourness masks a lot of the fruit flavors, but the brett funk is on full display. Delicious. O - This was a very good beer and Im glad I got to try this. Its not on par with the belgian sours, but this is a very impressive american wild. It was my first RRion beer and from what I read this is the bottom of the tier. Cant wait to try some of the other ones.
Batch 04x3. Interestingly sweet/sour with a slight tartness along with subtle fruit flavors.
On tap. Wooooow! It is a fabulous exemplar! I am very lucky to be one of the few persons who had the pleasure to taste it.

Reviewing from Notes. This whale , for me at least, was shared with me by a generous friend and new to trading techster82. It was his first sour and first beer trade.

A nice introduction to both Id say..

Batch001X4 - 750ml Caged and Corked.

A -Dark and Deep Red, Almost brown and fairly opaque. Very little head if any.

S - Lots of sourness, dark and sweet candy. I pick up some new fruit and slight oak as well.

T - Just amazing. I not completely versed in how these tend to age but I find the sourness fades a bit and the fruit becomes more evident. The currants, fig, and candy notes were outstanding and really stood up the brett/lacto nicely. The oak tends to develop nicely and become more prevalent with aging. It was only a bit but I felt like the oak was there on the finish. I was surprised it had any left but the carbonation was perfect.

M - Perfect. The carbonation wasnt low but just the way I prefer for this style.

What a great vintage and an even better way to share with friends. Thanks techster82

Serving type: bottle

Thanks to McGrupp612 for the bottle via trade!!   Rant starts now - WhyTF do brewers keep putting beer in wine and/or bourbon barrels.  If I wanted wine (dont) I would get wine - to me, there was too much wine aroma and flavor for me to get past; dont have a clue if this is good beer or not.  End rant.

Bottle, batch 003x1 (from mid/late 2009).  Pours a deep red/purple with minimal head.  Very intriguing taste, not as sour as I was expecting.  Smell is sharp, certainly sour, but with a bit of dark fruit scent.  Flavor is pretty similar....plum, currant (as advertised), dark flavors with the sharp bite.  Very good overall.

Tap @ brewery. Had this many times...very surprise! Clear, deep copper, tan head of medium size, turns to a ring, no lace.  Aroma of booze, wine, currants, smells sour...not sure what like...just smells like a sour.  Mouth is fullisg with light Carb and a balanced finish. Flavor is sour, currants, wine barrels as in oaky fruity and sour. Balanced sweetness, long pleasantly sour finance sh. Sour cherries. Very tasty.

This is the best of the russian river that I have had so far. Not overly sour with a very unique slightly sweet current taste. Not overly complex but a nice easy drinker. Thanks to Popkas trading me this

My second Russian River sour ale. 375 mL bottle poured into a tulip glass. Pours a light amber color, very little head, medium carbonation. Thin lacing all the way around the glass. If you are into sour ales, this is your brew. Not my favorite style, but a very nicely done beer from Russian River.

Bottle - 375mL corked and caged - batch 005x2E. Rusty copper with spotty bubbles.  Aroma is sour fruit, currants, cat urine, funky yeast, and pleasant earthiness. Lemon juice, unripe currants, sour cherry, sweat, leather, wet earth, and damp wood.  Carbonation is bubbly for this medium bodied beer. Acidic throughout and bone dry during the finish. Ends with vinegar, sour fruit, currants, funky yeast, damp wood and earthy notes.

Rating #700!  Corked and caged bottle enjoyed at City Beer with a few locals, upon their recommendation.  This pours red and orange, dark, with a small beige head.  Aromas of currants, red berries, toasted oak, red wine and grapes, and some light Balsamic vinegar and acidity.  The flavor is a refreshing mix of sour berries and wine, with noticeable oak present throughout.  Mouthwatering and complex, with just the right tartness and carbonation to yield a spritzy and refreshing drink.  So good, I wish I had access to this stuff.  [700]

i love this sour a great beer not as good as supplication in my opinion but a great, wine tastes with grape and champagne flavors and aromas. this is a fantastic beer. i cant wait to drink and rate again when i havent had so many beers already.

Poured from the 12 oz bottle. Aroma is sour, and makes my mouth water. C flavour is sour and there is a finishing flavour like that of some kind of fruit.. This is my second sour, and Im not really sure how to rate them but this one is delicious!

Poured into a tulip glass.  Color is a clear reddish orange brown with little head.  Aroma is sour grapes.  Flavor is sour grapes with a slightly malty finish.  Palate is medium bodied with a tart mouthfeel.  Overall I am still very new to the sour category but this does seem to fit well.
Bottle. Pours dark red / brown. Aroma and taste are... sour! Wood, yeast, wine, and funk in the taste. Another delightful tion.
Poured dark like a porter, so i thought it might taste similar. Nope, tasted like under sweetened lemonade. Not my thing i guess. To be fair i did drink the whole thing
Pours a dark reddish brown color. Very oaky lots of vanilla and toasted barrels, currents, red wine, and alcohol. Tannic and awesome.

(Bottle, 0.375l - batch 004X5, thanks Stig!, 20110514) The beer poured reddish brown and quite clear. Its head was small and white. Aroma had sourness, berries, black currant and malts. Palate was dry and medium bodied with quite a lot of carbonation. Flavours were sourness, berriness, fruitiness, malts, tartness, acidiness and bitterness. Aftertaste was sour and tart. Simply a great sour ale. Lot of strong flavours all of which would make a beer a horrible experience but in this brew they match quite perfectly together.

Pours a ruby red and dark mahogany color.  Head dissipates quickly with minimal lacing.  Smells of dried fruit, red wine, and rye.  Huge cabernet sauvignon taste, very dry like wine.  Huge carbonation in the mouth.  Absolutely phenomenal beer.

I am still chuckling from the funny Brits review comment describing this one as refreshing as a surprise blow job. 

I will agree that this is a very refreshing brew. Actually, it is shockingly tasty and say to drink at 10% ABV. The sourness is just right - no puckering yet addictively sweet and sour. It does have the cherry and cranberry fruit taste yet has notes of grape-like wine flavor and a vinegar tinge. Carbonation is high and part of what makes it very refreshing. Mouthfeel lingers for ages. Wish I could get more of this.

Batch 004X1.  Chestnut brown pour with a frothy head that dissipated in the blink of an eye, no lacing.  Smell of tart vinegar.  Rich and smooth on the tongue, the flavor is that of wood laced in vinegar.  Some fruity berry flavors, caramel malts.  The sourness is real, but it doesnt take over.  This thing coats your mouth after going down and the sourness just wont let go of my tongue.  Very winelike.  Nice beer.

Bottle shared on holiday with MesandSim. This is the kind of beer that impresses on me the importance of a dman good sour ale in my drinking life. Murky dark brown with a thin beige head. Complex in aroma and flavour. Aroma of famryard shite, balsamic vinegar, marzipan, lots of fruit, sultanas. Great mouthfeel, as refreshing as a surprise blowjob. Really tasty.

Bottle, thanks to zdk for sharing (Batch 001x4). Poured brown and mostly clear with a foamy brown head that fades. Fruity aroma with a light sourness, lots of currants, berries, and dark fruit. Lots of flavor, very sour with ripe fruit, red wine. A bit of sweetness to start, but finishes dry and tart. Very complex and delicious. I had very high expectations for this one, and it came pretty close to meeting them.
Aroma: sour cherry, plum notes, Taste/feel: high carbonation, some fruit note taste with a strong taste of dry wine with sour notes.  It has a very full flavor/feel.  Very quality.

Bottle, Batch 005X1F. Rating #1000 for me.  Thanks to many kind Ratebeerians for shares, good company, and generosity.  Ruby red brown with minimal head development. Lacto-sourness, some slight funkiness, and vinegar in the aroma with some fruit tartness. Dark and fruity flavors, cherry, rice vinegar, tart but not puckering or overly dry. Hints of cranberry and a slight woodiness. Medium to thinner body and softer carbonation.

Smaller bottle. Thanks a lot to the guys for trading this one. Poured light hazy brown with little head. Very sour with light floral and spice notes. One of the best sours I have ever had. Would like to have more.
Wow, what a good beer, Had from a bottle and poured really nicely. it was a super sour but really not too sour, it was an amazing beer. I look forward to my next tasting
Pours mahogany with brilliant amber highlights. The beer bursting with sour notes and fruit.  Cherries, apples, currants, and pears are complimented by woody notes and some brown sugar. Awesome

Bottle split with McBerko. Pours a dark chestnut brown with tan ring. Aroma is deep cherry, some brandied fruit. Taste is extremely sour, pithy, puckering oak, mild sweetness, finish is mildly boozy. Finish is long lasting and sour. Very good for style.

Tasted on 4/19/11 from a 750mL bottle obtained in a trade, batch 002x3.  Pours cloudy dark amber with a thick beige head that recedes fairly quickly to no head and a thin collar of lace.  The nose is sour and funky with balsamic vinegar, dark berries, tart lemon, and vanilla oak.  The flavor is very sour with tart berries, balsamic vinegar, vanilla oak, with an underlying molasses and brown sugar flavor.  The body is medium and somewhat oily with lively carbonation and a long berry, brown sugar, vanilla, and oak tannin finish.
Bottle. Pours brown with thin white head. Aroma is funky yeasty sour cherries. Flavor is more of the same, with some oak. Very nice.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2012 First rating375 ml bottle thanks to Reza! (not on ratebeer)Sampled on April 12, 2011Clear copper to brown color, small tan head. Sour and also sweet scent, some wood and hints of vinegar. Sour to very sour taste, unripe red currants aftertaste. Lingering sourness. Medium mouthfeel, warming alcohol feeling, very low bitterness.6/3/8/3/15=3.5Rerate375 ml bottle thanks to Gusgus! Batch 005X2E, sampled on August 11, 2012Murky brown color, small yellow to tan head. Acidic, lactic, yeast, alcohol scent. LActic, acidic, green currants, sour, tart taste. Smooth and puckering mouthfeel, dry aftertaste. Very low bitterness. Sour stomach punch.8/3/8/3/16=3.8
My first sour beer. Tastes more like a red wine than beer really. Carbonation accentuated by sourness. Enjoyable, but not cheap!

UPDATED: APR 10, 2011 75 cl bottle. Deep purple-brown with a low, fine, head. Rich lactic and fruit aroma, dusty, with cassis, yogurt, some chocolate, and alcohol fumes. Soft liquid body but with big carbonation. Sweet-and-sour flavor of cherry, currant, yogurt, wood, some vanilla. Great balance. Truly nice stuff.

Bottle shared by DalzAle. Pour is clear cola and copper with a kahki head that fades to a collar. Aroma is funk sourness and fruit. Taste is plenty sour and sharp cheese and fruit. Palate is thin fizzy and finishes chaulky.

Ive had the opportunity to have this on three separate occasions. Once at GABF, and twice at home with some bottles I was able to find while out there. The beer at first is unassuming. It pours a cloudy, hazy, mahogany with a small, tiny head. Then you smell it. Smell is oaked funk. Very sour, with a sufficiently huge aroma. First taste is an explosion on the tongue, with a huge sour note exploding outwards midway through the first taste. Wow. Thats really all I can say. Must be tasted to be believed. The standard bearer for sour beers. . Pliny gets all the press but this beer deserves all the accolades - and more. Most assuredly up there with my favorites of all time.

Sweet grape currant aroma with some sour apple notes as well light brown appearance with a small white fizzy head first taste is a strong sweet currant taste then goes to a very sour taste and finishes with a faint sweet sour taste

375ml thanks to my boy out in Colorado: Tennessejed420: Anyway, I got batch 005x2e (if that matters...). Anyway, it pours a reddish brown with a evanescent head that leaves but a speck of lacing. So what is in the aroma? Some wood, a little bit of wine, tart sour cherries, not the slightest hint of booze, some other ambiguous fruit aromas (currants perhaps...). So yeah, all good stuff. The taste goes through a series of stages (as a complex beer should one would think). At first, my mouth was not sure what was really going on, but then the sour started hitting and escalated. It enveloped the tongue brought out a little bit of astringency. This is not an extremely sour beer, although it is plenty sour (not that this has any impact on enjoyability). However, it is more complex than most other sour ales that I have had and it is also certainly of a higher abv. The mouthfeel, which I find to be one of the primary appeals of sours, is wonderful. Not too sour, but sour enough. Feels like you just ate some candy, but not in a bad way.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2011 Almost perfect. Pours reddish brown, and no head to speak of. Aroma is a mix of cherry (or currants, I suppose...), chocolate, with whiffs of oak and vanilla. Flavor is tart fruit and rich chocolate. Really, though, it isnt just the list of flavors that make this one awesome, its an almost uncanny way that such heavy flavors seems so light and airy. I mean, there is no way I wouldve guessed that this is a 10% beer. Just an almost perfect beer. I wish I had more. A lot more... Thanks to lithy for this one!

An impromptu Consecration vertical broke out at a recent tasting, we were able to sample batch 1, 2, and 3 side by side. I am happy to report that they are very similar.

Batch 001 - Beer is brown and clear, there is no head and only slight carbonation. The aroma is a mixture of sweet and sour (but not of the Chinese food variety). Really great sour / tart flavor with a hint of malt in there, really shocking. Beer finishes slightly dry overall. There is also a hint of oak and funk at the end, very slight.

Batch 002 - Again, it is clear and brown but this time the carbonation a lot higher. Large bubbles rise through the beer quickly, still no head. The aroma is slightly sweeter but is still very sour. The beer has the same sour notes at the batch 001, in fact they are pretty much the exact same flavor but this one has a slight bitterness to it. I think the bitterness helps accent the oak flavors in the back.

Batch 003 - This one appears slightly lighter than the other two, but just slightly. Still brown and clear. Not as bitter as the Batch 002 but just as sour. Some oak notes in the back.

Overall this is a top notch sour, one of my favorites by a lot. All three were great and I would have them again.

Serving type: bottle

Poured froma 375ml bottle into a tulip at Euclid Hall.

A: Pours a rich dark brown similar to a dark scotch or whisky with no head whatsoever. Lacing is lean if at all. Reminds me of a glass filled with a spirit.

S: Intense tart and sour notes. Currents are dominate for main flavor but oak is present as well. Touch of sweetness similar to vanilla pop up here and there but overall this is a very sour beer.

T: Clean and balanced but still quite tart and sour. Big sour and tart notes hit the palate up front with current as the fruit. Current is very dominate but the entire flavor is clean and balanced with just a touch of oak and wood.

M: Full bodied and clings to the palate, front to back, from start to finish. There is zero carbonation, the bite from this beer comes from the sour affects of yeast and barrel aging.

D: This is an amazing sour. The barrel aging in Cabernet barrels with currents truly gives you a puckering affect thats sour and tart from start to finish. This isnt over done on sour instead is incredibly balanced for how intense and big this beer is.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2012 Pours a medium brown/caramel color with a small white head. Aromas are sour yeast and sweet malt. The taste is initially wood barrels and  whiskey, followed by a sour finish, but not overly sour. Ive tried 3 or 4 sours now and I havent been a fan. This is the first sour I can actually say I enjoyed and wish I had more of. I had this again at the stumbling monk in Seattle on 7/27/2012. Its an amazing beer, I cant get enough. Russian River are my heros and I want to personally thank them for making amazing beers like this,

This pours a light clear brown, very clear in the light. The head is very small with no retention, light lacing. 

The aroma is light but pretty complex, especially compared to temptation, which I tasted at the same time. The sour funk is there but there notes of sweet druit, alcohol and wood, which is very pleasant.

The taste is very strange and heavy handed in the beginning. Its like the tannins of a red wine. There are some notes of oak and alcohol. The taste is very sour on the end. **Upon re-review 8 months later, I like it a lot better. The wood really mellows out and starts to show off a little more sweetness in the red wine variety.

Mouthfeel is very heavy, but not entirely drinkable.

Overall, pretty damn good sour, but not world class as its rating and ranking suggest. Worth trying but dont overpay or trade for it.

Bottle, batch 001x004. Nice deep red color with a small tanned head. Very beautiful. Aroma is heavy with mild sourness, saturated with sour berries, leather, lemon, vinegar, some hops, strong oak and alcohol. Very pleasant and balanced. Taste is extremely sour - more so than promised by the aroma - very fruity with a lot of oak, champagne, sour berries, cherry and leather. Very nicely balanced.

Tap @ Falling rock, Denver. Pours dark golden with a small white head. Aroma of tart sour cherries, earth, brett, barn, oak. Taste is very sour with tart cherries, green grapes, brett, green apples, oak. Thin body, lively carbonation. Very interesting and complex beer, and easily the sourest beer i ever had, and also abit over the top for me. 260211

Bottle, batch 005x2F.
Aroma: strong dark fruits; plum, sour cherries, red wine.
Appearance: deep amber - burgundy color, good clarity, head is basically nonexistent.
Flavor: tart fruits, cherries, oak, toasty malt notes hidden under the fruit.  Nice puckering sourness, flavor is fairly clean; not a lot going on in the way of wild yeast.
Palate: medium body and carbonation, puckering with a dry finish.
Overall: enjoyed this immensely, lots of complex fruit flavors and great sour character.

12.6 fl oz corked and caged brown bottle. Batch 004x4.

It pours with a super fizzy head that dissipates within a second and leaves no lacing. The beer is a hazy reddish plumb color with hints of brown.

It has a pungent smell. There is some red wine smell along with a huge whiff of oak. There is also some sour currant and caramel. It is very sour and oaky smelling.

The taste is very reminiscent to a dark red wine. It is very vinous and tannic. The oak is milder in the flavor than it was in the smell. There is a slight funk note but the yeast is mostly sour. Not asspuckeringly sour but pretty nicely sour. Underneath everything there are traces of malts including the smallest hint of toastiness. It finishes with a dry grapeskin/seed flavor. As you go the subtly sweet currant flavor can be tasted in the back of the mouth along with some oxidized apple. 

The mouthfeel is pretty good for a sour. It is a tad thin but very dry and tannic in the finish. The alcohol surprisingly isnt totally hidden under the deep complexity though it never becomes overbearing.

Overall this is a nice sour. It is definitely one of the sourest beers I have had yet.

Serving type: bottle

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2011 Bevuta alla spina alla Brasserie 4:20 (Roma) - Birra sensazionale. Ambrata, quaasi rubino, molto intensa e abbastanza limpida. Aroma molto fruttato con nette note legnose. In bocca è di una intensità straordinaria, acida, aspra, con note legnose e di resina, eppure bilanciatissima. Una meraviglia.
This beer begins with strong bitter cherry notes, but it mellows beautifully. The bar tender warned me it would change my life, and I do believe he was right.
Pours a hazey red with off-white foam. Smells sweet and tart of red currents and cranberries. Tastes very sour with sweetness and tarness from currents with a very tart aftertaste.

I carefully opened the cage and popped the cork in the sink just in case this one decided to do its best Old Faithful impersonation.  Luckily there was no gushing so I poured it into my Bruery tulip glass.  The color is a very clear, deep ruby red.  There is a thin tan head but it is gone before I can even take a picture.  My dad mentioned it fizzed away like soda.

I didnt get a whole lot in the nose to be honest.  The main things I picked up were vinegar and alcohol.

Now the taste was much more bold.  Sour cherries are the primary taste in there.  I get a rather acidic feeling in the taste as well.  Slight oxidation but not bad at all.  The taste got even better as it warmed up.

Batch 001x4, 75 cl, courtesy of Mashmaster. Pours chestnut brown with a dissipating light brown head. Aroma has lots of wine characteristics. Cabernet barrels really shine through. Huge oak, vanilla, slight acetone, hints of pipe tobacco, dark fruits, dates and figs. Taste is very sour with lactic acid up front, wet wood, oak, hints of caramel and dates. Brett is very clear too. Hints of cherries and grape fruit bitterness. Utterly complex and really good. 2-23-11

375 mL corked/caged bottle - batch 004X5 - pours a crystal clear ruby red color with tiny tan head that dissipates almost immediately. Aroma is ful of leathery horseblanket funk, sour cherries, musty earth, toasted oak, peach pits, bit of rusted iron and dried blood. Flavor is really strongly tart, with a fair amount of cherries, dried oak, notes of kalamata olives, bit of rust and damp earth. Finish is dry and pretty tart. Overall this is very good. The metallic notes detract a bit in my mind, and there is a bit of an odd saltiness - possibly a water issue? It does seem like it needs a bit more maltiness to support the bracing sour notes. Nevertheless, this is wonderfuly complex and interesting, and just furthers the advancement of what beer can be.

750ml bottle, batch 003 x2. Pours a hazy dark amber with no head or lacing. nice sour raisin aroma, very tart and dry with a bit of of barnyard funk. Huge sour taste on the palate, gets more sour, and absolutely no taste of alcohol. Seems thin but very complex. A great sour RR beer - one of my favourite easily findable american sours. 

Kelly recommends to take mango gum out of mouth before drinking (ideally wash out mouth with soap and then water).

On tap at the brewery.  This beer has sour aromas and notes of vinegar on the nose.  The appearance is a gorgeous dark reddish brown and almost no head.  Taste is very complex with notes of sour fruit like raspberries and figs, but then you get sour balsamic flavors followed by a dry oaky finish that lingers.  This is a very good sour and one that is not overhyped.  Overall, I like this one a lot....due the complexity.

Batch 4.  When I got this it was a Top 50 beer - not sure where it stands now.  I have been saving it for a big rating (1200!) and at $17 for a 375 ml bottle, it better be good.  The appearance is pretty average, but it is super interesting on the nose - aromas of fruit, cider, malt, oak, and some flowers.  The taste is very sour and oaky, and there seem to be wine tannins in there too.  Nice impact on the palate - numbing and sour.  You could easily fool someone into thinking that this was a random wine.  It makes me think more of a shiraz wine than a beer, and sure enough, a close look at the label reveals that is has been aged in cabernet sauvignon barrels - that explains a thing or two. 

It is interesting for sure, but it didnt really win me over.  The tarry wine residue clashes a little with the sour cherry flavor of the ale.  Consecration costs as much as good wine, and given that it tastes so much like wine, I would rather have a glass of good vino.  The alcohol content is similar too. And something is not right here - no wine connoisseur would drink a wine that has been aged in beer barrels.  So why are we beer geeks drinking beer that has left to sit in old wine casks?  Maybe I am being unfair.  I have not had a lot of the sour ales out there, not yet anyway, but I will give Russian River this - Consecration is not like anything else I have had yet.  This may end up with a good rating after all, but it is not going to the top of my charts. I dont think I will seek it out again. Interesting brew, but overpriced and overrated.

Bottle (batch 1 - so it cannot be better... ever!). Fruity and sour aroma. Hints of black currants, raspberries, redwine vinegar, balsamico and muscovado sugar. Quite sour and mouth drooling. What to say - its so rare that I like it. I fancy rare beer. No honestly, this is great! A sour complex beer with wine-notes, fruity and just so rare!

Bottled. Poured dark brown with a light brown head. Aroma was sour fruit, big malts, and more fruits. Medium sourness and lightly sweet. Average carbonation with a medium body, and a mild sour finish.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2011 Pours hazy dark amber with pretty much no head.  Aroma is sour oak funk, currants, sour apple.  Taste is tart apples, currant, lots of oak, some sweet malt and a buttery, almost creamy undertone.  Finish is long, dry, and tart with the slightest burn from the alcohol.  This is one of my all time favorites.  Its absolutely brilliant.

Bottle for rating #3200: &nbsp Heavy dirty caramel, large foamy fawn colored head, so-so lacing, little to no carbonation. &nbsp Musty nose, barnish, really barnish, heavy horse blanket with a strong undescript fruity flair. &nbsp Definitely currants, but not over the top. &nbsp Mmmmm, first and foremost, this is a sour with accents of currants. &nbsp And might I add very nice accents. &nbsp This is rather well balanced. &nbsp If this is 10% then I am the King of England. &nbsp Seriously. &nbsp Well hidden alcohol, tart, fruity, slightly sour. &nbsp This one isnt over the top. &nbsp Balanced enough to be dry, tart, yet also sweet. &nbsp This is rather devine. &nbsp Lingering currant aspects. &nbsp This would be great with a walnut salad. &nbsp Oh man... yeah, spinach salad too. &nbsp Damn, really impressed with this one. &nbsp Smooth, very smooth. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate to full. &nbsp God damn I want to eat a salad with this. &nbsp Maybe something with shrimp. &nbsp Land locked meats, stay away. &nbsp Maybe some shellfish or something... yeah, seafood too. &nbsp Now I am hungry. &nbsp Great F*ing beer. &nbsp Fruity, without being over the top. &nbsp Dry, yet somewhat sweet. &nbsp Perfect now... but what will a year or two do?

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2011 Batch 3, a fantastic batch.  

Nose is alcohol heavy but has pleasant light tartness, some fruit sweetness, and an underlying quality of slight caramel malt. Taste is sweet, sour, ethyl alcohol. Crisp and vibrant. Drinkability is high.

Aroma is great. Sweet and sour. Dark berries, red wine, vanilla, very complex. Appearance is dark brown with hint of red, small white head. Taste is.... wow... shockingly sour. I have little experience with sour beers... but to me this is just insane. Very salty and puckering bitter. Sour dark fruits and berries. Red wine very present. There is sweetness, but it is smacked down by the incredible sourness. Palate is medium and crisp. Just like a glass of wine. Overall a really unique interesting beer. Like nothing I have had. It took a bit to decide if I liked it. Totally different experience if you judge it as a wine. Again, one of the most unique beverages I have ever had...... very impressive. A well done combination of beer and wine is the best way I can describe this.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2011 Aroma is very sour with notes of fruit. The appearance is a brandy color with red hints coming through. The taste is sour, but in the best way possible. My favorite sour ale at the moment by far. Hopefully my local store will have some more soon. Russian River Brewing really has their act together with a great variety of top notch beers coming out, I have yet to be disappointed.

The aroma was sour and it had a strange quality, though some of that is expected. Rich amber appearance. The Cabernet Sauvignon is the most powerful flavor present in this beer. Currents back the wine nicely, adding to the sour content. It was heavy and difficult to drink much of. This beer however did not drink or taste like a beer. Nice for wine drinkers. Im glad I tried it, but I should have bought the 375ml.

Batch 04x2, 375ml Bottle purchased at LaBodega Wine and Spirits in Riverside CA.  Pours a clear, beautiful reddish-brown color with little to no head.  Aroma is fruity and sour.  Medium on the palate with average carbonation.  Flavor is a clean sour with hints of fruit and oak.  Extremely smooth.  I said it about Supplication, and Ill say it about Consecration: I would drink this every day if money and availability would allow.

This is one of my favorite sours at the moment.  Pours a nice brandy color.  The head was off white and dissipated fast.  the smells are cherry and plum.  Taste is sour cherry and plum, very clean finish.  Super refreshing after a long day without sour.

Draft. Poured a clear brown color with an average fizzy off-white head that mostly lasted with fair lacing. Moderate to heavy sour and yeast aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy sour flavor with a medium to heavy sour finish of moderate to long duration. This is a standout beer for style.

Perhaps my favorite beer at the moment. We had this on tap
in Seattle in December and then brought some home from SF. So sour and fizzy and magical.

Poured from a bottle into a tulip glass. Appearance is a translucent brownish amber. Aroma is a lot likes a long island iced tea. Taste is a wonderful green apple taste. This is perhaps one of my new favorite beers.
Bottle. 005x02F.  mahogany pour. this thing is great! very balanced with cherry, oak, lemon, sour and funk.  wish it was more available to me.

From notes:

Pours a deep ruby color with golden mahogany edges and a two finger frothy off-white head. Good retention, only slowly fading into a lasting ring that coats the glass with large chunks of soapy lacing.

Funky, musty aroma with lots of earthy oak tannis, dry brett and vinous dark fruit. The barrel aging is very prominent in the nose with lots of red wine character. Hints of grape, currant, tart cherries and other dark berries as well as oak and subtle vanilla. This is complimented by the funky/barnyard/horsey notes.

Full bodied, intensely tart and puckering with slight acidity and some soft carbonation up front. Very funky with lots of musty, dry brett/bugs as well as a sour vinegar flavor that lingers over the barrel and vinous dark fruit notes into puckering dry finish that leaves me drooling for more. As in the aroma, the barrel character is prominent with earthy oak, slight vanilla and a prominent red wine/dark fruit flavor. Hints of grape, currant cherry, plum, raisin and other dark berries.

This beer has an incredible balance of tart, acidic, funky sourness and sweet, vinous dark fruit and it is the perfect blend of the wine and craft beer worlds.

On-tap at Obriens. Pours hazy red/brown with a minuscule offwhite head with no lace. Smells fruity sweet and vinegary sour. Tastes fruity and malty sour with vinegar and some hay. Good. Some wood barrel on the finish. Medium body, good carbonation.

375ml bottle, batch 004X1, dark amber color, with some orangeish highlights, and an off-beige head, nice mild yeasty, funky, winey, woody, fruity, toasted, caramel malt nose, with a sweet and sour fruity accent of faint tart blackcurrants, elderberries, blackberries and blueberries, within an acidic, tannic aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a mild sweet and sour, fruity, winey, oakey, bretty, funky wild yeastiness, toasted, caramelized malt character with some tart green apple, blackcurrant, elderberry, red cherry acidic flavours upfront, with some red wine tannic wooden barrel undertones, leading towards a sour fruity, winey, oaky finish.

Draft at Monks for Russian River Day. Pours deep, dark, mahogany silky brown with a calm, smooth surface. No head. Aroma is subtle, but nice; sour cherries, tart fig, grapes, red wine, slight vinegar barley, hints of vanilla, oak, and sweet malts. Medium bodied with a sticky, tangy, yet amazingly sour and juicy mouthfeel. Finishes with an insanely crisp, tart bite. One of the most unique, beautifully arranged sour ales I have ever tasted. Great brew in every regard.
Bottle at manny browns in neshaminy. Sour smelling. Tangy, sour, mouth puckering.  Alcohol is well hidden but the warmth is there.  Aftertaste is a powerhouse of sourness.

After an unreasonably arduous brewday, I need something good to relax me and the funk was calling me. Poured into a tulip. Batch 003x4.

Cork pull gave a spirited pop, but then the beer inside got pissy and decided to spill out a bit over the top. Not really overcarbonated, but given the day I just had, Im not surprised that this beer was out to get me. Anyway...

4.0 A: Dark mahogany color and hazy. Looks like I might have gotten the yeast in an uproar. Two fingers of fizzy off white head that acts and falls like the head on a can of Coke.

4.0 S: Nose is pleasant, but pretty simplistic for a sour. On the acid front, the only thing that comes through with any power is acetic acid, which could be amplified by the currants. Latic acid is soft if it is even there at all. I can smell the barrel, but wouldnt have any idea that it was Savignon if I didnt read the label. Black currant and cherry fruitiness underlying.

4.0 T: Quite a lot more going on in the taste than in the nose. The first thing that struck me was a tongue paralyzing astringency, but this dies down upon additional sips. Very musky as well. The Cabernet makes an big appearance in the taste and actually this tastes more like a soured wine than a soured beer. Though there is a touch of vinegary-ness, there is a lot more lactic acid, though surprisingly not too tart. Tannins with currant and raisin fruitiness. Though I appreciate complexity, the big bold flavors are each too aggressive on their own and fail to mesh harmoniously.

3.5 M: Lighter medium. Good moderate amount of fizzy carbonation. Astrigency on finish that lingers. Alcohol is noticeable, but seems more like 7% than 10%.

3.5 D: Not bad, but seems like there are too many flavors competing without any direction.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-24-2010 05:00:47

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 Tap @ Falling Rock. Pours a dark red, burgundy appearance with a light red/white head. Nicely carbonated. Fairly sour currant (somewhat cherry-like) nose with notes of funk, lots of oak, red wine, fig, and tobacco. Oaky, puckering sour, red fruity, cherry, dark berry, red vinous, mild vinegar, wood, fig flavor. Quite amazing!

Slightly muddy red pour with a good amount of carbonation and a light tan head.  Aroma is sour funk and some sweet currants.  Relatively mild but exciting.  Flavor is vinegar sharp with a good bit of mouth puckering sour and some wonderful sweetness coming through the backend.  Best of the Russian River sour beers Ive had so far.

Regular on tap from brewery in Santa Rosa. The sourest and highest alcohol beer RR serves on a regular basis. Pours a pretty brownish red color. Initial scents are what pulls you in, but in no way prepares you for the oncoming sour taste. Smells of bready yeast, oak, earthiness, and hints of red wine barrel room. Flavors of puckering sour, wine, dark fruit and cherries. Medium bodied with some light carbonation. Complex aromas and flavors. Gets better as it warms and as you get to the bottom of the glass... Could have something to do with the high alcohol content! Great sour!

Pours a beautiful dark red, almost like a very dark red wine. Smells funky, with lots of fruit and sour aromas in there. Earthy mud smell is noticeable, but fruits and sour are prevalent. The taste is heavily sour, with tons of cherry and berry tastes. Alcohol is not noticeable at all. Sourness is not too heavy - this beer was easily drinkable to my brother and I. If you see this in the store, get it.

Bottle from Healthy Spirits, San Francisco. Darkish brown pour with a fading off white head. Nose revealed fruit and barrel notes aplenty in addition to traces of alcohol, spice and barnyard sour. Very sniffable. Flavour was similarly laden and complex. Dark fruit, wood, berries, brown sugar, sour lemon. Cracking stuff. Dried out markedly towards the finish with some further tartness lurking. This just got better with each sip, and I was torn between wanting to eke out and savour every drop or just take a whopping great big indulgent swig. A very refined and fine spun beer.

Shipped to me by my wife on a trip to Portland. Batch 003X. Sampled from a 750 ml corked brown bottle this beer poured a dark red-brown color with a medium sized foamy beige head that faded quickly and produced no lacing. The aroma was sweet, funky, lactic and had moderate notes of grape, wine, nut, bread and a tart and sour undertone. Complex and interesting on the nose. The flavor was very tart and sour with notes of funk, merlot, raisin, vanilla, nut, and wood. The finish was very long, tart and sour with lingering fruit, lactose and funk. Moderately full bodied. Not at all an easy to drink beer but certainly complex and interesting.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2011 Sample at the brewpub. Pours a clear brownish-amber color with a medium fizzy head that evaporates rather quickly. Spots and strings of lace. Aroma of oak, cherries and malt.
