Rich and tart vinous character with flavors of oak, dark fruits, malt and yeast. The finish is woody and fruity with a yeast aftertaste. Solid brew all around.

Hazy mahogany red with a one-finger head that dissipated slowly and left nice lace. Dark fruit aromas, mostly sour cherry and grape, almost wine-like, with hints of oak. Flavors were similar, but much stronger, featuring a tartness that bordered on sour. Sour apple, black cherry, and tart grapes rule, with candy sugar and oak also prominent. Medium body, minimal carbonation, and a pleasant fruit sweetness in the finish. Outstanding.

375ml bottle corked & wire caged. batch 004x4. corked popped aggressively with no foaming.beer served at about 45*F. beer served in snifter glass. beer poured a beautiful deep brown with ruby red hues. first smells give off a lovely sour carmelized fruit scent. the smell is sharp but well rounded at the same time. acidity notes throughout . first tastes are initially very sour with sweet fruit flavors, transcending into beautiful mild acidic tones. truely a nice sour ale ! one of my top favorites!

Bottle [750ml] shared with HogTownHarry, tupalev, jerc & mabel -- c/o j&m. Batch 002X2. Pours a murky orange-brown with lots of sediment and a small diminishing tan head. Nice sour fruity aroma along with oak, some alcohol and red wine. Flavour of sour fruit, red wine, oak and light spices. Alcohol is well hidden in the flavour. Very tart finish. Medium bodied. Fantastic stuff.

Pours a clear reddish brown color with a quick fizzy head that is gone after a few seconds. Aroma is sour and funky with citrus and floral notes. Flavor is VERY sour with lots of citrus and mineral. Just a touch of bitterness at the end, but maybe thats from being so sour. Underlying all of the other flavors is a rich oak character. The carbonation is almost like a flat champagne but gives it a nice body. Very nice.

Bottled (thanks after4ever!). New Years Beer enjoyed at midnight. Amber colour, small head. Aroma is barnyard, sour wood, some mild wood, quite pleasant balance. Flavour is very much the same in a really excellent balance.

Bottled (batch 004X5)
Deep nut brown color, no head. Sour nose has berries, black currant leaves, citrus and oak. Medium bodied. Very delicious acidic flavor with berries (cranberries), fruityness, earthy, wood .... Extremely balanced wild yeast beer. I had this with oh6gdx out in the yard at 0000 1.1.2011.

Batch 004x02. Consumed on 08/23/2010.

Pours a lusty and hazy ruby red with little to no head, though I poured it cold. Second pour yields a nice, short-lived three-quarter finger head. 

Sweet and tangy berries, sour cherries, a muted oakiness, major vinous notes. Fresh and bright aroma. On the palate, Consecration starts with the taste thats left on your fingers after picking blackberries, which is overcome by leathery and funky brett. Nicely blended, wonderful currant presence, and the Cabernet notes come through beautifully, but this vintage is heavy on a tobacco character I find distracting on the finish. 

Fairly light, with a dry finish. Its hard to think this is 10% ABV.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2011 Tap @ Beveridge Place. Clear, red-amber pour with minimal head and no lace. Sour nose with some fruit. Sourness continues from start to finish, but it is tempered nicely by some bitterness and umami added by the oak and currants. There is an underlying sweetness that builds towards the finish. Grape, cherry, lemon and currant flavors, very well balanced. ABV is nearly transparent. Medium body with light carbonation. Lovely!

375 ml bottle.

Aroma: Funky, sour, lactic tang, dark fruit, black currant, cask wood. A huge nose with the promise of great things to taste.

Appearance: Brown pour, ruby highlights, thin, off-white to tan head faded pretty quick but left decent lace.

Taste: Incredibly sour, tangy, oaky. Black currant, dark, bready malt, barnyard, brett bitterness, lacto tanginess, vinous, tobacco leaves.

Palate: Highly carbonated, satisfying. The carbonation balances the intense sourness well.

Overall: Incredible. Amazing. Easily rivals anything brewed in Belgium. Brewing brilliance at its finest. I wish it were more widely available.

aroma of currants and slightly vinegary with some yeast - pours a nice brownish copper with little head - flavor is very acidic with a sweet after taste and hints of currant and oak - to me the taste is reminiscent of the smell of the lumber yard when I was a kid!

750 ml bottle courtesy of a trade with Smokepot23.  This is another bottle that Ive had in my cellar for a while that I am finally getting around to drinking this week.  The cork popped out rather aggressively and there was an initial pulse of foam that ejected from the bottle but nothing further.  I allowed it to settle for a moment before pouring.  Pours a deep but still transparent clear ruby with a moderate-large off-white head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left very little lace.  The aroma is filled with currants, lemon, mild oak, and red wine vinegar.  The flavor is simply lovely with currants, lemon, black cherry, red wine vinegar, and some soft, mild oak.  Sour but also bright and crisp.  Lively on the palate.  This is a wonderful beer!

Sour ale is appropriate.  Incredibly sour. Scent yields currant spice. Taste was initially extremely sour with a well rounded sweet/dry aftertaste. 
Not my cup of tea

Pours amber with a thin head. Aroma is sour with hints of dark fruit and wine. The taste is much stronger than you would expect from the aroma. Very sour with a dry finish. Has good carbonation. Overall, this is a great sour. Not to funky with an excellent finish.
bottle. pours ruddy amber. thinnish diminishing head.  aroma of wine, dark fruit, sugar, sour funk.  flavor is nice sour finish, dryish moutfeel, thin but delightful.  great beer.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2013 On tap at Russian River, pours a dark reddish brown with a small beige head. Nose brings out dark sour fruits, red wine, and wild yeast - exceptionally complex. Flavour is no less complex, with loads of tart dark red fruits, complex wild yeast, and fine cabernet wine notes. Amazing depth to this - the wine barrels and wild yeast are executed to perfection. A benchmark dark sour.

Tap at the source, courtesy of Jess and his moustache, thank you sir!  Last bit of the keg.  Hazy brown color, no head or lacing.  Aroma resembles a Rodenbach, sour oak.  Taste resembles port wine, medium body.  Good stuff.

[3465-20101113] 1pt9.4floz bottle. Nice sweet yeast aroma has roast malt and mild toasted old fruit. Hazy, dark brown body with a quick bubbly head. Sour tasty fruit flavour has wood stems and some raisin notes with a long sweet and sour aftertaste. Full body. Great!
Overheard: "And then Ill buy the heads separately."
(Bottle #002X2; w/ blankboy, HogTownHarry, jerc, tupalev)

(Batch 3 aged in bottle about a year) aroma- wild yeast, red grapes, blackberry, raspberry, oak, light alcohol, some vanilla.  pours a dark cherry red/brown with some head and lacing.  taste is tart cherries, grape, wild yeast, sugar, some alcohol.  The finish is very long with dry oak and fruity tartness lasting long after the sip.  palate is medium bodied with lively carbonation.  Very impressive!

5oz pour from a flight at Capones (batch 2).  Pour is shimmering maple syrup without head or lacing.  Nose is yeast, sour cherries, and currents.  Taste is Sour cherries, currents, and tart yeast.  Although sour beers I usually rate lower, this is actually the first one I could classify as delicious.  It seems a mastery of the style to hit it without having it come off in part as vinegar.

Batch #2 on tap at Capones Black Friday beer event, served in a snifter. Clear dark ruby with a thin ring of head. The nose is very sour with huge notes of wood,  fresh fruit, alcohol, and dried stone fruits. The flavor is much the same but somehow more intense with some cereal and vanilla. Sour, sour, sour. This beer is awesome!

Had the pleasure of trying this at Dark Lord Day 2009.

A: Dark red-amber color with an off-white head. Pretty good lacing.

S: A good sourness; not at all overpowering--more of an inviting scent. Behind that, sweet and tart fruits.

T: Excellent level of sourness. A lot of complexity in the flavor. Lots of tartness paired with some citrus and sweet fruits. 

M: Very nice. The perfect amount of sourness. Light mouthfeel. Good carbonation.

D: Definitely the most drinkable sour that I have had. Very complex, and also soothing on the palate.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-29-2009

375ml bottle from Pollack, brought to a tasting.  Cork made a loud pop with opened.  Amber pour with no head.  Lively carbonation throughout.  Aroma was of brett funk, big sour notes, no more of a light fruit presence, thought there would be more fruit.  Flavors were more distinguished, a tart sourness lasted throughout, more dry than fruity.  Nice.

Shared by Fred82. Merci Fred! (batch 4x2) Brownish red pour with a ring of white foam around my tulip. Aroma is actually quite mild for the style, currants, subtle (winey) oak and sour aromas. Taste is this beers strength, a well balanced  mixture of sweet fruity flavors of the currants and the lemony tartness. Some oak flavor as well but nothing overpowering. Palate is smooth with a nice dry tart finish, I can also get a bit of alcohol heat, which I understand now that Ive seen this beers ABV. Not something Im used to for the style but quite interesting.

2010-11-13. Dark brown body, with a small tan head that fades fast. 3 Interesting aroma has light alcohol character, sweet musty fruit and other fruity nuances that defy my description, red wine accents, hints at oak. 7+ Flavour is acidic up front, with a mild oak flavour that follows it up. Tart fruit, oak comes out more as it warms up, to its detriment in my opinion. Fruity notes, interesting melange of flavours. 7+ Smooth medium palate. Well made and interesting, but there is something about the combination of the oak and fruit character that would probably keep me from coming back. Bottle, Batch 002X2 from Belmont Station, Portland

Bottle; Pours a Dark Golden Brown into a tumbler - off white/beige head on the pour. This one has been sipped for a while - proving an excellent retention on this brew. Lacing in comparison to the supplication is modest - With that said - the aroma really blew me away. Straight from the bottle the currant element really stood out - you get the vinegar sour currant on the nose - everything about this brew seems perfect to me. It blends the oak barrels, currants, sour tartness, with a vanilla note on the backside. There is a warming element from the alcohol - I am just incredibly impressed -
On tap.  Dark copper color with a white head.  Acidic/sour aroma.  Complex flavor of sourness with grapes, plums, and oak.  Delicious!
On tap at the Bistro Barrel Aged Beer Festival.  Outstanding sour aroma, very tart.  Flavor follows.  Just a well-balanced sour.  Nice woody flavors come through as well.

Huge thanks to Dave for sharing this one! Bottle pours hazy deep amber with an off-white head.  Aroma is tart with notes of berries, apple, oak, and a touch of white vinegar.  Flavor shows the same. The berry sweetness plays nicely with the sharpness of the acidity and the spiciness of the oak.  Overall extremely well balanced, just not quite as much depth as some of their others.

Batch 004X4
Bottle pours a hazy amber with no head.  Aroma of dry red wine.  Flavor dominated by grapes, wine, and vinegar.  Very lively carbonation.  I was really disappointed with this ale.  Perhaps I had a bad bottle.  Expected more.
Nice dark color with with a very oakey nose. Has a nice sour cherry taste with hints of oak, raisins, and Vanilla. A world class beer.

Bottle. Clear, dark coppery red pour with a loose white head that doesnt last long. Nose is earthy, vinous and slightly funky with notes of berries, oak, grapes and dried fruit. Flavour is slightly lactic and quite sour, quite similar to aroma with added notes of apple, vinegar, lime and lemon. Dry, slick mouthfeel with moderate carbonation and a long dry, tart finish. Wonderfully balanced beer that is still challenging, the alcohol is hidden really well and the currants are noticeable but subtle. Very fine.

deep brown nearly mahogony wood color w/ some good visible carbonation and a small pure white head.  Huge fruity aroma, sour fruits that I thought smelled like sour cherries, with some sweetness in the back and a light earthy undertone.  Pretty avg pal, quite tart.  Flavor is well blended big tart some sour tangy almost grass mixed with leather then the lightly bitter fruits that I guess are currants.  A nice beer.

Big thanks to Dstruco for my first encounter with the great consecration. Im slowly getting deeper into the world of wild/sour beers and this one held a lot of qualities that I really liked. The aroma was pretty fruity and tart, hints of cherries and raspberries. Super sour taste, made me pucker quite a bit. Really enjoyable. Im sure the next time I try this one Ill be able to pick out a lot more flavor.

Bottle, 12C. Almost clear brooding reddish amber with beige head that retreats to the rim quickly. High bead. Gentle aroma of currants, lemon, cherry stones, earth. Fruity taste has cherries, lemon, pomegranate molasses, red wine vinegar - wouldnt pick currants in the mouth at all. Woody and dry. Modest but enduring sourness. You can feel alcohol, but I wouldnt have guessed 10%. Doesnt seem that vinous in the mouth, but theres a bit of very dry sparkling shiraz in a finish that has insistent lemon on the lips and wood on the roof of the mouth. Complex without being crowded. Has that enlivening "stick your head in a bucket of nature" quality. A very lovely beer.

One of the beers from the major trade with Eclectic. This one says Batch 001x3. Its pretty hard carbonated and goes of with a booom. Luckely we sat outside - otherwise we surely would have had some trouble with the ones living upstairs. The pour leaves brown-redish body with a thin off white head. The nose has lots of berries, and especially something that reminds me of blue grapes stands out. There are wooden notes and hints of redwine, cinamon and "dark" fruits. Some figs, plumps and a clear presens of alcohol finish the aroma. Pretty complex for a sour. In the taste the taste of red wine stands out pretty clear. Together with the wood the redwine gives a nice sourness and a long lasting sourish finish. In the taste you fine some sweet notes aswell like from winegums. The mouthfeel is medium with a faint buttery touch. On top of that it has a violent sparkling attitude that makes this a impressive and nice sour that are very drinkable and could go brilliant as an apperatif. I really like the wine-thing that is going on in this beer. Cheers

Pours a very deep red brown color with fizzy soda-like head which instantly vanishes.  Aroma of black currants, raspberry, red wine, oak, soft cherry and a framboise lambic aspect.  Has my mouth watering, Ill admit.  Flavor is an initial tart bite, heavy on carbonation, which then releases a cascade of complexity and different flavors, resulting in a very long finish.  %10 completely hidden and a couple sips of this beer go a long way fast.  Its really good but I dont think I could drink more than 1 or 2, every now and then it might hit the spot though.

Tap @ East Side Club Tavern (early 2010 brewing). Clear, dark amber pour with minimal head and no lace. Sour from start to finish, but there is an underlying sweetness that builds towards the finish. Grape, lemon and currents; ABV is transparent. Medium body with light carbonation. Lovely!

Picked up at Olive Tree Marketplace while in San Diego.  Red brown pour .  Minimal head.  Sour grape, berry, and oak notes.  Puckering sour mouthfeel.  Fairly simple flavors, but they are intense.  The sour style in general is not my favorite, but this is definitely interesting and pretty good.  Could not finish more than one of these.

On tap at sf tornado (09 I believe) and a 375 bottle. Bottle has a weird rum like character that the tap version didnt have. Pretty similar though, but tap was a little better-about a 4.1 as opposed to 3.8 ish for the bottle. Moderately sour.

On tap.  Pours a dark reddish amber with a small tan head leaving very little lacing on the glass.  Aroma is light tartness, wine, oak, and very light alcohol.  Initial taste is sweet, followed by a lemon zest, red wine, grapes, and some oak coming through on the finish.  Light-medium body body.  Medium carbonation feels perfect on the tongue.  Fantastic beer.
Reddish brown and dark. Smells strong of the bretts and currents. Really really sour. medium body, little coronation, Finishes on the back of the tongue with lingering sourness
No aroma. Clear brown, thin fizzy head. Powerfully sour, all black currant. Fizzy mouthfeel. Tasty and sour yes, but completely lacks character. Boooo

Pour is opaque amber with a small yet big bubbled and fast fading light brown head...smell is strongly fruity and sweet with some dry leathery brett notes with musty currants...taste is slightly sweet up front quickly turning crazily and abrasively sour...currants, dates, brett...then some strong sweetness with alcohol coming through...I mean this is jaw clenchingly sour...seems thin somehow and not really well balanced...I mean this is a tremendous beer but just isnt their best showing...
Bottle.  Batch 004X5.  A reddish brown color with an off white head.  A wonderfully sour dark fruit aroma.  A rich and delightful mouthful of sour goodness.

August maroon color with a nice tanned head, with fine bubbles, that quickly thins, but still stretches across the top.

Wonderfully complex bouquet with oaked cabernet tones and light fruitiness amidst the sweet tart pungence. No detectable vanillins.

Easy sour tart body. Much more subdued than other sour beers and with the appealing complexity-adding nuances of oak, cabernet, and delicate, well-blended fruitness. Horse-hair and barny sour touch on the finish--but all in proper balance.

Im not generally an appreciator of the style, but I enjoyed this.

Draft at the brewery. Really looked forward to trying this and it didnt disappoint. On my palate, only eclipsed by the Temptation. Good job of avoiding being a one-dimensional sour by maintaining some barrel and fruit notes.

Poured at Monks for the RR dinner to end Philly Beer Week, this beer smells a bit sweet with notes of berries, currants, and subtle vinegar. The color is dark ruby amber with almost no head. The flavor of the currants on top of the sour and vinegar notes is a delicious blend. It went perfect with the pickled cherries allowing the flavors to flow on the palate.

Bottle. [thank you, after4ever]
batch 01
Pours a lovely clear deep red with a small, frothy, off-white head. Aroma is sweet, fruity, raisins, bourgogne, light chocolate, tart and mild viniousness, red wine. Really lovely. Highish mild carbonation, dry and light grainy palate. Flavour is just world-class, red wine, blue grapes, roasted and chocolate malty goodness, light vinious, plums, oak, dry and elegant. Stunningly well-balanced and composed.

~12 oz bottle courtesy of Josh.  Deep amber color, little to no head.  Aroma is (obviously) sour with some notes of fruit.  Super tart, puckery flavor with a bit of an awesome fruity finish... Im not too familiar with currant but Im guessing thats the flavor I got.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2017 "Wow...just wow. Chef Chad had encouraged me to drink as much of this as i could, and now is see why. This ruby colored brew had an aroma near perfection. tart fruit, with perfectly balanced sweetness. Comparable only to Liefmans Goudeband, but better in every aspect than any other RR sour, including the $25 Beatification I had a few weeks ago. The flavor was less sour than La Folie, Rodenbach, or other RR sours, but was definitely enought to stand up and take notice. Sour cherry, deep dark fruits. Great body too. They couldnt tell me why the goblets were $6 but the 750 bottles were $25!! Come on...more than twice as much per ounce in a bottle? Isnt it usually the other way around? So as much as i liked this beer, I have a huge stash at home and couldnt justify the price. A prime example of gouging here...but a frikkin awesome beer either way!"

Funk, oak, and cabernet notes.  I love the way the critters make the carbonation play.  Very champagne-like only a little more random.  The oak has a lasting but not overpowering flavor that lightly coats the tongue, while the cabernet, currants, tart, and slight tannin tastes play.  The dryness of the beer help all of these elements to pop on the palate and make me a happy man.  I cant wait until my next bottle.

Bouteille de 750 ml, batch 002x2. Arômes incroyables de fruits rouges sûrs, de tanins de chêne et de levures sauvages. Robe mauve et trouble, effervescence active et légère mousse. Ce qui impressionne chez cette bière est son côté fruité très frais,  qui se manifeste comme une explosion de groseilles bien sûres. Le fût de chêne, très vineux, est également bien présent. Une touche dacide acétique, à peine perceptible, donne un peu de mordant. Finale sèche et bien franche, à la fois lactique et citrique (les fruits ?). Un grand cru !
Saved this for a year before opening.  Pours reddish brown.  Slight funk aromas, currant and wood.  Big sour currant flavors.  Overall a very drinkable 10% ABV which is well hidden.  Very tasty!

Bottle of Batch 001 x 1. Pours cinnamon stick brown-red with moderate fizzy beige head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is full of strawberry and sour cherry complemented by subtle notes of brown sugar and prunes. Flavor is first and foremost delightfully tart fruit (strawberry, lemon, sour cherry), followed by sweet caramel, dark fruit, oak, and dry hoppiness. The tartness definitely lingers but ultimately takes a backseat to dry bitter hops, oak, and prune juice. Heavy on the carbonation; prickly mouthfeel. A fun and delicious beer with lots of high-quality flavors. If this is past its prime, I cant wait to try a fresher version!

Deep mahogany color with an off-white head that fades to a nice ring. Fruity aroma, mainly cherry, that is sour and tart. Resembles wine on the nose. Similar tart taste. Has some barrel-aged qualities. Quite delicious.

375ml.  Pours a reddish copper with almost no head.  Although there was no head, there was a fair amount of fizz present.  Nose is strictly stongly sharp and potent acidity.  Palate is consisting of dark berries, funk, and abrasive tartness. All of which culminates into a looooong, tart finish that sits in after a few moments. Awesome.

On tap. deep dark red in color. First taste was a blast of sour cherry. Carbonation was a bit odd, kind of like a mellow champagne. citrus, lemon. This beer was just amazing as it warmed there was flavors of oak, rum, brandy. This beer is a real treat for the taste buds, sensations of all types. A slightly sour finish. My wife even liked this one and she hates beer!

750 ml bottle from South Bay Drugs.  Batch 004x2.  Pours a deep reddish-orange-brown color with a small off-white head that dissipates, although there is some visible carbonation throughout.  Aroma of sour lemon, tart cherries and other dark fruits (must be the currants), oak, vanilla, and some funk.  Flavor of tart cherries and currants, sour lemon, tart apples, oak, vanilla, funk, and a hint of vinegar.  Hard to believe this is 10% ABV because its nowhere to be found.  Medium-bodied, with a sour mouthfeel and mellow carbonation.  Complex, well-balanced, interesting, a downright awesome beer.

750ml bottle from doubleo. Pours hazy brown with reddish tints and tan head. Aromas of cherries, funk, acidic notes, bread, and dark fruits. Flavors of sour cherries, funk, acidity, dark fruits, and a ton sour tartness. Finishes sour and leaves you smacking your lips. Should of had this one 6 months ago, but it is still a damn good sour.

(Bottle) Pours muddy, dark brown with ripe cherry-red highlight. The aroma is red wine fruity and bretty up front. Tones of mould, wet oak, dust, horse blanket, light butter, cherries, raspberry vinegar, green house, mould cheese, bitter almond, light red currant, medicine and pecan and fudge ice cream. Quite full malt profile. Very bretty, everything is else secondary on the nose. The flavour is dry, medium to heavily acidic and almost no bitterness. Super bretty and lacto aggressive, almost numbing. Mould, wood, berries, tart juice, horse blanket and earth. The mouthfeel is tart, dusty and medium carbonated. Super citric, tart dryish and bretty finish. Medium bodied. Aggressive yet complex.
For me Consecration was a one dimensional Sour Ale.   Medium bodied, flat as a board ale with a sourness I could not shake.

Bottle thanks to Owen. Pours a very hazy dark brown with some reddish tints. Decent coffee coloured head which provides some lacing as it falls away. The aromas are super complex. Initially all i really get is a big whack of sourness, perhaps some stone fruit and a little funk. But after a while the wood seems to come and i pick up butter scotch and a little vanilla. Mmm great stuff. Flavour wise it basically is all just about the sourness. Light blasamic I guess.Still it is not over poweringly tart. Struggle to pick up much else but brilliant all the same. Finish is very dry thanks to the acidity and also the lively mouthfeel. Great beer.

From a 375mL bottle.  Pours brownish orange.  Looks like ice tea or cola due to the carbonation.  Has a sodalike fizz sound due to bubbles rising to the surface.  Sharp sour and acidic nose.  Slight citrus fruit aroma, too.  Taste is similar with a very sour flavor.  Also some slight fruit there.  Very good.

Batch 003X3. Served from bottle into a Duvel tulip. Pours a deep reddish brown with a two finger off white head that subsides to one quickly. Lots of carbonation rising to the top and makes a fizzing like a soda. Maintains decent lacing throughout. The aroma is comprised of yeast, bread, sour apple, and grapes. The flavor is of sour apple, grapes, very subtle alcohol, and citrus. It has a light feel on the palate with high carbonation. Overall this was the first Wild Ale I had tried back at a tasting and it got me interested in the style. This is a very nice blend of flavors all in one package that makes my taste buds jump for joy after every sip. If you have not tried any Wild Ales, this might be a good place to start.
Oak wood overwhelms sour. Dark bowman with no head.  Long lasting sour that does not go away.

At the brewery.  Pours dark amber.  Definitely the most intriguing offering of all 11 tasters.  This is my first sour ale and I had no idea what to expect.  Tastes like a tart cherry bourbon, like sour whiskey with some vinegar, all the flavor without the cloying sweetness of whiskey.  I decided that I really like it.  In fact, I was still thinking about it later and considered swinging back for a full glass.  I have nothing else to compare it to, but it certainly left a strong impression and was delicious.
On tap at monks cafe in Philly.  Poured in a tulip.  Beer pours a dark ruby.  Taste is ultra cran/cherry with a touch of vinegar.   Very robust a full bodied... Without a doubt best in class.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2012 750mL Bottle. Batch 001X2. Wow. Just wow. Amazing nose of strawberry jam, dry red wine, black currant juice, and vinous character. Pours a strikingly clear browned ruby red, with a nice tanned slick head. It has really incredible flavor complexity thats inline with good red wines, a touch of spicy, dry leather, some fig-like dark fruits, and smooth-well-integrated alcohols. This is so graceful. Even the sourness is gentle, soft, elegant and complexit, with piquant sharpness that adds fun to the beer, but doesnt get overly harsh or brash. It elicits a thought of tart, acidic port, without the sugary heaviness and with the complexity and the rich fruit-flavored profile. Amazingly delicious. 9/5/9/5/18


330mL Bottle. Batch 004x2. Either my tastes have really change, or this beer thas become a lot more uninteresting. I do remember being really enamored with the vinous complexity of this beer, but now it just seems like a singular white grapefruit juice bomb with some dried currants added. Warmer and with more tobacco. Its good, up there with a number of Russian River sours, but its not mind boggling. I almost want a bit more body and definitely some more funky complexity. 8/4/8/4/17

(375ml bottle).  Pours copper color with small off-white head. Aroma of funk and fruit.  Taste is sour with some sweetness.  Somewhat light-bodied with thin texture.  Finish is sour, but currants balance the beer nicely.  Alcohol is making its presence known as it warms the throat and chest.

Bottle of batch 1 from brewolf...thanks Michael! - Pours cola colored and a light tan bubbly head. Almost smells bourbon aged, with caramel notes, red wine, and light sour notes. Not what I was expecting. Real dry in the mouth, lots of red wine and tannic notes. Dark berries and caramel, with tons of dark fruit and vinous notes. Damn. This is really complex, but it makes me want to try this fresh.

Had on tap at Monks Cafe

A-pours a flat looking reddish copper color that is quite clear and has virtually no head.

S-the nose is very big, lots of vinous red wine characteristics with a faint earthy tone to it.  very little oak with the sweet currant in the back.  just a hint of acidity in the back but light.

T-nicely balance, sweet red wine, dark red grapes, nice sourness to it, hints of oak underneath.  tart cherries and currants add sweetness to it with a light spice in the back.

M-this has a smooth and medium body with huge carbonation and a crisp dry finish.  very nice feel to it!

D-awesome beer, great vinous characteristics with a light barrel aging and great balance of sweetness to sour.  the spice adds some kick and this is a beautiful very wine like brew.

Deep reddish brown with almost no head.  Aroma is sharply tart and a bit band-aidy with a concentrated berry note.  Taste is the same, and I salivate even to recall it.  Tart in the extreme with cutting acidity and an an underlying graham cracker sweetness throughout, and even into the finish.  Hard to drink, but plainly excellent.  Alcohol is barely evident beneath it all.  $8/12oz

Poured a dark amber - almost ruby red with minimal head and very little lacing.  Beer was extremely aromatic and immediately noticeable once the cork was removed.  Smells of a yeasty cabernet, wild cherries, roasty malts and oak filled the room!!  Those aroma characteristics were consistent with the flavor of the brew, some mild tartiness and yeasy flavors - a medium to heavy body, creamy texture and light carbonation ... very interesting.  Not one I would continue to pursue due to personal tastes - but a very interesting and fun to sample beer!!

375mL batch 004X5 pours dark amber small bubbly head disappears quickly. Aroma is sour and sweet fruits, cherries. Sour tart wraps around the tongue like a tight blanket followed up by oak notes, herbs, Cabernet. No alcohol taste amazing. Extremely well crafted, loved it.

Bottle from PeteinSD 
Hell yeah, finally get to try a sour from Russian River.  I dont have a ton of experience with sours, but if I can get my hands on more of this caliber, I might gain alot more interest in them.  Its a vibrant ruby red in color with a foamy white head.  Aroma is a fruity tartness with funk and a bit of vinegar mixed in as well.  Flavor is intense, strong fruit dominated by tart sourness and yeast. Palate is full with lively carbonation. Cant wait to try more of these.

This beer pours a nice deep amber/red color.  The aroma is a tarty fruit with a little bit of funk.  This beer has an amazing taste to it.  It has a sweet and tarty fruit taste to it.  I think its more tart than sour and I could easily drink a whole 750 bottle to myself.

Pours a dark amber, very little head.  Aroma: Oak, Cherries, sour, sweetness.  Taste: very sour currants/cherries/plums.  very complex and oakey.  Finish is very sour and leaves my mouth watering for more.  Best sour Ive had and for a 10% brew i could drink this all night.

What the...?!  I was going to age this a few months longer, but it just new blew the caged cork with a loud bang that scared the crap out of me! thats never happened to me.  Guess its a sign that I should rate this.  Ive had it on tap a couple times, but this rating is based on a 375 ml bottle (batch #4) from Holiday Wine Cellar ($11.99).  Pours a lovely deep red, almost brown.  Obviously, the carbonation is downright explosive but escapes so quickly as to not really leave a head -- actually, its almost like cola.  Aroma is complex and lovely with notes of fine wine, fruit (cherry and grape), wood, funk, and vinegar.  Flavor is similarly complex with many of the same elements: rich dry red wine, grape, wood, vinegar.  Its certainly sour, but not in an inaccessibly astringent kind of way.  The flavor is also not as funky as I might have thought considering that the bottle indicates four different strains of bacteria.  Quite dry finish which must be derived from the tannins in the barrel.  Really good stuff and this transcends what "beer" is and can be.  Of course, it possibly would have been better if the bottle had been chilled before the top shot off!  (530. 339)

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Batch 3 on draft at Local 44s Russian River Philly Beer Week Event

A: Rich mahogany color body with a shimmering silkiness to it... solid khaki colored head, which receded to a nice cap which last throughout... some lacing lingers

S: Sweet, sour, tart. Its all there... Dried red fuits (think plums, grapes, various berries)... sour cherries... earthy leathery brett goodness

T: Cherries are the overwhelming characteristic. Nice sour and tart combinations of the fruits. Clearly aged in cabernet, there is a strong dense tannic characteristics and even a hint of pepper. Brett and bacteria are clearly present in a hearty but refined showing.

M: Almost like a sparkling juice that has sat out for an hour. Still some carbonation, but not out of control.

O: Up there with supplication as the best, relatively easy to find sours.

Picked up a bottle from Sid at Best Damn Beer Shop in downtown San Diego.  Poured a dark orangey brown color with off-white head.  Smelled sweet like wine thats left out when you dont want to clean up the night of the party.  Sweet at first, becoming intensely sour.  Flavors of apple cider vinegar and warm red wine.  Indicia left at the bottom of the glass, and lingering tartness on the tongue.  Quite an experience, and Id do it again.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2013 Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy amber with an orange-white head. The strong sour aroma holds notes of tart fruits and berries, as well as wood and light funk. Flavor is immediately sweet but then becomes quite sour with bright fruitiness. Light to medium in body with fine, fizzy carbonation. Finishes with a long sour note and heavy dryness. Very, very good. (4.3)Update: Had some Batch 4. Pours a mostly clear, maroon-brown with a faint head. Sweet aroma with tart fruits and brett. Flavor is sweet with grape, currant and other berries, and quite sour. Medium in body with fine, tingly carbonation. Finish is dry and lip-puckering. Again, very good. (4.2)Update: Batch 3 at The Funky 7. Great stuff. Gave it a 4.4.Bottle aged four years shared at Craft Beer Co. Clerkenwell - London. Pours lightly hazy amber with a fine, off-white cream head. Sourness comes through well in the nose, some sweat and meat, prunes. Big tart flavor, raisins and currants, light licorice, light to medium sweetness, other sour berries, light acidic burn. Light to medium bodied with fine, massaging carbonation. Balanced tart berries to finish, ripe fruit sugars, good tartness, faint licorice and brown sugar. Lingering tart berries. Well rounded. Great beer. (4.3)

Im giving this beer a perfect score. 

I was lucky enough to have found a bottle for sale at the Canal St Pub in Reading PA. It was a 12oz bottle for $18.  I wanted to buy 2, but they only had 1 left.

Everything about this beer was neat.

The aroma was a sour/malty red wine smell. I know that doesnt really go together, but somehow it worked for this beer. 

Appearance : Reddish/Brown Amberish in Color.

Taste : My friend said it best "its almost like a warhead how sour it is". Its really sour, with a great red wine taste and a dry finish.

Overall : This is THE beer to get for sour ale fans. Its the most accessible of the Top 10 and its fantastic.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2014 Bottle split with bigmmartin, thanks, Mike.  Aroma is sour fruit, sweet malts, and a bit of red wine.  Notes of currants (go figure), yeast, and dark fruits come out. Palate is sour, biting a little hard.  Flavor brings out the red wine and it finshes dry, leaving a nice sweet aftertaste.  Pretty damn good, best sour ale I have had.

Wow.  On tap. Light ruby with a whisper of fizzy foam. Aromas are off the chart with cherry, apple a brandyish whisper and constantly evolving scents that kept me thinking.  The flavor is a shock to the palate with its mouthfeel and dizzying complexity.  Berry, champagne, apple, peach whispers grassy musty barnyard clusters of cherry. Wonderful finish with warmth and flavor on the exhale.  Wow.  Top notch.

This stuff is really really cool.  A sour ale and almost tastes like a sparking red sour wine, if that made any sense.

More carbonated that most beers I like, this has a flavor of sour and a lot of grape.

Im doing a terrible job describing it, because I have to experience with sours...just go try it!

Bottled. Dark amber coloured. Unclear. Dense dark beige head. Aroma of sourness, spice, grape, brett, lacto. Yummy. Flavour is extremely sour. Grape, wood, spice, earth, brett and some barnyard. Delicious. Full bodied. Dry earthy sourness in the end. This is a gem. Thx. snojerk321 for this.

Snuck this into a wedding so that  the groom could get a change from the Miller Lite. Jowl juicing tart cherry aroma , a little wine like, taste was the very tart/sour pleasing fruit flavor ,could be any number of fruits, and I agree,that tartness adjusted in your mouth in the swallow. Everyone who tried it loved it,a sour even the BMC crowd was impressed with

On draft at TJs Everyday.  Poured deep ruby with minimal carbonation.  Nose of sweet, sour cherries.  Loads of deep, dark fruits evident.  Tons of black cherry flavor as well.  Started with an extreme tongue stripping tartness that lessened as the palate adjusted.  Medium bodied.  Remarkably complex.  Worth a try even if sours arent your thing.

(750ml Bottle - Batch 001x1) Pours a dark amber color with an off white head. Smell is sour, funk, brown sugar, raisins, vanilla, and oak. Taste is sour cherries, brown sugar, dark fruits, funk, and oak. Medium mouthfeel, medium carbonation. Overall this is another great sour from Russian River.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2011 I had this as part of the 16 beer sampler (enjoyed with my future wife..couldnt do it all alone). I just recently became a fan of sour ales, and this one was pretty good, even if it went horribly with the jalapeno and sausage pizza we ordered.  To me, this smelled like bourbon, kind of reminded me of Early Times.  This was very very sour, had a bourbon appearance, which threw me off as Ive never had a Belgian sour that tasted like whiskey.  It couldve been the black currants, who knows, but thats what I got from it.

OK...re-rating as I had this at Dark Lord Day at 3 Floyds in Munster, IN...a friends co-worker was passing around a bottle of this for people to try.  This really is incredible stuff and I couldnt imagine a better sour ale.  Appearance a coffee like brown with rich off white head, copperish as well.  Aroma sour,vinegar, stinky cheese, very potent, very nice.  Taste sour cherries, stinky cheese, ridiculousness, vinegar, an acquired taste but Im happy with it.  DLD FTW.

0.375l - Color of a cinnamon stick, fizzy in appearance.  Nor real head (the only disappointment).  The nose was sour cherries.  Palate was sourness, Brettanomyces yeast then cherries with a smooth sliding finish.
A slight more mellower taste than most sours I have tried. I can also taste raisins in it. Had on tap at Lucky Baldwins. One of my favorite sours.

Bottle bought take-out at Russian River.  Pours copper-red with minimal head.  One smell and you know youre in for a uniquely well crafted sour ale.  This is the kind of beer that could bring a life-long wine drinker into the craft beer fold.  Staying power the of tart, sour finish is memorable.  Easily in my top 10.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2010 Thanks to hophead101 for sending me this bottle. 

Batch 001x1, sampled June 19, 2010. 

The beer pours a clear dark red color with a white head. The aroma is awesome. I get lots of brown sugar, oak, vanilla and a low amount of tartness. The flavor is brown sugar, medium tartness, dark fruits, vanilla and oak. Medium carbonation and medium mouthfeel. This beer matured into a wonderful drink. It was tried alongside Sanctification, Temptation, Supplication and Beatification and I think this beer was easily the star of the show.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2014 batch 002X2  This bad boy was a gusher.  This reddish brown sour patch kid is definitely an acquired taste.  A huge mouth puckering sour taste overrun with tart fruit, cherry, currant, vinegar, and cheap cabernet sauvignon.  It finishes off with a little burn.  Might be best out of one of those titty sip cups with the nipple drink hole.  Its is Rodenbach done Cali style.  It does get a little better with each sip...
Just tried batch four which deserves a re-rating.  Not nearly as sour, with big black currant flavors.  Wow, what a difference.....
Batch 2 is drinking fan-freakin-tastic right now.....
Batch 1 consumed 5/14.  Unbelievable....

Bottle. Batch 001x3.

Reddish brown with a medium-sized tanned/off-white head that leaves a lot of lacings. 

The aroma is malty with a noticeable funky and lactic character. Notes of wet wood, mud, grass and tart fruit. A herbal note as well, perhaps anise. 

The flavor is full with a nice malty foundation and tart fruit notes. Lovely tart currant flavors coupled with grass. Overall, the flavor development is really pleasant and integrated. The finish is very very dry considering the ABV, and has a light bitterness to it beneath a sour fruitiness. 

Full-bodied and smooth with a semi-sticky mouthfeel. 

This is a very impressive beer. Considerably sour and no sign of the alcohol, almost hard to believe its 10%. Good craftsmanship.

Consecration #9, on draft at Toronado, SF.

Winey, vinegary, sourish nose.  Reminscent of Rodenchbach.  Taste: HOLY SNIKES!  Explosively huge flavors of oak, cherry, vanilla, vinegar.  Eye-wateringly sour, yet remarkably delicious.  This beer has twice the flavor of Rodenbach, itself a magnificent beer that overwhelms most of the uninitiated.  Lingering, strong aftertaste.  Had to immediately order another glass.  Definitely one of the ten best beers Ive had.

This is the best sour ever! From that first smell and sip pucker to the sweet mouth feel and the lingering bitter and sour taste left in your mouth this beer is great! It left a nice lace on our glasses and a longer for more in our mouths. The aroma alone is enough to make you fall in love with sours. It has the perfect balance of sweet Belgium yeast sour candy and and bitter hops. Thank you Tim and Rachel for sharing this with me
Bottle.Pours a deep dark red with a fizzy reddish white head.Nose is cherry and candy.Taste is super sour cherry with a distinct wood aspect.Palate is flawless.Stupid awesome killer beer.

Caged and corked bottle (thanks to thebeergeek.com).   A dark pour, with a relatively quick fizzle of a head.  The aroma is wickedly sour -- my mouth is already puckering.  And indeed, this is a brutally sour beer ... the strong cherry character literally sucking the moisture from the sides of my mouth.  Despite the giant sour character, which would put off most casual drinkers, this is actually quite drinkable.  (#3921, 6/13/2010)

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Very nice aroma. But in the flavour the sourness and alcohol do note compete. The wood and cherry is nice though. Nice experiment but should be balanced.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2013 Bottle. Batch 1 x 3. Differing finishing yeast than the current iteration. Poursw a dark rust colored brown that starts with a nice head that quickly dissapates. Funky sour aroma with hints of fruit and a slight oakiness. The initial taste is not quite as sour as I would have expected but still havs some sourness notes. Im told new bottles are more sour than this batch. Slight sweet taste followed by funk then sour. 
Re-rate: Had the opportunity to sample a newer bottle and in my opinion it was a touch better than the Batch 1 with more sour/tart flavors. Just an outstanding beer. Re-re-rate: Batch 3 with T20 and T25 side by side. Sweeter than I remember it being but still enjoyable.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2010 Had via Jamess generosity. Pour is a maroon body with absolutely no head or lacing. Not too thick and syrupy. Aroma is tart berries and some alcohol. Flavor is smooth and full of raspberries and other sour tartness.  Nice brew indeed

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2010 12oz bottle in a Tulip glass.  Pours dark ruby-brown, almost opaque, with a thin beige head.  Aroma of oak, dark fruits, and slight notes of dough and grass.  Very complex flavor.  Initially the dark fruits, the sourness, and the high carbonation are noted, but the sourness becomes strong toward the back of the palate.  The finish has a lingering dark fruit, alcohol, and the sour taste.  A great sour ale, and a perfect 100th beer.

Tap @ Falling Rock Taphouse, Denver. Bright red with a light brown hue, tiny off white head that quickly vanished. Aroma is very, very tart and sour, lots of funky yeast and barrel scents with some cranberry, cherry and oak. Flavor is all sour, the first sips puckers you up really good, as you drink it the sourness isnt quite as sharp but still very sour. Medium body with active carbonation and a sharp dry finish. The alcohol is no where to be found in this one. Excellent sour beer.

Dark mahogany, no head. Aroma is dominated by dark sour fruits and acetone. Sour grapes, figs, and sour cherry up front in flavor. Fades to oak dryness through the finish. Slick and oily mouthfeel. Have had better bottles in the past. Will rerate accordingly.

pours a nice ruby color...slightly brown with a quickly dissipating lt. tan head but returns quickly with agitation.  aroma is definitely sour with a hint of leather and wine...also a subtle sweetness and not vinegary.  flavor has very nice sour qualities...hint of sour cherry, leather, funk, and a touch of oak.  no alcohol flavors at all...hard to notice it is 10%.  mouthefeel is slightly lively and light with a dry and sour oaky finish.  not my favorite style usually but this is defintely making me want to try more!

Had from 750ml bottle.  Pours dark red/brown with tan head that dissipates very quickly and some slight blubbles on the edges.  Aroma is very tart, sour, citric, hints of cherries, yeast, and alcohol.  Taste is amazingly tart, refreshing, citric, and complex.  Flavors range from oak to cherries to currants to lemons.  Really a treat to have and a wonderfully complicated beer that might require some time to get used to if youre not a fan of the sours.  This sour goes above and beyond the slightly acidic and citric tastes of other "weaker" sours and really punches your tastebuds with flavor.  More sour than I remember it on tap, but still an amazingly good beer.
Pours a dark muddy purple brown color with white head. Nose is mixed berries, currants and dark fruits. Taste is blackberry, currants and dark fruit. Medium tartness. Pleasant and well balanced brew.

Almost no head, just around the edge of the glass. Dark rich reddish body with a buttery red wine aroma. First sip was like sweet tarts on steroids with a lingering dry sweet finish. Second sip a littler more mellow.  My tongue is coated and happy!

375ml bottle (004X5) from City Beer in SF 
Appearance: Pours clear dark copper/amber with a small off-white head that recedes to just a small ring in the glass, no lacing 
Aroma: Tart dark fruits, peppery & dry wine 
Taste: Tart fruits, some sweet malts. Finishes off with a nice tart fruits with a dry wine finish 
Very nice Sour, probably the best Ive had.

nice ruby pour with off white head.  Smell of aged vinegar, slight cherry and tobacco.  The wood, brett  and musk are very real and become more evident upon warming.  The fruit taste is complex - blackberry, cherrry, apple and this along with the perfect sourness makes for a pleasant and unusual taste - simply great.  becoming my favorite- no actually is aleady there - just keeps making me happy.  could not distringuish b/t batches 1, 2 or 3.  RR is top rate.

Batch 4.  Pours a deep amber brown color with a medium off white foam head.  Has an aroma of vinegar and cherry.  Has a sour, tart taste with hints of cherry, some grapes as well.  Very excellent sour brew.  I have been very impressed with this brewery.  Ready to move to Cali and hang with Vinne.  Just good stuff.

From a 12.7oz,batch 004x3 Its one of those Flavors i dont necessarily like but damn this is great Dark fruit note beer,no head,super dark red,I can taste the wine or Cabernet Sauvignon and it goes well with this beer for it being  currantsGreat flavor for a dark fruit sour

750ml bottle purchased at liquidsolutions

Appearance: Nicy ruby to garnet body with a lovely silky frothy light mocha crown that pours large. Lots of retention and lacing with a silky slightly oily sheen!

Smell: This is one of the most intoxicating olfactory pleasures Ive ever had. Im really having a strong positive reaction to the nose. Nice amount of barnyard plus additional aromatics from the wild yeast come together with currants and other dark fruits. Nice oak notes dominate and create a wonderful musk. Leather and a light cigar note really round it out. Highbrow all the way.

Taste: First of the sourness is so well crafted. I cant believe Im about to describe "sourness" as "velvety" but that is what I just did. The sourness is velvety smooth and lush. Im getting a lemon/grape citric type note but I think that is coming from the wine barrel usage. The black currant mixes well and I feel like Im getting other notes of black cherry.

Mouthfeel: Very lush and extremely carbonated.

Drinkability: I think this one will give me heartburn by the time Im done but its damn tasty so its going down fast. :)

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-13-2009

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2010 My Bottom Line:
This accomplished Sour Ale astonishes through its suave complexities, with flavors ranging from coniferous brettanomyces, black currants, red wine, lemons, raisins and balsamic vinegar. This one has many things to say, and all of its ideas are harmonious.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A ring of foam circles the reddish marroon.
-The black currant fruitiness and well developed chocolatey malts are a wonderful match.
-The finish is an agile blend of sourness, dry brett wilderness and lingering juicy fruit.
-The mouthfeel is lush and effervescent. Its hard to believe this is 10% abv.

From bottles and from the tap at the brewpub and at Toronado SF.

bottle thanks to Zathrus!  Pours dark brown with a lively light tan head that quickly dissipates.  Aroma is light red wine vinegar and tart cherry with the currents coming on strong as it warms and breathes.  There are light barrel elements in the aroma as well.  Wet wood and some tobacco and earthy leaf and herbs.  Flavor is  a mellow sweet brown ale up front, lots of bready malts and light notes of sweet red wine but the finish is where the magic of the tart currants and barrel do their magic.  Lots of tart fruit and dry wine.  This is a special beer.
Bottle @ UDRM. The aroma is vinous, has wood, fruits. Amber, brown coloured beer with a thin head. The taste is sour, little sweet, citric, some darker fruits, some tartness, wood. Average.

375 bottle from South Bay Drugs (Batch 004X2 bottled February 3, 2010).  Deep reddish-orange pour with a champagne-like effervesence.  Obviously sour aroma of lemon and dark fruit but without the usual, sometimes off-putting, funky cider vinegar often associated with sours.  Very sour flavor of dark berries, apple, and lemon and this time the cider vinegar does make its way through along with a hint of oak.  The alcohol is almost invisible in this beer totally masked by the sourness.  No doubt this is a sour beer but the flavors are well-balanced with nothing too funky that gets in the way.  You would be hard-pressed to find many sour beers that are better than this one.  Another outstanding sour beer from Russian River.

Pours rusty-amber with a thin, active head. Has a nose of prunes, cranberry, red wine vinegar, and a hint of vanilla. Taste of lemon, booze, tart blackberry, and some oak. There is a distinct lack of barnyard here as compared with several others in the category. A very nice brew indeed!

Pours a deep cherry with a beige head.  Aroma is of funk, cherries, oak and vanilla.  Taste is tart that is moderated by the oak and vanilla that lends some sweetness.  Finish is bitter and dry.  Exceptional brew.
On Tap at Toronado - poured with slight off white head.  Tart aroma of cherries and oak.  Very nice tart flavor, cherries, citric acid, and faint wine.  Very little alcohol taste, too drinkable.

Believe this is batch 2, will have to double check with the bottle in the cellar if its listed.  Pours a murkyish light brown merging with maroon color.  Nose is sour off the bat, big time acidic funkiness going on.  Flavor full of fruit, oak, heavy cherry presence, some wine notes.  On the sweet side, but overall quite complex and very tasty.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2011 Bottle split with pat from Teresas. Pours an interesting body. Dark, dark red body that pours one finger, carbonated white head that evaporates instantly.  Aroma is delicious sour cherries, vanilla, and tart. Mouthfeel is full, silky, sticky with syrupy flavors of cherry, sourness, tart, grapes, and vanilla.

bottle, batch 01x03, ruby brown color with nice tan foam ring as it settles, aromas of woody currants, blackberries, vinegar,  flavor is sour and dusty with jammy fruit flavors, some horse blanket, finish is fruity sour

Bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Deep orange-red-brown murky body with dark sediment, effervescent carbonation that oddly developed a thin head halfway through the glass. Sharp, sour, lactic, acidic nose, biting, with lemon and tart dark fruits, peaches, floral elements, and dusty oak. Sour, funky body with vinaigrette and currants, almost lemony, somewhat cut by dry oak notes. Good complexity. Very nice sour ale.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2010 Ive had the benefit of enjoying this beer in bottle and on tap multiple times so it seemed appropriate to update my review.

On tap at PP Solana Beach.  Dark, polished copper brown/red in the glass.  Minimal head with steady carbonation.  Aroma is deep tart/sour with currants and trailing lemon.  Taste is a burst of sweet fruit up front with some hidden malt and alcohol followed by lemon and sharp, juicy fruit.  Like a classic gueuze the beer presents different flavors and perspectives on those flavors with each sip.  I love this beer.

Rating #250.  Pretty excited to have found this in a 375ml bottle.  Pours like a mix between ice tea, cola, and honey.  Lots of fizz to a white foam head that is short-lived.  Aroma is faintly and pleasantly sour, with just a touch of tartness, cherries, sour apples, etc.  First taste is a-w-e-s-o-m-e!  An explosion of cherry tartness on the tongue, that builds to a crescendo, then flattens out pleasantly to a smooth finish.  Really, wonderful stuff.  Not overly complex, but thats in its favor here, as it seems to only be trying to be good at being an awesomely sour beer.  Really, high marks here.  Thanks Russian River!

Pours Concord grape in color with no head. Aroma of dark cherries soaked in lemon, sour funk, oak. Wonderful and inviting. Flavor huge in tart currant, cherry, oak, citric acid, grass, funk, powerful and puckering. Huge tart finish.
Had this one @ Unofficial Dutch Ratebeer Meeting. Red, amber colored brew. Vinous, syrup in the aroma. Flavor is sourness, too much, too sour, cherries.

Poured into a tulip. Pours a murky brown with a very active, but thin head. Smell is of ripe fruits- I get prunes, rasberry, and the like. Some sugary alcohol and vinegar as well. Taste is not as sour as I had imagined. Really smooth flavor, actually. Again, some dark fruits, and smooth rich wine flavor. Alcohol is extremely well hidden. Some active carbonation in the mouth, but overall very smooth and rich.

750 ml bottle Batch 001x2. Acquired in a trade and has been aging in my cellar since. Poured into a snifter. Consumed last night.

A-Body is a very hazy translucent medium mahogany hue. Pours with an approximately 1 finger foamy off-white head but this quickly fades pretty quickly leaving only a thin collar.

S-Nose has a very pungent acidic tartness from and is all that I noticed initially. With a deeper look aromas of oak, cigars, red wine, and cherry pits are also noted.

T- Much like the nose the flavor initially is dominated by a sharp acidic sourness all the way through with a very clean finish. With a deeper look and as one becomes more accustomed to the sourness the oak barrel flavor comes through as well as red wine and tobacco-more so with the finish than initially. Its interesting because the more you sip the more complex the beer becomes and the more you notice. The slightest alcohol

P- Exceptionally smooth and creamy with moderate carbonation. Body is thick, velvety smooth, and rich.

O- Wow. This is another excellent sour from the folks at Russian River. Delicious, rich, and complex. This beer has aged very well so far and is certainly a slow sipper. This should definitely be shared- 750ml is too rich for one person in one sitting. This is a beer that I would love to have again.

Serving type: bottle

Bottle @ RB meeting by Joes. A clear light brown colored beer with no head. The aroma has some fruits with sourness. wood notes in the back. The taste is sparkling, sweet and sour with some wood in the back. There are fruits and a little alcohol. The aftertaste is some sour with sweet and a little bitter.

Sampled at Toronado. A really quality sour ale. The palate on this thing is really fantastic. Drinks so nice and leaves you really freshed. The sourness has a good bite on it but last flavor is excellent. Really a quality drink. Good prices at Toronado.

750ml bottle, batch: 003X3.
aroma is very lambic, intense sour fruit, some horse, tobacco, oak and a bit of malt vinegar, fruit leather, and cherry pie
brown/ruby-red with thin fizzy light beige head.
flavor is again sour and fruity, lots of sweet/sour grapefruit in front, and sour, bitter, oaky and green olives further back -- rotten fruit.
effervescent and super dry, long sweet-dry finish.
this is great stuff, just a very complex mix of flavors.

Bottle from a trade with JohnC. Batch 001x4. Pours reddish brown color with off white head. Sour aroma with some oakiness. Tart currant flavor with some woodiness and lots of sourness. Medium body with average carbonation. Thanks John.

Thanks to Morgan.  Pours a cloudy, purplish amber, off-white head and nice lace.  Some arm pit in the nose but balances well with the other notes and only adds to the aroma.  Also some hints of oak, definite fruity black current notes, and an overall very enticing funk.  Flavor is predominately black current and a little sweet but even more tart with a great dry finish.  A really wonderful beer.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2011 shared 750ml bottle on 4/29/11.  deep red pour with a 1 finger tan head which quickly falls.  nice round sour nose with notes of band aid, dark fruits and wine barrels.  solid body with deep sour notes, dark fruits, oak, and a big vinous character.  dry, puckering tart finish with some heat and currants.

on tap at Falling Rock on 4/7/10... dark ruby pour with little to no head... deep sour nose with some currants...  big body with a sour top and smooth sides filled with dark fruit notes... lingering oak... big tart finish... very well rounded sour.... the alcohol is hidden very well and drinks like a 5% sour.  top notch!

flat with a deep dark brown hue, the aroma is a sweet fruity vinegar. Flavor is amazing, pure bliss. Peppery with a spicy palate balanced by the sweetness. Quite good. Bottle from a tasting with Smith4498, Legato, and Cbeers21.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2011 Bottle at Dutch RB meeting, thanks for sharing joes! Pours a clear dark orange to copper color without a notable head. Aroma of earth, leather, vinegar and fruits. Flavor is very very sour with hints of vinegar. A bit too extreme for me with its jaw-quenching acidity.
750 mL bottle thanks Kegbear. Pours a deep amber. Not a whole lot of smell.VEry nice sour taste. Not noticeable bite which was surprising. Alcohol was not noticeable .Very very good beer
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Fabulous beer, and you can get this any time in the Bay Area. Were lucky that way. Beautiful ruby red pour, inch-thick head at the top. Nose of currants, oak, funk. Taste is a bit thin with batch 03 right now but its stiLl incredible - lingering sour mouthfeel, not overly sour, tons of fruit and oak. Were very lucky to have this anytime we want it here. A masterpiece that keeps on giving.

Bottled, thank s tjthresh!  Hazy magogany colour, brief head. Buttery nose with citric acid and barnyard. Tart and fruity, surprisingly slim for a 10% beer. really sour and citric, somwhat nutty. The alcohol is extremely well hidden. Very intense.

Wow!  Very sour needless to say.  Cloudy darker ruby red on the pour.  More full rich body that has slight carbonation as well.  I am smelling, grapes, cranberries, slight currants, strong red wine and just a bunch of other sour notes on the aroma as well.  I taste sour fruit upfront, cabernet towards the middle, yeast, sharp orange peel flavor.  Excellent!  You can tell lots of love and creativity went into this beer.  Also there are some hops hidden in the mix there as well.  As usual an excellent beer from an excellent brewery!

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ place. Thanks for cracking this beauty open for our tasting!

Appearance: Red-brownish with a generous, foamy, head.

Aroma: Cherries, Funk, Malt, Wood. Quite lovely.

Taste: Malt, Cherries, Currant, Wood, Hint of Vanilla, Hint of fruit.

Palate: Wonderfully balanced with just enough funk for my taste. Insanely drinkable and the 10% abv is nowhere to be found. Has a very fresh feeling to it.

This is a very impressive american sour. It is easy to understand the high ratings. Awesome.
Wow. Awesome. Amazing sour fruity taste with just enough funk. Aroma is sour, fruity, oaky vanilla, and more!

(Batch 1x01) What can I say? Its incredible. Pours a translucent auburn with nice lacing. There are notes of red wine, currants (of course), cherries, malt and a wonderful sour like an incredible vinegar. The flavor is similar. The sour bites nicely. Theres actual malt presence behind all of the fruit and sourness. The fruit flavors are refined and elegant. The whole thing is a wonderful experience. I cant imagine how they could improve on this flavor profile. The sourness blends with the fruit and malt at just the right level. Theres also a dry oak flavor that keeps any possible sweetness in check. It drinks like a beer with half as much alcohol content.

This beer courtesy of Paul R. This poured a very cloudy dark brownish red, with some foam which quickly dissipated. Aroma has a few notes of the cabernet grape and a bit of the sourness that comes from belgian yeasts. Taste has a very strong sour flavor of red currants, plums and some over-ripe fruit. There is a slight sweetness that comes across on the aftertaste, mostly some pear and oak. did I mention this beer was very sour? Kinda makes you sweat a little. Mouthfeel is very nice on this one too. A very hard to get beer that is definitely worth the effort.

Ruby red.  The aroma has a lot of barrel.  Juicy, winey with lots of lively tartness.  Tasty, raspberry (OK its probably just currant) notes.  Interesting vinegar notes comes across the palate, lending nuance and an almost oily complexity.  Nice brew.

On draft at Russian River Brewing (Santa Rosa, CA): Pours a glowing, translucent mahogany red and topped with a thin white halo around the edges. This appearance alone is enticing enough. Vinious on the nose- aromatic notes of black currants, cherries, tart blackberries, kiwi, dark pitted fruits past prime, chocolate, earth, and a hint of damp basement. Flavors are similar with added chardonnay, wood, and various funk. Mouthfeel is quite heavy, dominant on the tart side. A massively drying finish. Drinkability: Good, but just not as epic as Supplication. Pairing: A swirl of thick vanilla ice cream and sorbet. Rebuy: Yes. #350 on 30032010, DG.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2013 Tap at Toronado. Wow - I dont really like sours, but this is terrific. Light cola colored pour. Aroma and taste of apple, cherry, and wood undertones. Really nice.

Re-rated 2 years later at Russian River. Looking at my prior rating...what a rookie I was! This is awesome.

On tap at Torondao. Vinegary, lactic and fruity with terrific winey notes. Woody and complex undertones in the nose. Balsamic? Rick copper brown clear with little head. Medium body with medium-high carbonation, carbonic fizzy and acidic burn. Starts and remains tart throughout, terrific acidity on this. Lactic, acetc, malic. Oaky and rich, caramel. Great woody notes with fruity crisp acidity. Mild alcohol sweetness but mainly cranberry tartness or cherry. Just a spectacular sour ale.

Tap @ Falling Rock.  Reddish brown with no head.  Airy nose of cherry, wood and vanilla.  Sour, but not puckering.  No real sweetness.  Tastes of apple and cherry with a hint of oak.  Nice, long tart finish.

750mL bottle, Batch 002x2, thanks to erice.  Pours a deep reddish brown with a decent amount of off-white head.  Smells great, lots of sweetish, tart fruit, cherries and grapes, with a bit of funk, oak, tannins and alcohol.  The taste has tons of oak, sweet dark fruit and bitter peel, but is a tiny bit too heavy on the tannins for my taste.  Finish has bitter grape and cherry peel.

Fruity, currant and cherry nose, funky cheesy brett, some caramel and cola. Bright acidity, lots of currant, some grapes and light cherry; Light to moderate sweetness, I actually think its the fruitiness of the taste thats making this seems sweeter than it is. Just a bit of cola and caramel. High carbonation, but gentle for the most part, texture is soft and round. Excellent.

On draft at TJs Everyday, Paoli, PA. Superb sour ale. Poured the color of dark tea, with very minimal head that disappears completely. Wonderful aromas of oak, barnyard, vinegar, sour cherry, and toast.  Aromas strengthened and multiplied as beer warmed. Terrific body. Astringent finish. Alcohol content completely imperceivable.

Draft @ Stumbling Monk. Garnet red-brown. Flat looking. Beneath a tart shell is a layer of sturdy dark malt that is pure, lovely, amazing, and deceptively simple. Even has a toasty character that is unexpected. Astringent. Evaporates on the tongue. Lip-puckering sourness. Acetic acid. Pungent wood. Dry and fruity. Great stuff.

When I bought this beer it was being chilled at the store. I brought it home wanting to age but I felt that drinking it now would be best. I was right. Poured red with little to no head. Aroma of sour apples and pears. I also get hints of grapes and wood. Explodes on the tongue from the hidden carbonation. A defenite sour taste again reminding me of cider. Lingering woody taste with a poukering after flavor drying out the mouth asking for more. This is my first ale and I enjoyed it.

Pours a burgundy color with a small head. The aroma is woody and oaky with some mild berries and alcohol with some good funk. The flavor is remarkable plenty of cranberry and currant, the beer is very sour with some tart and funky notes. The beer is just a tad sweet but perfectly balanced between sour malty and fruity. I have never in my life tasted a beer that concealed alcohol so well. Excellent.
Bottle shared by hellbilly.  Thank you sir!  Deep red brown color with a thin head.  Sour fruit, funky yeast and a bit of oak coming through.  Amazingly tasty!

750 ml bottle.  Pours reddish brown with fizzy, thin off white head.  Head disappears quickly.  Not much to look at.  Aroma has huge sour notes with vinegar, grapes, and oak.  Sharp tartness in the first sip.  Flavor of sour cherries.  Big Brett taste and nose.  Thick mouthfeel.  Very dry, long finish.  Complex and very good.

750 mL big, big thanks to BossHossBikes for the hook up on this one. The pour into a Trappist glass reveals a clear brown/red body with a fizzy, disappearing head.  I cannot see visible carbonation, though the mouthfeel is lively and tingly somehow.  The aroma is spot on for the style. True, genuine sour ale qualities of vinegar, oak, horses, overripe fruits and vinous tones make for an enjoyable and balanced bouquet. The flavor is much of the same. Lots of sour funk up front, though without being aggressive, with an endlessly complex body of grape, cherry, oak, vanilla, grass. The most notable flavors are of balsamic vinegarette, farmland and wool. Quite an offering from the masters at Russian River.  What makes this beer is its finesse, completeness, and robust flavor.

Bottle thanks to DuffManSW.  Mahogany pour with a ruby highlight and a short lived, fizzy, off white head.  Deep oaky aroma with a strong tartness, sweet rich molasses, and strong aromatic black currants.  Rich buttery charred oak flavor with some sweet molasses and caramel in the middle and finishes with black pepper, vinous black currant and a strong lactic sour bite.  Dry medium body with loads of carbonation.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2010 Draft at Monks for Russian River Day. Pours deep, dark, mahogany silky brown with a calm, smooth surface. No head. Aroma is subtle, but nice; sour cherries, tart fig, grapes, red wine, slight vinegar barley, hints of  vanilla, oak, and sweet malts. Medium bodied with a sticky, tangy, yet amazingly sour and juicy mouthfeel. Finishes with an insanely crisp, tart bite. One of the most unique, beautifully arranged sour ales I have ever tasted. Great brew in every regard.

Nice darkish red looking, thick and rich. Mild but rich oak aroma with pleasant sour notes. Very sophisticated. Mouthfeel is thick and rich with huge fruity and rather original flavours, pleasantly sour, complex and suprisingly fat. Hides the alcohol perfectly while leaving you just wanting more.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2010 Had it a Brouwers sour fest.  Constantly evolving as it warmed.  That was the best part.  It pours a reddish brown with a dissipating beige head. Nose is that of cherries, old wood, earth, and some pinot noir. On taste it is bold and not overpoweringly sour. Very well balanced with juicy fruits at the front with a hit of tart brettanomyces, finishing somewhat dry. Great carbonation level as well. This is a damn fine beer.  Outstanding.

Poured a hazy mahogany color with an off-white head.  Woody and tart aroma with a light fruitiness underneath.  The flavor was fairly tart with some light cherry taste.  Pleasant woody finish.  Light to medium bodied.

You’re either with the brett or against it. I can see this beer oscillating between a life changing experience and a complete drain pour. Nose is funky, dank and sour fruity. In the mouth it has almost champagne like presence, but with bracing bitterness help up by a second wave of sweeter currant and cherry. The funk is all over this and was different in three different glasses. Complex but definetely a beer geeks beer. Would like a bit more body to it too, but really easy drinking for 10%. Reminded me of the cantillion kriek in MANY ways, but this has a bit more to it. Thanks vinny will have to try this directly from the source one day. Gonna give it a 4...that could vary greatly though depending on my mood.

Bottle (Batch 003x4). Pours mahogany with a thin laced beige head. Quite vinous on the nose - heaps of tart cherries, oak, chocolate and earthy notes. The flavour mirrors the aroma with cherry, chocolate and various funk. Mouthfeel is quite heavy with feels very chewy, with the tartness very dominant. An extremely dry and tart finish, probably more than Im used to. Really interesting stuff though and a style I need to try more of. Massive thanks to Jonno who came through once again!

Pours deep red with head that quickly dissipates, batch 002.  Aroma is huge grape/wine with some oak character.  Taste is incredible, oak and wood up front leading into some grape/wine flavors and ending with a huge and lasting sour finish.  Amazing brew!
What didnt I like about this beer? Honestly loved it from the first whiff of the aroma all the way through its incredibly long finish. just amazing.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2011 2oz tasting at NOTB 
Appearance : Clear amber

Aroma : Fruity and tart. Slightly lactic and barnyard. A tiny bit medecinal (vicks or something). 

Taste : Fruity, syrupy and nicely tart. Cherry-ish. A bit mouth puckering.

Overall : Carbonation and tartness just felt really weird on the tongue. Hard to explain but it was quite unique. The description doesnt do it justice. I was really blown away by this beer. Really need to get a more reliable sample.
Re-rate 100710. Had two bottle samples of it and it was a bit less mind blowing. Still very good but not that good. Taste 10 to 9. Pal 5 to 4.  Total 4.4 to 4.2110125 Fixed typos

Russian River
Consecration
First true sour ale, last true sour ale. Pours brown with a reddish tinge, smallish head clear body. Aroma of red wine grapes and pickle juice. Tastes sour as hell and nasty as piss. Maybe I just dont like or understand the style, but this tastes like shit. I was super pissed that I just poured out a $23 bottle of beer. Third time I have felt burned by this brewery. Overrated.
Excellent sour from RR you can really taste the currants which blend well with the brett. Out of a bottle in a tulip.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2010 2nd Rating: Had a regular come into work tonight with this and asked if I had tried it before.  I said I had, but didnt remember loving it.  We cracked it and had a little private tasting.  Oh man, not sure what I was think the first time around... I cant believe my palate would have changed much in just 3-4 months, but this is MUCH better than I remember.  Would love to have more of it now, lol.

1st Rating: Bottle at Home during the race.  Thanks to JohnC for sending this one out.
 Have to say, Ive never been much of a Sour fan, so I wont give this a detailed rating.  But needless to say, if youre a sour fan, give it a try. I could recognize the quality even though I didnt appreciate this ale.
Two flavors are duking it out on this one. sour and spicy.  after awhile the sour wins.  really a pucker inducing beer.  needs to be drunk separate from anything else and enjoyed for what it is.

A: Opaque, dark brown with a very noticeable reddish tint.

S: The nose is sour in general, but specifically sour cherries. The oak barrel also really comes through.

T: Again, lots of sour cherries. Quite tart. Maybe also some grapes and you definitely get the currants. The combination of the Brett, barrel, and fruit give the beer a very dry and tannic character..

M: The body is rather full with a high level of carbonation and a very dry finish.

D: Incredible. You would never know the ABV strength of this beer as the alcohol is completely covered by the wonderful taste.

Bottle: Pours a dark brown color with a nice head. The nose is tart and ripe with grapes, brett and sour peaches. A nice malty body and mouthfeel to accompany and a balanced tart/bitter finish. Very rounded offering with a great fruitiness, tartness and explosive barnyard qualities. Thanks Matt!
Batch 001/2. Corked bottle. Vinous, oaky aroma with raisin and dark chocolate. Sweet and sour flavor with lemony tartness. Raisin, toffee, oak. Vinous with notes of grapes. Lovely complex brew.

Dark brown color with frothy tan head that was very bubbly. Carbonation can be seen shooting quickly up the sides of the glass. The smell stung with a hint of sour, bready malt, and currants, and funky yeast. Taste is slightly sweet and moderate/heavy tart sourness that backs off gently as you breathe.  Very crisp and carbonated mouthfeel, and it hits you in the back of the tongue with puckering sourness. Incredibly well-balanced with some sweet malt, tart fruit, great mouthfeel. Very drinkable.

750 ml bomber poured into a wine glass (had to improvise at in-laws house).  Cloudy brown color with frothy tan head.  Carbonation can be seen shooting quickly up the sides of the glass.  For aroma, sourness is the first thing that hits your nose.  Some sweet bready malt, tart grapes and currants, and funky yeast.  Taste is slightly sweet and moderate/heavy tart sourness.  Very crisp and carbonated mouthfeel, and it hits you in the back of the tongue with puckering sourness.  Incredibly well-balanced with some sweet malt, tart fruit, great mouthfeel.  Just a masterpiece!

Trade thanks to LtDan. Aroma of citric acid with a faint whiff of wild yeast hiding beneath. Pours a medium amber with a small tan head. Flavor begins only slightly tart, with penetrating elements of alcohol and oak coming through. It becomes increasingly sour as the glass opens up, passing through a sweet spot where the tartness harmonizes well with wood, toasty caramel and vanilla from the oak barrel, and a lightly roasted chocolaty malt element. Eventually the sourness takes over, and the beer become liquefied sweet tart. Medium body, nice pucker on the palate.
Had a glass of this followed by a glass of Supplication. Both were great RR sours. This one was a bit sweeter and reminded me of cranberry juice. Overall a great beer.

Drinking out of a Stone tulip. Small white head that dissipates quickly great color to it almost like a super dark cherry color.
