Quite hollow and airy at the center, with the snappy brett-derived phenols and gritty-iron-clasp displacing the curiously ghostlike malt. Clean yet merely suggestive pale malts take on some strawlike bounce toward the finish, but fail to impart any substantial heft or depth along the way. Fairly simplistic due to the prevalent iron-tinged lacto twang and nonexistent malt sweetness. Juicy smack of currants dovetails with the raspy iron and coarse mineralic bite, though due to the rampant, unchecked tartness, the fruit character is largely reminiscent of dried strawberries, unripe plums and peaches rather than boasting a deep, fresh-picked succulence. Oak graces the palate with a dusty dryness, but is otherwise muted. Steadily wavering notes of Band-Aid and crunchy phenolics succumb to the pervasive lacto twang and faint medicine. Closes with a fluffy dollop of pale malt, though with a slightly clashing tart and gritty mixture of iron, medicine, leather, minerals and unripe fruit. Darn, was really hoping the bottle conditioning would impart additional nuance and send this into the realm of otherworldliness. I find this to be marginally superior  namely in mouthfeel and appearance  to the draft version I tasted six months ago. While this is certainly skillfully crafted and refined, as are all of Vinnies bottled creations, this is in dire need of some soft, full, sweetish malts to both complement the pale malts while cushioning the mineralic briskness, slight astringency and one-dimensional acidity.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Thanks fogdog for the share.  Pours red-brown with an off-white head.  Nose is vinegar, reminiscent of Duchess de Bourgone, dark cherries, and spice.  Flavor is vinegar, funk, dark cherry, dark fruit, plum, and tart sour cherries.  Very tart, excellent.

Thanks to John C in a trade.Pours a dark red with a small beige head. The head diminished quickly. The aroma was full of sour cassis with strong alcohol notes. There was also some wood present. I really enjoyed the aroma. It was medium bodied with a wonderful sourness. Quite nice on the palate. Overall a really nice beer.

Rating #800. Bottle, courtesy fogdog. Dark brandy red pour, white film of lacing sheen on the glass, and no head. Nose starts sweet, with dark plums and cherries, big tart and brown sugar, with some spicy cider notes that blend quite well. Flavor has lots of dark fruit, plum, apricot, sweet full finish of tart apples and other crisp notes. The oak gives everything a nice frothy shower of flavor. Very balanced, full-bodied, delicious, and really just another fine example of a world class beer from Russian River. They can do no wrong.

750 ml bottle from Freddy. Pours a murky amber-brown with a small beige head that quickly dissipates. The aroma is strong with berries, wine, spicy oak, and funk. The flavor is complex with sour cherry pits, berries, lots of oak, red wine(merlot or cab), vanilla and caramel. The mouthfeel is silky smooth  with lively carbonation. The finish is long and dry with lingering complex tart flavors. Overall: This is an impressive sour, but its really not worth the high price tag; a good beer, but a poor value.

tap at toronado, dark red with minimal head. strong winey sourness aroma. very strong sour flavors, with hints of red wine and oak. assault on the palate, dry at first then it leaves your mouth watering wanting more. boozy and thick once it warmed up a little. the currants are barely noticable with the prescence of such strong sourness.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2009 Bottle shared by Bstil and Eyedrinkale, thanks guys.   Pours a dark mahogany with a thin lacing.  Currants, and raspberry.  Light woodinesss with a tart dry woodiness and low acidity.  A moderate etoh warming slips out in the finish.  
I had another bottle with strasko last night and i would have rated it a 4.0, but hey why bother changing it.
on bottle at toronado and stone. very smooth and mild sour aroma and taste, almost cherry like with the aged currants.

On tap at the brewpub, shocked that I got a 16 oz pour when I was expecting a 10, but it was a bargain at 6.75. Dark cherry red pour with a hazy tan head that lingers. Very sour aroma of cherries and plums with a light vinous smell to it as well. The flavor is like a sour fruit explosion in your face: cherries, grapes, blackberries, and a nice wine thickness. Very nice carbonation in the mouth and a nice malt profile as well. Hopefully my future experiences with sours will match up to this one.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2009 (on tap @ fathers office in culver city)brown body with a white head.nice aroma of oak,red wine,fruit,and sourness.flavor is heavy oak/wood,funk,and fruit.very nice stuff.(re-rate of bottle on my 33rd birthday.)in the bottle the oak is not as powerful.its more balanced.this is awesome stuff.

Bought a bottle at the Bi-Rite in Castro. Thanks to the sweet beer girl there for all the chat. Wonderful dark amber color, nice jammy aroma with a touch of claret barrel to it, heavenly tartness with all kinds of fruit dancing around....by the tweaked nipples of Ninkasi I love this style. Hooray for Russian River.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2010 really was my lucky day when Kevin broke out a 750ml at grape & gourmets 3rd anniversary and poured me a tulip glass full. pours a dark, cherry wood color with a substantial and fizzy light tan head. aroma was immediately striking and fantastic. sour, dark red fruits dominate with scents of cherry, blackberry, and raspberry that came together in an amazing red wine profile. aroma also had a touch of sweetness and oak that made it all the more complex. flavor was deliciously tart and vinous with sour red berries and black currants balanced by very dark, and slightly sweet malts. mouthfeel was very lively with the high carbonation and warmed nicely on the swallow. amazed that i got to try this one. cheers to RR for quickly becomming one of my favorite, albeit very difficult to find breweries.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2010 Tap @ Saraveza...  Poured ruby with a beige head.  Tart, oak and yeast on the nose.  Well carbonated for the style which balanced the alcohol and tart, sour characteristics.  I could feel the alcohol going down my esophagus which was pretty warming.  Some flavors of oak and wild yeast which was noticeable but not as smooth and tart/sour as I would hope.  Still one hell of a (A+) beer though.  Oh, and the currants were very subtle and in the background mostly and a little in the finish.

Pours out dark brown black with thin brown foam which quickly falls. Smells is sweet and funky with some wood. Taste is fizzy with nice tartness. Great sour cherry notes with some funk present. Dry finish with great sticky sweetness. One of their best beers.

Bottle from a place of which Im not supposed to mention.  Pours a dark, clear mahogany with a thin tan head.  Aroma is lots of oak with some white whine and sour fruits with notes of vanilla.  Flavor is a lot of barrel.  Sour cherries and currants as stated in the description.  Sourness is balanced nicely with some malt sweetness.  Not much alcohol is apparent.  A good deal of carbonation and surprisingly lighter bodied than expected.  Wish I had more than 1 bottle!

Draught at Toronado, SF
Slightly hazy, dark copper. Medium, tan head.
Really with oak and black currant.
Fine maltiness and warming alcohol.
On tap at Obriens.  Dark reddish brown pour with medium off-white head.  Sour cherries, apple, currants, oak, notes of dark fruit, and vinous grapes.  Very good sour.  Quite tart and dry.

(Bottle from 001X3). Good Lord this had some serious carbonation. The pressure behind the cork was more than one of Frances best champagnes. Unfortunately, it also started to foam up out of the neck and a some drops made it to the carpet. Pours very carbonated into the bottle with effervescent head that you can hear in the glass. It falls quickly like a glass of cola. Aroma not huge, but you can smell the bugs in the whiff. Flavor is interesting. Clear sourness of the brett/lacto/ped mixture, especially when you role it over your tongue and its gazillion taste buds. You also have a finish of the currants its supposed to have. Clean palate with no real lingering. The description says it is fermented in Cabernet Savignon barrels, which I can taste (or perhaps its just my imagination?). Kind of surprised in that Im not getting any warming effect despite the alcohol is 10%. Also, its a very lightweight body beer.
I had this at the Russian River brewpub.  Poured with minimal head, dark purple color.   The tart sour cherry flavor  complements the sweetness of the malt nicely.

Dark purple, no head or lacing.  Very vinous aroma, sweet cheap wine, MD 20/20, red fruits a bit of tartness.  Nice tartness in the flavor, along with sweet fruit, raspberries, and a vinous quality.  Nice dry, clean finish.  Almost boozy, and it borders on cheap fruit wine but saved by the tartness.

750nml corked and caged thanks to 	iowaherkeye.  Gusher.  Pours semi hazy and light reddish brown in color with a small tan head which diminishes into a collar .  Aromas of sour currants, berries, oak, acidic cherries and other darker fruits.  Flavors consist a sweet and sour entry of cherries, currants and fruits.  The tartness and sour notes really mellow out the sweetness.  Finish is a long sour and tart orgasm of fruit.   Palate is smooth, and perfectly carbonated.  Fuck me this beer is good!  Thanks again Joey!

Bottle -c&c- from Ledgers Liquor. Batch 001X4. Slight gushing shortly after cork removed. Dark coppery color with a slight tan head - it went up, then down. Aromas of berry, wood and mild sour. Near full bodied with tart, fine carbonation. Speaking of tart the flavor is, along with aged musty oak and something like dark sour cherry. Each taste begins again with wood, then sour, then fruit. Tends to get a little less so in the finish. Incredible. Also brilliant. Just gets better with time.

Bottle, Batch 001x4 (2/14/09). Bottle exploded upon opening watch out for that! Pours a cloudy deep ruby red to brown with a flowing head that quickly disappears. Nose is sour currant, oak, a nice wine characteristic, very complex. Taste is pleasantly tart with currants, cranberry. Nice warm melted chocolate Mouth is full with a lot of effervescence, the beer makes you salivate after it goes down. Very warm in the stomach. Wonderful sour!

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2010 750ml bottle. Deep ruby red with a frothy head. Nice barnyard aromas with sweet n sour currant and sharp caramel. Light bodied with a frothy mouthfeel. Good balance of sweet and sour flavors, with glazed caramel, spicy currants, sour cherry and some wet wood. Has a mildly acidic finish.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle shared by miketd.  Thanks Mike!  Pours dark brown with off white head.  Has acid and tart cherry aromas.  Flavor is tart cherry, dark fruit, wood, and some wine notes.  Finishes with a super pucker mouth watering sourness that is great.  Medium light mouthfeel.  Overall a great brew and one I really liked.

On tap at Toronado RR Night. This dark brown ale poured with a decent beige head and a pleasant vinous aroma. The flavor is very tart cherry, with oak undertones and a vanilla backwash. Believe it or not, it tastes quite a bit like Schaarbeekse Kriek, probably due to the addition of currants. This is a signature brew that could only be created by Vinnie and his crew (hey, it rhymes). So far, my favorite RR (even better than Toronado 20th).

Amazing beer generously shared by Bobby at Pre-Sex. Dude, major thanks! Mild amber pour with a subtle, extremely complex nose filled with oak, tannins, delightful currants. Even when measured against Russian Rivers other superb offerings, the woody splendor of this beer stands out. Wow, such a rich treat.
On tap at Hollingshead. Beautiful red copper color. Complex flavor, tart cherry, cranberry, vanilla, oak. Beautiful texture and carbonation. This is a fantastic sour.

On tap from OBriens Pub gave a reddish burgundy color with minimal head to speak of. Aromas of some dark fruit and grape. Super rich and smooth on the palate with a perfect bit of carbonation. Tart, sour, plum, currant and raspberry flavors. Long finish with great retention of flavors. Alcohol not over bearing. One of my new favorite sour ales for sure!

Drank this side by side with Foothills BA Peoples Porter to start off the festivities at the pre-footsex gathering this year.  After getting the okay from Scott to start drinking the porter and sitting down to start taking notes, I heard a gush and turned around to see Bobby91w and tjthresh trying to stop a gushing bottle of this here beer. I aided by sticking out my glass for a pour of this dark sour elixir. Tasty treat, highlighted by deep red fruits.  The currants and red wine oaky notes come through nicely amidst the sourness. Russian Rivers balls are firmly located on my forehead and Im proud of it.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2009 Another gem via Bobby91w! Batch 1 Dark brown pour with garnet hues. Thin tan head.  Cranberry and oaky nose.  Complex flavor; vanilla and sour grapes.  Long sour finish.  Not overly acidic

Thanks Bobby91w for sharing at the Pre Sex gathering. Pours a murky ruby with a fizzy tannish head. The nose is tart and acidic, background vinous character, oaky, nice vanilla coming through, some spicyness. The flavor is nice and tart without being overbearing, oaky with some vanilla, nice fruity character, warming, tannic bite. Palate is nice and tart without being overly acidic with a nice tannic oakiness.
Bottle shared by Bobby91w.  Pours dark red-brown. Not much head. Good nose of oak, and dark berries. Huge tannins sour bomb. Nice fruit flavor. Med syrup body. Dry.  Pretty good stuff.

On draft at OBriens. Pours a deep magenta to purple hue, thin off-white head dissipates, fair clarity. Nose is dark fruits and berries, light sourness, oak barrel, and vinous. Flavor is very fruity with a nice backbone of acetic sourness, jammy and woody tones midway, finishes lightly tart. Medium-bodied with smooth texture and moderate carbonation. A nice more-fruity-than sour ale with woody accentuations.

Bottle. Probably oone of the best sours I ever had and I am not a sour fanatic.
Wonderful flavors of wood, oak, tart fruit and some vinegar. At the same time very smooth on the palate. Aromas are fruity with some earthiness

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2010 On draft at RRBC. Integrated fruit that dries out in finish, like a great Petite Syrah or Rhone, but softer and with a tang. 
Pours  from 750ml  like dark cherry nectar with faint off white spray of  foam. Aroma and flavor dominated by jammy cabernet fruit notes and tart currant with sour acidity.
Nearly medium-bodied with almost slick mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Just a tinge of balanced alcohol warmth (hiding the huge ten percent). The bouquet of wildness in the aroma carries through to long-lasting aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2009 On Tap at RR. Smells like cherry oak. Looks like dark cherry champagne. Funk in full, but not overkill. This was after drinking Sanctification, so my sour buds were prepped for any sourness there. Notes of tannin and the currants, as well as wine notes all over the place. ON SECOND ANALYSIS: I can completely see the tobacco notes in this! Smells like either (1) a fresh FRESH pack of cigarettes or (2) A cigar from the streets of Havana. I love this beer! It made a Sour lover out of me!
very nice beer tons of cabernet and currant flavors with a nice funk to smell and taste...balanced and hides the 10% really fucking well

On draft at OBriens Russian River night.  This was my favorite beer of the night (aside from Pliny the Younger of course).  Pours a deep plum red, lightly hazed, with the head being a thin light purple ring.  Tons of berry fruits and red wine in the nose with some oak in there as well.  A very long finish that seemed to stick around for days.  A very balanced sour ale, one of my favorites to date.

Heavy influence of currants and cabernet / oak flavors.  Blue and red berry fruits.  Cassis, seemless and very balanced.  Long finish and almost thick silky texture.  Zero alc noticable.  Tried from Keg at OBriens Russian River nite.
Huge tart cherry flavor.  Strong earthy oak aroma.  Hints of vanilla and caramel to balance out the strong sour flavor.  Pleasant lingering finish.

Sour, cherries, figs, raisins, toffee.  It has a dry, vinuous character, should age superbly, and the barrel character is quite apparent, slight notes of vanilla, oak, earth.  Quite acidic and a lingering sour finish. This one sticks with you.

Date: December 12, 2008
Mode: Growler
Source: Tasting
Appearance: clear dark ruby red, scant head
Aroma: sweet and sour aroma, tart fruity wine character, oak, touch of chocolate
Flavor: big tart flavor, lots of oak and fruity wine in good balance, sweet caramel, touch of chocolate, light bitterness, sour picks up with each sip, woody caramel starts to become domanant, tart cherry pit is ever lasting
Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **4

Hand bottle from iowaherkeye shared with the troops by pepsican. Thanks to both of you! Poured a clear garnet brown color with an off white head. Fruity and funky aroma with distinct whiffs of plain doughnut, cherry, red wine, and oak. Medium bodied with light to moderate acidity. Very nice. Not much in the way of alcohol warmth given the 10% ABV. Vinous without being boozy. The flavor was reminiscent of red wine vinegar, tart cherry, and oak. Delicious stuff. I need a case of this.

This poured a cola-like amber brown in color with a thin beige head of fine bubles that fade away quickly.  The nose is filled with cherries, currant, orange peel, concentrated grape juice and woodsmoke.  In the mouth this begins tart with the acidity immediately hitting the palate.  It is medium-bodied and deep with lots of flavor in the midpalate to tame the tartness.  The palate is surpisingly smooth given the level of tartness.  There is a dryness running the finish which just makes you want to take another sip for that burst of acidity.  I’m really glad they decided to bottle this one!

On tap at the VIP session of 2008 Strong Ale Festival.  Reddish brown in color, strong dark fruit aroma with a little funk.  Amazing mouth feel with flavors of cherries, plumb, and red wine.  Pretty sour but not unbalanced.  I think this is my favorite RR brew so far.

Thanks to Jason for driving  to get a growler and fly it home for me. Shared with fordest, toncatcher, Jason, and Mike. An excellent smelling sour. Wood, sweet juicy fruit gum. Very tasty. Sour, a little vinegar, dry finish.

On tap at Falling Rock, GABF 2008.  Somewhat hazy, dark amber colored body with some deep cherrywood hues and a quickly dissipating head of dark ivory.  Aromas of cabernet grape tannins, hints of toffee, and a moderate mustiness.  Very grapey, although some of the softer currant aromas seem to peek through.  Medium bodied, softly carbonated mouthfeel with a moderate acidity.  Currant fruit flavors up front with a tingling tartness.  Some mild malt sweetness is left lingering on the palate, but it melds nicely with the fruit sugars.  Lots of tannic grape flavors, but some softer notes of plum, and of course, currants add some roundness to the fruit profile.  Finishes moderately dry with a lingering black pepper yeasty spice.  Lovely fruit and vinous flavors, but the body is slightly sweet and the tartness has not really developed much complexity at this point.  A favorite at the festival, but not as impressive when served a full pour.  Will definitely look forward to bottled versions of this in the future.

Growler courtesy of Gillard. Thanks a bunch Ryan. Pours a clear amber with a one finger light tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of tart cherries, spicy brett, oak, slightly rotten citrus, and a touch of caramel. Taste is tart cherries, vinegar, oak, vinous notes, rotten citrus, and a touch of caramel. Medium thin mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness and moderate acidity. The alcohol is almost non existent. Another wonderfull brew from Russian River.

Growler courtesy of Gillard. Pours a dark red mahogany color with a one finger white head that settles quickly. Aroma is woody and bourbony with notes of worchestershire, oak, ripe fruit, some hints of malt. Flavor is insanely sour with notes of  ripe fruit, some hints of malty sweetness and even ripe grapes. A strong sour ale that will cleanse the harshest of palates. Generally light to medium body with a very sour and tart finish.

Growler courtesy of Strelnikov poured into a goblet.

Pours a deep, clear copper with a decent bubbly cream head that dissipated quickly to a thin collar.

The aroma is wonderfully complex with the slightly sharp currant sweetness on top of a sugary sweetness. The barrel characteristics are also present with hints of vanilla in the nose. The brett is there to lend an ever-so-slight sourness with a complementary earthy funk in the background.

The taste seems to be a more complex and balanced version of the nose. The sweetness hits up front with the light tartness of the currants balanced by the underlying sugars. The brett makes its presence felt but the finish is very vinous with the oak playing a role as well.

The mouthfeel is lightly carbonated and very wine-like with a dry finish and bits of funk throughout.

This is a fantastic beer and one of the better sours Ive had the opportunity to try. Superbly well balanced and extraordinarily drinkable for the ABV. Highly recommended.

Big thanks to Gillard for bringing this 2L growler to the weekly tasting. Pours clear deep brown with copper hues and thin tan head. The aroma is full tartness and aspirin. Behind that I get faint sweetness and a touch of fruitiness. The taste has solid tartness that over powers the milder notes of fruit, wine grapes, tannins and wood barrel notes. Nice palate cleanser. I was tasting the Brett a good 15 hours later.

Growler, courtesy of a freind of my brothers, THANK YOU John. Dark mahogony color, with little head. Fantastic aroma, I could smell it all night long, somewhat vinieous aroma, slightly sweet and sour, nice combo. Wow, thats a lip smacker, really nice sourness to it, more wine as well, pretty tasty. Me likey.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
growler courtesy of gillard. Thanks for bringing this fine beer.
Pours brownish with off white head.
Aroma sure has sour written all over it. Add to it some fruity -helping it getting its wine nose - notes and wood.
Taste is just very sour with good balance of the oak. Beer gains some really nice fruity undertones, grape-like with the oak coming alive and the Cabernet barrel making this beer a good sour.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2008 Growler. Big fruity nose, grapes and light peach with pear and berries. Clear brown with no head, low carbonation from a growler that had previously been opened. Very nice fruity sourness, extremely long lingering. Peach, berry, apple, and figs. Smooth and drinkable, even without carbonation it never becomes aggressive.

On tap at Strong Ale Fest 12/05/08.  Some lady thought it was too sour and gave me her sample!  Dark maroon with almost no head. Sour cherries, cranberry, wood, chocolate. Tastes of sweet red grapes, oak, funk and another source of sweetness I couldnot pin down. Not overly thick in viscosity. The best wild beer I have had from RR to date.

On tap at the 2008 Strong Ale Festival. Poured a dark brown color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of dark fruits -dark cherries-, berries, chocolate, and wood. Tastes of grape skins, dark cherries, wood, lightly vinous, chocolate, and funky. Softer body. Nice tart finish. Nice way to start of the festival for sure -my 1st beer of the night-.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2009 re-rate thanks to guy for sharing, 28Jan09, full sized sample shows much better flavors 

On tap at the 2008 San Diego Strong Ale fest this is a reddish brown pour with no head. Nice complexity of flavors

Tasted on tap at the Bistro Barrel Aged Beer Festival on 11/15/2008. This sour ale pours a medium orange gold color form the tap. Small sized white foamy head. The aroma is fruity and sweet with a touch of tartness. A medium bodied sour ale. The malts are fruity and sweet. The hops are earthy. Lots of funk, but not mouth puckering. Nice balance between the sweetness of the fruit and the tartness of the funk and brett. Lively carbonation. Hides the alcohol well. The finish has a nice lingering tartness. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter and tart.

Growler at WeeHeavySD’s 2000th rating party, thanks to kmweaver! Pours a clear dark reddish-brown with a white ring. Huge sour aroma, of fruit and malt, cherries, lemons. Huge crisp sour taste, lots of fruit, cherries and currants, a hint of sweetness, and red wine. Lingering crisp sweet-sourness. Wonderful.

Growler from Ken at WeeHeavy’s tasting, thanks Ken.  This is one damn fine sour beer.  I thinkk some of RR’s sour are a little sour for me.  Pours an amber red hue,  Aroma was tart ith a little sweetness.  Flavor was currants, red wine and wood.  Nice and sweet and sour.

From a growler shared at WeeHeavySD’s 2000th rate tasting.  Thanks KEN!  Lots of tart aromas off this orangeish reddish beer.  Not too much head.  Flavor was amazingly good.  More tart with hints of grape and cherry and apple.  Somewhat acidic finish, but still very smooth.  So So yummy.
Pours attractive pale red with no head. Awesome tart funk nose with some vinous notes. Lively mouthfeel and complex flavor with the nose influences along with a subtle sweetness from the currants.

Growler generously brought by Kmweaver, he calls me from the brewery and asks If I’d like a growler when he would be in town.  I didn’t even blink, glad I didn’t.  Shared at my 2000th rating tasting with Kmweaver and his wife, my girlfriend Cyn, dalekliz, fordest, toncatcher, and wetherel.  Pours amber dark orangey brown with a tan ring.  Nose is super strong and big with lots and lots of vinegar and sour currant.  Taste is huge, lots of wonderful currant flavor, completely amazing vinious red wine character.  Sweet and tart very very very good.  Excellent.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2008 On tap @ Russian River. Hot damn am I happy to see this on the chalkboard.  Clear ruby brown with a small beige head, fading to a thin ring before long, and served in a snifter. Big oak and red wine nose up front with the vinegar and sour apple notes next. Buttery brett and leather peak out stronger as I nose this, and its hard to pick out the sweet dark fruit that is Salvation in the base beer. Whoo! Flavor is full of tons of sour fruits and berries with a definite dry red wine and oak (lots of oak) finish. Sour factor peaked ~ a 6-7,and I wanted to add there was some low earthy bitterness in the backend as well. Im hard-pressed to find any Salvation in this. Full body with light prickly carbonation--just a little warming in the belly implies the 10%. Really effing good--looks like my Iowa homies are getting one pricey growler!
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: dark brown with fizzy white head. Sour vinegar aroma. Nice sweet fruity taste with hints of pear and a big oaky sourness.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2009 Draught at Falling Rock Taphouse, Denver. Clear red/brown - offwhite head. Vinegar, balsamic, rubber, cherry, caramel, sourness, tar, wood, oak, dark fruits, berries, sourness. Very very nice.....Again as: #13 - Amerikaner Smagning 01-Maj-2009 hos Papsoe. Bottle. (6/4/7/4/16)

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2009 Update: the most recent batch is much not quite as good as the first batch, less oak, a bit more harshness, still and absolutely amazing beer.  No head, but surprisingly effervescent.  Thinner mouthfeel than anticipated.  The oak and Cabernet taste is quite strong and is a good counterpart to the sourness.  Cherry tastes from the brett sing through.  This one is very dry!  Completely blurs the line with wine.  Even better the second time I had it.  A fantastic beer.

Draft at Bistro BA fest.  Brown pour.  Tart aroma, some wine and fruity characteristics as well.  Just a nice tart flavor, some dark fruity malt, not much funk, good balance with some wood as well.  My favorite of the day.

Sampled at the 2008 Great American Beer Festival. Another backlogged rating. By far one of my favorite specialty barrel-aged ales of the festival. Deep, opaque brown color with faint beige lacing. Beautiful nose of tart currants and oak wood. Well-balanced fruity flavor with a lactic acidity providing a strong, but near perfect amount of tartness for this type of sour beer. The big oak character with the currants lends a nice vinous wine note to the beer. Overall, very nicely rounded. Cant wait for this stuff to come out in bottles!

Draft @ Russian River.  Pours a dark, bold brownish-ruby color; thin light-tan head with patchy fine-bubbled lacing.  Lots of sour red fruits, some bittersweet vinous notes, cherry pulp and skins in the aroma; nice tartness upfront with some basic black cherries underneath.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: loads of intensely sour and strongly acidic cherries and citrus, black cherries, and moderately tannic cabernet notes; strongly vinous, dense wine-barrel presence, more prominent cabernet notes than I can think of in any other barrel-aged beer, while still very drinkable and gorgeously bittersweet; very nice beer, very nice barrel.  Lengthy finish: tart black cherries, bing cherries, and lingering cabernet tannins.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2009 Draft at the Bistros BA fest: Nose of Light Brett, Caramel, oak, light peachy fruitness, and some light tartness; clear brown without much carbonation; flavor is tart with light fruitiness. Very tasty!
4/21/09 Bottle shared by Enniskillen. Now i smell the currants in the nose along with a very light tartness and caramel. Clear purplish brown with a small beige head. Flavor is slightly sweet dried cranberries and a hint of tartness. Finish is a lightly increasing tartness, but not a lot.

Sampled Falling Rock, GABF week 2008
I was able to sneak into a spot at the bar and got one of the first glasses of this, the first keg blew in 5 minutes (before Chris even had a chance to announce it was on tap) and the second only lasted an additional 15 minutes; I was definitely quite lucky to get two glasses of this beer.  The beer arrives with quite a clear appearance, it is the hue of a raisin with a rich concentrated color and shows a deep red hue when held up to the light.  It is topped by a pale, ring of a heat that after a bit forms a brown tinged, full tan colored head that just covers the beer.  The aroma definitely has a tartness to it, but also has a rich, thick fruitiness to it that reminds me of a mix of concentrated tamarind, syrupy-fruity balsamic vinegar and rich raisins.

As the beer first hits my tongue it is chewy and rich; a sour beer with a substantial texture (at the time I didn’t realize how strong this beer was, but in hindsight the richness makes a lot of sense).  Tannins coat my teeth and there is a soft, yet noticeable barrel character in the finish that adds a spicy oak bite.  Rich raisin flavors, a substantial berry-like wine note, as well as some rich dried fig and prune flavors all combine to provide a big, fruit-driven backbone that anchors the flavor of this beer.  The rich fruit and oak flavors is tempered by a mouth puckering, somehow rich, sourness that is mostly lactic in character but sees to have some acetic overtones to it that reminds me of some sort of berry vinegar as well as hints of a rich, grape balsamic notes.  The beer almost develops a raspberry flavor at times, and this actually is pretty nice (says someone who generally shies away from raspberry flavors in beer).  As I contemplate my second glass of this beer I start to notice more of the oak flavors coming to the fore with flavors of vanilla, light coconut that is sort of Bourbon-like somehow as well as a structured wine character and a definite berry note that seems like a wine signature.

I haven’t said this yet, but this beer is just fantastic.  It has an incredible balance of tartness to rich fruit and light, though structured oak character.  The flavor is just so well integrated, everything just seems to work together to carry this beer up to another level of complexity and interest.  The oak really does add lots of structure, which goes a long way towards helping the overall balance of this beer.  I like that the incredibly rich fruit character never gets overwhelming (back to that balance again).  This is an awesome beer, whose enjoyment I am sure was magnified by the setting as well as he prior afternoon session of the GABF.

GABF ’08.   A beauty of a beer...the acidic, teasing sour itch works perfectly w/ the red wine oak and fruit additives.  I like the currants here, they do it right.  With more plum/cherry taste.  Sticky and warming, prickly carbonation.  Just wonderful.  I can only picture the bottle version to be ridiculous.  It also looks like the gabf sample was better received than the falling rock tap...

Draught at Falling Rock Tap House, GABF 2008.  Pours clear tawny with a small, fizzy, light brown head, somewhat lasting with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, hay, straw), light hops (herbs), average yeast (earth) with notes of plum, cherry, and wood.  Full bodied, sticky texture, average carbonation, and a sour finish.  Long duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and sourness.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2009 Multiple samples at GABF.  Poured a brownish-amber color with a thin off-white head that faded to a layer.  Aroma of dark, vinuous fruits (grape, currants, light berry), tart, funky yeast, some light acidity, and a nice oak.  Smooth, tart entry leads into a moderate fruitiness with hints of currants and red grapes leading into a funky barnyard yeastiness followed by some acedic sourness with some tart citrus fruits and some drying oak on the finish.  Low carbonation, nice bite.  Another good sour from RR.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2009 GABF 08:  Clear burnt bronze colored beer with a tannish colored head.  Thick, vinous, boozy, sour, and malty nose with the added bonus of strong concentrated fruit in the way of nectarines or peaches.  Largely sour with interesting grilled fruit-like maltiness behind.  pluot flesh mouthfeel...THis is one complex fucker. The woody tannic cabernet-like canvas gives birth to complexity beyond comprehension...the hotness is felt...that scratch on the back of my throat could be gods word.

(Draught)  Pours a clear deep amber body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of barnyard, vinegar, citrus, some yeast, and wood.  Flavor of sweet berries, sour citrus, light vinous, and earthiness.  Nice!

Draught at GABF 2008.
Clear golden coloured with a medium sized off white head.
Light acidic aroma of fruits, wood and vanilla.
Fruity flavour of wood and vanilla with notes of berries and acidic notes.
Tart finish.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2009 On tap at Falling Rock: Deep burgundy hue looked good inside a wine glass. Vibrant nose. Felt full on the tongue; carbonation was tingly; refreshing. Salty and rich with flavor.  Raisins, rum, currants, brown sugar, molasses and sour cherries. Vinous and peppery, with a nice and sour base. Rich and tingly on the tongue. Lesser notes of oak, vanilla and light vinegar.

On tap @ Falling Rock poured a clear reddish brown with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of dark fruit, sour citrus and light barnyard. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a tart finish. Flavors of currants, oak, sour citrus, barnyard and light leather with a crisp dry lingering sour finish.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2008 Pour is almost a red wine with a small ring of foam arond the edge of the glass.  Aroma is of red fruit like berrys or cherries with some sugar and vinegar.  Flavor is holy super sourness! The first things i though of was that this must be what its like to lick the inside of a barle of red wine after you poured it out.  Very big oak flavor along with some leather and earthyness.  I probably takes a lot of skill to make a beer like this.

G.A.B.F. 2008: Pours a deep orange with a tan ring of head. The aroma has some sweet raisin like fruitiness with evident currant- funky leather, and horse blanket. The body is creamy and tart- with an underlying sweet raisin/grape character with earthy oak tannins, a leathery touch, vinous notes and more oak into the finish. This is a young Sour, and I seek a bottle to let it age; I want to see where this goes..
tap.  Wow.  wonderful fruity aroma.  Dark blue amber color.  Nice medium to strong tartness. Easy to drink.  Lots and lots of oak.  Wonderful. 4.5-4.6.

Draught, Falling Rock.

Head is fully diminishing.
Body is dark reddish-amber.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (caramel, toasted grain), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of berries and plum, wood, hint of cinnamon.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic.

Surprisingly uninspiring.  Had a glass all to myself and spent a good while with it, but it never really did much for me.  Its pleasant, no doubt, and clean, but...kind of aimless.  Huge fan of most of Vinnies Belgian style brews, but not so much for this one.  Would have rated it a bit higher (3.8 maybe?) from the one GABF sample I had, but it was a different story with a full glass...it became fatiguing pretty quickly for some reason (too heavy and sweet)...I literally didn’t finish my glass.

GABF 2008.  Dark brown with a faint head.  Incredibly sour body with tart fruityness in the sour aroma.  More like a lambic with the barnyard .  A distinct vinous character to the incredibly sour body.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2010 initial draft rating from last year indicates i liked it, but i havent had a good bottle of consecration since then.  the nose was like creamed black cherries, prickly barnyard and Rodenbach-like flemish red yeast with a heavy wood presence and it seemed to be around 7-8%, but recent bottles are a mess: aspirin/vitamins/minerals/gravel combined with excessive alcohol... it has a bit ethyl acetate problem.  score lowered w/ proper rerate pending.
